column1: 0-           About to go t bed late (again) got sucked into (another) late night film.

2-It was really good made me think
3-The guy screws up his marriage and it made me think about making sure
column3: that mine is tip top.

column1: 4-If I'm honest there are areas that we are just getting by in - so I need to resolve to sort them out now before they are a problem.
5-In the film they both keep diaries so I thought I should blog tonight.
6-Weekend was hectic but great fun.
7-Not that long ago k and I had to work on spending time with other people as a couple.
8-This weekend we never ate alone

column2: P and I went for a very breif trip on the river saturday durring a gap in the weather.

column1: 10-K stripped off and went for a swim
11-Tonight we went out for dinner.
12-It was a lovely evening
column3: so we ate at the Bridge and sat outside

column1: 13-My Dad has always wanted to go to  urlLink America .
14-I have been several times
column3: to see friends or for work.

column1: 15-I'd love to go with Dad and go on a long road trip.
16-Would make a better blog than this.
17-...is a guy painting a blue wall blue.
18-Can't the  urlLink weather  just sort itself out.
19-I'm sure we'd already had 2 heat waves by this point last year.
20-I look out of my window on yet another grey day.
21-I wouldn't mind but this is the last free weekend I'll have in a while I want to be out enjoying it.
22-Yesterday we wrote some thank you cards.
23-Kirsten worked on the garden and I bottled my latest batch of  urlLink beer .
24-In the evening Anna and Jon came around for dinner.
25-I made a lasagne
column3: and it was good fun.

column1: 26-I'd not been feeling too great all day and was exhausted by bed time.
27-This morning K felt ill and stayed in bed.
28-I was stewarding at church and as usual I was put on car parking.
29-We(I) messed up giving out the buckets for the offering but it was ok. After church I dropped some firewood around to Liz and dropped off K's keys while I was there.
30-Liz wasn't in but I saw paddy through the back door as I left the wood.
31-I don't feel that great myself.
32-Might be time to join K in the sick bed.

34-Plus they have free breakfast (quite a spread too!).
35-Good to do a bit of socialising.

column3: was in a building right opposite the  urlLink gherkin .

column1: 37-If I'd known I would have taken my camera.
38-I had a bit of time to kill after getting off the train so I went for a bit of a wander around the city.
39-So I've been in the Cambridge office for 3 days now.
40-The job is good and the people friendly.
41-There is no tuckshop which will be good for my waistline but currently I'm craving snacks!
42-My  urlLink HDD case  arrived on Tuesday.
43-I had a few problems at first getting it working with the aluminum case on but once I added a bit of card under the circuit board to act as insulation it worked fine.
44-It is really small
column2: hardly bigger than a 2.5" drive and it works really well.

column1: 45-Also to arrive on Tuesday was the adoption certificate for my gibbon.
46-NCorp  urlLink adopted  me a gibbon to remind me of them as my leaving gift.
47-I'm sure that I have a part share in a whole troop of gibbons but I like to think there is one that's mine.
48-I have called him Dobbo.
49-Andy  Anita came to dinner on Tuesday night.
50-After dinner the whole proceedings kind of deteriorated into Kirsten and Anita playing the drums while Andy tried to fix my  urlLink sparc station .
51-Much fun was had by all.
52-Yesterday Labhaoise passed her driving test so K and her when to look at cars together.
53-Pete
column3: K and I went to see  urlLink Shrek 2  in the evening which was really good.

55-Pete and I  urlLink fixed  the lights so Labhaoise could drive the car back to their house.
56-Welcome back.
57-Well sort of
column2: I discovered that my old blog from 2000 was still on the blogger.com server.

column1: 58-I read the thirteen posts and they were really dull so I deleted the blog.
59-It was from the days when I was living with my Dad after uni and working for Pilks.
60-It was a month or two before I went to work in the USA which would have made a much more interesting blog had I done it.
61-Tomorrow I'm off to London for my induction meeting at my new company.
62-I'm so relieved to leave NCorp that I haven't really given the new place much thought.
63-I'm sure it will be great
column2: I was really into the new place 3 months ago when I got the job but  urlLink the pangalactic bellwether in miserable notice periods  has kind of taken the sparkle off it a bit.

column1: 64-At least the train ride down will give me time to write to manda - haven't been in touch since the wedding - bad pen pal!0-26
0-        Entry originally posted on 8 August 2003 .
1-This is not a journal in the traditional sense of the word.
2-This is an exploration
column2: a new beginning mapped out through language and metaphor.

column1: 3-There are a great many changes that are taking place in my life.
4-Tommorrow
column2: I will become a mother to a tuxedo cat named Demeter.

column1: 5-In two weeks
column2: I will be starting graduate school
column3: embarking on a life-long journey into the world of academia.

column1: 6-My friend
column2: Julius has joined the Navy and will be shipped off to basic training next week.

column1: 7-Lots of changes.
8-So
column2: this space is a reflection of those changes
column3: the need to write and think beyond the traditional weblog

column1: 9-This space will be composed of ideas
column3: academic pursuits
column4: and the occasional antedote about graduate school and life

column1: 10-There will not be an archive section
column2: because the purpose of this space is to write and live in the present and not rehash the past nor to dwell on the future.

column1: 11-Right now
12-"For the love of God is broader that the measure of the mind And the heart of the Eternal is most wonderfully kind."
13--Our Lady of Mount Carmel Hymn  Michael was the first openly gay man that I met in life.
14-Every day after World Literature we would walk to the college cafeteria and eat lunch together
column3: but mostly we discussed his sexuality and his faith.

column1: 15-I was curious about him
column2: about how he could be both gay and Christian.

column1: 16-I grew up in a Southern Baptist tradition that labeled homosexuals as deviants who were out to corrupt Godde-fearing people.
17-Listening and learning about life through the eyes of scared adults
column2: anything and everything can be painted as black or white
column3: right or wrong

column1: 18-When you are a child
column2: it is hard to see the that the world is comprised of multiple shades of grey.

column1: 19-Therefore
column3: too easy
column4: to judge others for their differences
column5: because you are not yet comfortable in your own skin.

column1: 20-At a time when I was advocating at the top of my lungs against institutionalized Christianity
column2: Michael was advocating in favor of the church.

column1: 21-It baffled me that he did not consider it a paradox
column3: or an oxy-moron to be a gay man and a Christian.

column1: 22-I did not understand how he could support and participate in an institution that stated that Godde hated him for who he loved.
23-Michael told me that he believed that Godde is merciful
column3: and loving
column4: rather than a vindictive deity that is pissed at the world.

column1: 24-"Sometimes the people in charge of the religion
column2: he said, get so wrapped up in the rules that they forget about the message.

column1: 25-The message of Godde
column3: is ultimately about love for your fellow man."

column1: 26-A few weeks later
column2: Michael broke down another barrier of prejuidice that resided inside me.

column1: 27-He told me that he was HIV positive.
28-I remember that we had been sharing a basket of french fries and I was paralyzed with fear at the thought of contracting the disease.
29-Now
column2: I realize that it was a naive and foolish fear
column3: but at that time it was a life-altering experience
column4: because it showed me that who you sleep with is insignificant in the grand scheme of life.

column1: 30-I never saw Michael after that semester.
31-I tried to track him down several times
column2: but never succeeded and I have moments when I wonder if he is even still walking among us.

column1: 32-I am convinced that he was an angel
column2: a messenger sent to me by Godde to teach me about compassion
column3: honesty

column1: 33-In light of recent events that have taken place within my community of faith
column2: I have thought about my friendship with Michael more and more and I often wonder what he would think of all this controversy surrounding a gay man that wants to bring people closer to Godde.

column1: 34-To me it is clear that Godde places people in our lives to teach
column3: and make us better human beings.

column1: 35-Godde does not discriminate and I am very proud of the Episcopal church for recognizing that truth by ordaining Gene Robinson.
36-I will stand by my church and my faith
column2: regardless of the political ramifications that come from this decision.

column1: 37-It is my firm belief that
column3: we will all have to answer for our actions.

column1: 38-To the individuals that are quick to suggest that Gene Robinson will be punished by Godde for his relationship with a man
column2: may I remind you all that casting judgement is also considered to be a sin.

column1: 39-Instead of pointing fingers
40-Open your hearts and embrace the message that is being sent to you.
41-A couple of years ago
column2: I wrote a short story entitled
column3: "Faith is a Funny Thing."

column1: 42-I wrote this story at a time in my life when my quest for spiritual direction was beginning to resemble a fruitless search for a needle in a haystack.
43-In the story
column2: a young woman find solace in a dusty cathedral
column3: the very institution that she spent years denouncing.

column1: 44-It was a piece that would foreshadow my return to the church in the years to come.
45-I was a spiritual pilgrim for the span of a decade
column2: researching and practicing a variety of religions.

column1: 46-I attended a service at a Jewish synagogue
column2: read Thich Nhat Hanh's  Living Buddha
column3: Living Christ
column4: held a full moon ritual in my living room
column5: and attended Catholic Mass on a Sunday afternoon.

column1: 47-In Yann Martel's  The Life of Pi
column3: Pi
column4: practices a multiplicity of religions and sees no conflict in his syncretism.

column1: 48-Halfway through the book
column2: Pi and his family are walking through town and are approached by the leaders of the local temple
column3: church

column1: 49-Each leader tells Pi that he must chose a religion to practice.
50-He can be a devout Hindu
column3: or Muslim
column4: but he can not practice all three faiths at the same time.

column1: 51-Pi remarks that all he wants to do is love God.
52-The church leaders are speechless at the simplicity of that statement.
53-I love to tell people the story of my return to the church.
54-I tell them that I am a Christian because of a conversation that I had with a Pagan.
55-My good friend
column3: listened to me rant on and on about my spiritual crisis until finally she told me that there was no shame in being Christian.

column1: 56-She reminded me that there are a lot of interpretations of what it means to be a Christian
column2: that Jesus was a profound teacher and prophet
column3: and that a great deal of beauty remains in the Christian tradition.

column1: 57-You just have to find a community that you feel comfortable attending.
58-I did.
59-I am an Episcopalian.
60-I am an open-minded
column3: goddess-loving

column1: 61-I believe that Jesus was sent to the Earth to teach and inspire humankind.
62-I believe that Godde is both masculine and feminine and that He/She resides in every single heart that beats on this planet.
63-I am addicted to Sufi poetry
column3: and Celtic rituals.

column1: 64-Religion
column3: is not about the rules
column4: but what road the heart travels.

column1: 65-If our motive in life is to love Godde
column2: regardless of the form that being/spirit takes
column3: then does it really matter how we go about expressing that love?

column1: 66-My answer is no
67-Rituals
column3: and theology are wonderful things until they begin to place limitations on a person's soul.

column1: 68-In the end
column2: what matters the most is how that person uses their faith in the world.

column1: 69-Their actions towards other human beings are a reflection of their interpretation of Godde.
70-The rest is just ashes and dust.
71-I believe in eating.
72-I think women especially have this fear of eating
column2: and I think there is a whole euphoric plane you can rise to when you have a good meal.

column1: 73-You sit down and with every bite you honestly just say thank you.
74-(Tori Amos)  I was eight years old when I went on my first diet.
75-I have this memory of standing on the scales in the pediatrician's office and hearing the doctor tell my mother that I was fat.
76-As an adult
column2: I look at pictures taken of me during that time and I often wonder what the doctor was thinking.

column1: 77-I looked like a healthy
78-My mother immediately put me on a diet.
79-She gave my grandmother the strictest orders not to let me eat anything other than cantaloupe for a snack.
80-Nan took pity on me after the second week of scarfing down cantaloupe; she gave me cookies and ate the fruit herself.
81-I have not eaten cantaloupe since that summer.
82-My weight haunts me.
83-It speaks to me
column2: nit-picks me in the guise of voices from the past; Lance Crane telling our fifth grade classmates that there would be no more ice cream left once I went through the serving line
column3: the constant pressure of being stick thin in high school
column4: and my best guy friend from college telling me that men did not like girls with guts and if I wanted a boyfriend then I would have to lose weight
column5: because no guy would want me otherwise.

column1: 84-These are the things that I think about when I am in the presence of a man
column2: even if that man is my lover.

column1: 85-I know that it does not do well to dwell on the past
column2: but when you spend your life hearing that you are less because you are more
column3: it is hard to believe that beauty resides within your body.

column1: 86-I do not blame my mother for her obsession with my weight.
87-It seems that she too was contantly struggling with her self-esteem in that realm.
88-In her mind big was a simple translation for ugly and so I can not hold her actions against her
column2: because she was suffering from the same societal ideals of beauty.

column1: 89-She was struggling to feel beautiful and she wanted me to not have that struggle.
90-It amazes me how many beautiful women
column2: who I am surrounded by on a daily basis
column3: think that they are hiddeous.

column1: 91-I read my livejournal
column3: listen to my friends; all of them think that they are less than wonderful
column5: this culture tells them that they are worthless unless they have Sarah Jessica Parker's body
column6: a body that has no curves
column8: and is nothing but skin drawn taunt over bone.

column1: 92-How is that beautiful?
93-I stand in front of the mirror naked and I like what I see.
94-I walk around my apartment without clothes
column3: finally
column4: learning to be comfortable in my own skin.

column1: 95-It has nothing to do with being sexy
column2: although if you ask me I will tell you that I am sexy
column3: and everything to do with feeling at ease with the woman that I have become.

column1: 96-Yes
column2: I want to lose a few more pounds
column3: for health reasons.

column1: 97-Next week
column2: I am going back to the pool and swimming laps
column3: because I miss the feel of the water between my thighs and the burning in my lungs when I am holding my breathe.

column1: 98-I want to
column3: be addicted to the feel of gliding through the water.

column1: 99-I used to swim two miles non-stop
column2: the equivalent of 72 laps in an Olympic-size pool
column3: and I want that to happen again.

column1: 100-Until then
column2: I will continue to stand in front of the mirror and celebrate my hips that could bring children into this world with great ease
column3: my breasts that are full and lovely and tinted at the tips with a shade of pink

column1: 101-I am a work of art
102-As women
column2: we must learn to embrace ourselves and not fall victim to the societal contructs of beauty.

column1: 103-If society had its way
column2: I would be the size of my letter-opener
column3: quiet

column1: 105-Fucking.
106-Thank You.
107-This one is for you
108-I want to talk about censorship.
109-I want to talk about what happens when you get home after a hard day and find that you father has left a message on your machine
column2: telling you that he read your website and that he thinks that using the "f-word" to make a point is very inappropriate.

column1: 110-If it were any other person
column2: I would launch into a lecture about my right to free speech
column3: free assembly
column4: and the academic concept of language reclamation.

column1: 111-However
column2: when it is with my father
column3: confrontation seems more difficult
column4: because I was daddy's little girl long before I was a feminist.

column1: 112-When you plant your feet
column3: mind
column4: and soul under the banner of feminism
column5: loving men reaches a level of frustration that is unparallel to any other experience.

column1: 113-There are a great number of men who continue to identify feminism as an anti-male campaign.
114-This is a lie.
115-The complexity with feminism and my relationship with my father is that it is difficult to play out simultaneous roles.
116-I can no longer play the role of dutiful daughter
column2: because the woman inside me is demanding justice.

column1: 117-I can no longer pretend that my father is a paragon of perfection
118-For any woman who once thought that her father walked on water
column2: it is a hard lesson to learn when you discover that you are a disappointment to the man who gave you life.

column1: 119-I am sorry that I disappointed you
120-I am sorry that you think there is hypocrisy in my lifestyle because I use vulgar language and then call myself a Christian
column2: but I will not censor myself for anyone
column3: especially not for you.

column1: 121-You were the person who taught me to be strong
column3: to always be true to myself
column4: and to believe that I could do anything that I put my mind to.

column1: 122-Now
column2: you are telling me that the way that I conduct myself is inappropriate and even though you do not verbalize it
column3: the insinuation in your message is this;  the man who I adore most in the world is ashamed of me.

column1: 123-That is a bitter pill to swallow
column2: even for the most ardent feminist.

column1: 124-I still remember what it felt like to be the pride and joy in your life and thought it sounds selfish -even to my own ears- it hurts to even consider the possibility that those feelings are no longer present in your heart when you think of me.
125-Sunday evening
column2: I went to church for the first time since my confirmation in June.

column1: 126-It is pathetic and sad
column2: how distracted I became this past summer.

column1: 127-Lust overcame my heart and I pulled away from Godde
column2: deserting my faith for the simple pleasures of the skin.

column1: 128-Yet
column2: when the inevitable happened and that man disappeared from my life
column3: I found myself clinging to my faith like a life-raft.

column1: 129-Godde became my glue and she held me together during that horrible time
column2: when I felt him slip through my fingers.

column1: 130-Godde continues to hold me together as I am writing these words.
131-It felt like coming home when I received communion.
132-I could feel this overwhelming sense of purpose and direction flood through my body
133-When I tasted the bread
column2: for the first time in months
column3: it had a dry bitter flavor
column4: but it connected me with the others in the church.

column1: 134-When I drank the wine
column2: I could feel the blood of Christ renewing me
column3: strenghtening me
column4: preparing me for the road ahead.

column1: 135-Catholics believe that the Eucharist involves the process of transubstantiation
column2: where the bread and wine are
column3: literally
column4: the body and blood of Christ.

column1: 136-Episcopalians recognize this belief
column2: but tend to view the Eucharist as a symbolic act
column3: rather than a literal one.

column1: 137-In my opinion
column2: Christianity is about the blessing of this sacrament.

column1: 138-Long before there were numerous denominations
column2: the early Christians were meeting in secret to receive bread and wine.

column1: 139-They risked persecution
column3: for this simple act.

column1: 140-The Eucharist is an invisible rope that
column2: through this acknowledgement of the sacrifice of Christ
column3: binds Christians to one another.

column1: 141-Growing up in a Southern Baptist tradition
column2: I received communion during two services a year
column3: Christmas and Easter.

column1: 142-I never considered communion to be an active part of the faith and when I started attending services at the Episcopal church
column2: I thought it strange that Episcopalians received the Eucharist every single Sunday without fail.

column1: 143-Now
column2: I can no longer imagine going to church and not receiving communion before I go out into the world.

column1: 144-It is the ultimate business card
column3: take our Savior with you.

column1: 145-His body and blood are yours
column2: if you wish to carry it inside of you .

column1: 146-It is an incredible gift.
147-This is the reason that I am a Christian.
148-The Eucharist brought me comfort when my relationship with Gene was falling apart.
149-I know that there are a number of theological interpretations within the world-wide Christian community
column2: so many that at times it seems as if that community will fall apart.

column1: 150-The Eucharist is what binds us together in the face of adversity and change.
151-It is an integral part of the faith.
152-It is what brings Christians back into the church
column2: even after they have been gone for days
column3: weeks

column1: 153-It is a blessing.
154-It is home.
155-Fortune cookies are beautiful things.
156-I get excited
column2: like a school-girl in a candy shop
column3: at the very thought of what the Fates are contemplating sending in my direction.

column1: 157-I hold on to my fortunes
column2: those little paper notes that following in the wake of a simple cracking of a cookie.

column1: 158-I have it taped to my computer monitor
column2: this one fortune that reminds me to savor life and live for the moment.

column1: 159-You will discover the truth in time .
160-I meditate on these words every single day
column2: searching for a better understanding of what they mean in relation to my life.

column1: 161-At first
column2: I thought the note was a message from Godde about my ex-boyfriend
column3: putting me at ease about our troubled relationship
column4: letting me know that we would overcome our differences and move forward together.

column1: 162-How naive was I
column2: to think that I knew the meaning of truth
column3: the meaning of time?

column1: 163-There are moments in my life
column2: where I feel like I am in a rush to learn everything at once.

column1: 164-I worry that I will run out of time and that I will never discover the truth about myself
column3: and Godde.

column1: 165-I obsess over the fear that I will never find a safe
column3: loving relationship with a man.

column1: 166-There are so many items that occupy my mind
167-It is only my faith
column3: that allows me to take a deep breath and force these thoughts out of my mind.

column1: 168-I remind myself that there is a plan
169-Despite the presence of my fears
column2: I feel more grounded now than I have at any other point in my life.

column1: 170-I have a wonderful job and my career goals for the future have come full circle in the wake of my return to school.
171-I am surrounded by the most incredible support network of family and friends.
172-I go to an incredible church
column2: a place where I am encouraged to think about my faith instead of blindly accepting doctrine.

column1: 173-I have a cat who adores me.
174-Truly
175-I came here
column2: once or twice since I last wrote
column3: with no topic in my mind.

column1: 176-I came here with a voice
column2: but no words to give that voice a contextual meaning.

column1: 177-What should I write about in this space?
178-Should I tell you about my ex-boyfriend
column2: how his memory continues to break me
column3: even after he abdicated from my love?

column1: 179-Should I discuss the weather
column2: the change of colors and climate?

column1: 180-Perhaps
column2: I could write about my indecisiveness regarding the future; professional and personal?

column1: 181-With each passing day
column2: I am becoming more of an introvert
column3: more shy with the world.

column1: 182-I enjoy my new-found solitude
column2: but I would be lying if I did not admit that there are times when the loneliness hits me hard.

column1: 183-There are times when I wish for a companion
184-I want a man in my life
column2: not for sex or romantic love
column3: but for friendship
column4: for those times when I need strong arms to hold me.

column1: 185-I am fully aware of my faults.
186-I am stubborn
column3: loud

column1: 187-I am passionate
column2: almost to the point of being militant
column3: about certain issues.

column1: 188-I have no problem with expressing my opinion
column2: to an individual or a crowd of people.

column1: 189-I am an emotional eater.
190-I have a vulgar sense of humor and a tendency to use excessive amounts of profanity in any given situation.
191-I am picky about spelling
column3: and style.

column1: 192-For all of my faults
column2: I have just as many good qualities.

column1: 193-I am intelligent.
194-I write a mean research paper.
195-I try to see beauty in everything.
196-I have strong faith.
197-I like to give back to my community.
198-I want to make the world a better place to live
199-I want to be a role model for young girls who are searching for an idenity in this crazy messed-up world.
200-I am compassionate and giving.
201-I put my all into my friendships and relationships.
202-I love sex.
203-(Of course there are some individuals who would argue that this is a negative quality.
204-Screw them.)
205-I am honest.
206-Also
column2: while I may never win the Miss America pagent and I know that I have some weight to lose
column3: I do not believe that I am hard on the eyes.

column1: 207-I can look myself in the mirror and see a valuable woman who posesses beauty
column2: even if it is of the inward variety.

column1: 208-I am not perfect
209-October is a difficult month for me.
210-Three years ago
column2: Nan died on Friday the thirteenth.

column1: 211-She died in her sleep; she had sat down to take a nap during the middle of the day and when her daughter came home from work
column2: she discovered that her mother was no longer among the living.

column1: 212-The funeral took place on what would have been an otherwise gorgeous autumn afternoon.
213-As I watched her casket being lowered into the ground
column2: I could not help but ponder the irony of burying my grandmother
column3: my spiritual rock
column4: on such a day as that one.

column1: 214-A couple of years later
column2: my family buried our beloved pet
column3: Freckles
column7: an ailment that is very common amongst male cocker spaniels.

column1: 215-It happened so fast and I will never forget my mother calling me and tearfully telling me about his passing.
216-She loved that dog.
217-It seems that there is so much pain in life.
218-Sometimes
column2: I want to wail against Godde
column3: because I know that she has the power to cease the world's suffering and sadness.

column1: 219-Then
column2: there are moments that I know I am growing stronger
column3: because of the suffering that I have had to endure at times.

column1: 220-The fall is the perfect time of year to reflect on that strength.
221-In the tradition of the Celts
column2: the autumn season has become my personal New Year's celebration.

column1: 222-I use this time to re-focus my goals
column2: especially since I have a habit of getting distracted over the summer.

column1: 223-This is the time of year that I pay homage to those individuals who have passed through the veil.
224-I miss her.
225-There are still days where I feel an overwhelming need to hear her voice over the phone or to hold her hand.
226-When I realize that this is no longer a possibility
column2: there is a sharp pain that runs straight through my heart.

column1: 227-It takes my breath away and I start to leak silent tears.
228-I watch the students in this college town.
229-You would think they're carefree
column3: Frowning into Shakespeare and practicing their smiles

column1: 0-            The history of seitans origin and different ways to prepare the seitan.
1-Seitan (say-TAHN) is made from gluten.
2-Gluten is the name of the insoluble protein in wheat
column2: probably most familiar as the stuff that makes bread dough elastic.

column1: 3-Known as Seitan in Japan
column3: and as "wheat meat" and "gluten" here in the U.S.

column1: 4-It has been eaten in China
column3: Korea
column4: Russia and the Middle East for thousands of years.

column1: 5-Gluten is often referred to in Chinese restaurants as "Buddha food"
column2: because of the claim that it was developed by pacifist
column3: vegetarian Buddhist monks as a meat substitute.

column1: 6-It is a food rich in tradition as well as nutrition.
7-As a protein source
column2: seitan contains about 31 grams of protein per 4 ounce serving (which means it has more plant protein per serving than tofu)
column3: provides a modest amount of B vitamins and iron and contains no saturated fat or cholesterol.

column1: 8-A 3 1/2 ounce (100 gram) serving contains 118 calories
column2: 18% protein and less than 1% unsaturated fat.

column1: 9-The same amount of beef has 207 calories and 32.2% protein and is high in saturated fats.
10-As recent studies have shown
column2: our need for protein is much lower than previously believed and any opportunity to remove saturated fats from our diet would be an excellent improvement.

column1: 11-Another dietary benefit of seitan is its low sodium content
column2: although cooking often adds considerably to this.

column1: 12-Most of the commercially prepared seitan contains a considerable amount of sodium (up to 100 mg. per ounce).
13-If you choose to deep-fry the gluten
column2: the fat content will jump from virtually zero to the number of grams in whatever oil is absorbed (at 4.5 grams per teaspoon).

column1: 14-Moreover
column3: this protein is incomplete and needs to be complemented with other protein sources such as dairy or legumes.

column1: 15-Many vegetarians' first experience with eating gluten is at Chinese or Vietnamese restaurants
column3: "mock chicken"

column1: 16-When it's sold in little tubs at the natural/health food store
column3: probably because marketing studies showed that the word "gluten" lacks consumer appeal.

column1: 17-It stands in for meat in many recipes and works so well that some vegetarians prefer to avoid it because the texture is too "meaty."
18-However
column2: for many vegetarians and others who are trying to make the transition to a meatless lifestyle
column3: Wheat Meat" is growing in popularity.

column1: 19-Seitan usually starts out as whole grain wheat or high gluten flour mixed with water to obtain a bread dough consistency.
20-The dough is kneaded vigorously for about 10 minutes
column2: and then is left to rest so the gluten can develop.

column1: 21-Next
column2: it is rinsed many times under running water
column3: which removes most of the starch and much of the bran.

column1: 22-What is left is a firm
column2: stringy mass of high protein gluten that is then cooked in soy sauce and water with other spices added for flavoring
column3: often including the sea vegetable kombu.

column1: 23-When raw gluten (wheat dough with the starch washed away) has been cooked in a broth of shoyu
column3: and kombu

column1: 24-It is now ready to be used in casseroles
column3: sandwiches
column4: and enchiladas or just about anywhere that you might previously have used meat.

column1: 25-It can be oven-braised
column3: cooked in a pressure cooker

column1: 26-Each version yields a different texture.
27-Oven braising produces a texture similar to the chewy texture derived from simmering.
28-Baking produces a light texture that works well when grinding or grating seitan.
29-Pressure-cooking will produce a softer texture.
30-Fried gluten turns soft and slippery when cooked with a sauce and absorbs flavor well.

DISJOINTED   Who am I to tell you to stay and master the infinite complexities of unknown now  when power struggles weigh heavy on the scales shucked off with a borrowed knife and shining in the early light like rainbow fingernails  the missing piece is always missing or it would not be a piece  there are no stand alones or one offs or this or that creation to believe in something better different new  dreams are analyzed and shown on television for the masses wanting reality when truth does not connect them  soft edges the day at home incapable of being the listener to act alone  what purpose vision or adjustment or rain from these clouds heavy and boxes stacked like waiting for something grander or a kick in the ass never coming from one's own foot

DAYLIGHT SAVINGS   Fire does not sit well with me alone in this room still  and sweat is hanging like a heavy too big to hold child  in this room humid airless  and I could go open the windows  and I could turn on the air  but no and not and suffer this martyr I am not satisfied with all of my choice with all of my everything told I can do whatever I want as wanting makes  as desire fufills  as comfort shields my eyes I see nothing but blind  as routine paves my sidewalk I feel nothing under foot  as more advice to stay to not risk to not dare or dream or trust or live  all of the voices stop I have heard all the words from inside before  and this is just another hole and it's for me to decide something new and not worry about right

404   In an instant this one was gone in a blank nothing of return key silence  having filled the virtual page with words so cleansing and even on this one the ending was fabulous  but something happened page cannot be displayed this blog sever down  despair my words were not retained

EXPLAINING THE SILENCE   Three months passed with nothing much to say being on a power high and all or at least thinking I was but the pixie dust washed off in the turpentine bath and all that was left was dirty feet  The answer was not found in that question.

765-I must have been asking the wrong but how could I know and what made me think and maybe if and what about that and should I shouldn't I would I could I  trust myself to even trust the universe as though stars represent some kind of why enough to make us feel small and I say  no again not this time  running jump and slide  your whole life is this dive down down deep

APPEARANCE   PMS makes more sense than another 10 years of this goddamn job everyone says is so great because it pays the bills  so it goes  as he'd say  as for me I have had enough  as for me my last never is worked  I'd have to be out of my mind to stay another minute  I'd have to be drugged and sacked in burlap  Even that sounds like more fun than another drive on the turnpike  back and forth endlessly  making someone look good

IT ALWAYS COMES TO THIS   the moment of flight  people parachutes  a lead weight a helium balloon  whispers from an alley a stern glance of disapproval  acceptance the unknown  trust shame  the ego's despair  clutching grappling and dusting off  the cape

I CRADLE IF   I cradle If and dress her up like dolls for girls to play with  I hold her hand at the end of the street and look both ways before crossing  Late at night I tuck her in with When and How beside her  If I were If I'd never know fuck is this cadence or what is this shit that's happening

CROSSROADS   Pounding breath is shallow body thick and hard with tense hammering desire to quit to flee to love to be to stop copying and start creating to move on and find the path is still there winding to another crossroads somewhere further on

RSVP   Busting out a tickle pins and needles inside below the rib cage  the urge is so strong to live to create to be become feel free  liberated at last  something unknown magnetic tractor beam pulling me towards the next step  life mapped out and the bread crumbs eaten by forest animals  body draped on the massage table while my neck is pulled and pushed left center right  scolded for wearing my shoulders around my neck and the woman's pecs forgotten  hunching over from too much keyboard caressing  my fingers begin to curl  until at last reminded  death does not have to come by invitation

DIALOGUE WITH YOURSELF   Did you expect to find me here in this location starting out at you  and we I mean you and I being you  you feel who you are talking to who is talking to you from behind these fingertips ever pressing and there is nothing but the abyss of bytes spewing data like stars the universe expanding exploding consciousness in batches recorded here for all to see  like blindness like turning away and what is visual is what is coming to screen  and I am alive here and with you as much as you will let me be  there is brightness illumination signalling and like a race to the finish  you are with me now and who am I but you
ALCOHOLIC   Weak

column1: 2006-food and water too close to litterbox  objectionable chemical used to wash or disinfect litterbox  location preference: your cat may want the box in a different location  texture preference: your cat doesn't like the feel of the litter  failure to cover litter: learned process from parents  use of litterbox is instinctive  cats that don't cover litter may be more prone to litterbox problems  your cat may be indicating texture preference problem     POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS  provide a box for each cat  change litter daily  provide constant access to a box  go back to previously used brand of litter and/or discontinue new disinfectant  move box to where it was previously used  eliminate new or frightening noise near litterbox  move food and water away from litterbox  if cat is only going in one spot

Bees invade the internet   By BBC News Online internet reporter Mark Ward  Soon software that acts like bees or ants could be running the internet.
2293-Researchers at the University of California are claiming that we need radically new ways to run the net as more and more people and devices go online.
2294-Michael Wang and Tatsuya Suda say that existing methods of keeping the net going will not be able to cope when billions of people
column3: hand-held computers and household appliances are routinely using it to communicate.

column1: 2295-What is needed
column3: are self-organising systems inspired by biology.

column1: 2296-The researchers are experimenting with discrete programs called agents that have been modelled on bees and ants.

2297-Individually these insects are very stupid but put enough of them together and they do a very efficient job of running and maintaining huge structures like nests and hives without any central control.
2298-By contrast
column2: current internet management systems tend to be very centralised and directed by people.

column1: 2299-Mr Wang says that this set-up will be unable to cope when everything from our PCs to refrigerators is online.
2300-No-one will have the time or inclination to ensure that all the devices are doing what they should
2301-"The devices should just self-manage or self-organise and just do the right things
column2:
says Mr Wang.
2302-Many popular web events already struggle to serve all the people that want to see them.
2303-When Sir Paul McCartney did a webcast of a performance at the Cavern in Liverpool, servers were overwhelmed by the numbers wanting to watch the show.
2304-Under the scheme proposed by the US researchers, as a website increases in popularity the content on it, be it a video or audio stream, will be copied and ferried to websites closer to the people trying to see or hear it.
2305-Mr Wang says that the user requests are like food and the small software programs that ferry the content across are like bees blazing a trail to the source.
2306-The bees die" when users stop requesting clips.

column1: 2307-Belgian scientist Marco Dorigo is looking at using small
column3: ant-like programs to improve the running of the internet.

column1: 2308-But he is proposing to let the ants run the infrastructure of the net rather than just serve up video clips to people.
2309-The bee-like software entities are programmed with a few simple rules that define what they do.
2310-This rule-based approach is also being used to recreate huge battle scenes for the Lord of the Rings movie currently being filmed in New Zealand.
2311-The troops in the battle scenes are computer-generated orcs
column3: humans and dwarves that have been programmed with a few rules that define their fighting style
column4: who their enemies are and what to do when a foe has been killed.

column1: 2312-Battle commences when the troops are unleashed on each other and computer cameras record the flow of action.

urlLink Are We Not Geeks?
2318-Tolkien and his keen readers are often criticised for being stuck in eternal adolescence
2319-I'd like to take a closer look at these labels.
2320-Consider how many useful and pragmatic people read therapy and self-help books because they're want to fulfil their potential as balanced
2321-Many of these books talk about the notion of nurturing one's 'inner child.'
2322-The inner child is that part of us that feels enthusiasm and joy most strongly
column2: and which responds most truthfully to the world.

column1: 2323-Well and good; evidently the "inner child" is regarded as good and precious.
2324-But what can we say about the inner adolescent?
2325-Why aren't we nurturing the inner adolescent?
2326-I think you can hardly say the phrase 'teenager' these days without immediately thinking of somebody rebellious and confused
column2: or remembering one's own years of irritable awkwardness.

column1: 2327-We haven't got a lot good to say about teenagers
2328-The author Philip Pullman wrote something very interesting in response to a question about why he preferred to write for and about teenagers.
2329-At that age
column3: children are becoming aware of the world in a new way
column4: and they have time to ask the big questions: What is the meaning of life

column1: 2330-Later on we get busy
column3: and we are in danger of forgetting we ever cared.

column1: 2331-I'd agree with that.
2332-I'd go further and say that for many teenagers
column2: those years are a time of great stress partly because it is an age of idealism and yet they are just beginning to learn about the world's tired habits - its petty hypocrisies
column3: callous persecutions
column6: and the ignoble worms of greed that gnaw away at the heart of every great enterprise... Teenagers rage against the wrongness of the world because they see it more freshly and it wounds them more keenly.

column1: 2333-As one becomes older
column3: and tireder
column4: it seems less hassle to take the easy course
column6: to be politic more often than honest.

column1: 2334-I think teenagers rage against growing into that state
column2: and the best of them still believe that they will change the world by virtue of naming and confronting its evils.

column1: 2335-I'd like to throw in one of the ultimate Romantic poems I've ever come across.
2336-It's by an Argentinean poet
column2: and to me it sums up that idealism of adolescence which rejects the deceitful world with one grand gesture:   For Afterwards  I would like to die when the day is ending on the open sea and looking at the sky; where the agony of death may seem but sleep and the soul may seem a bird which mounts in flight.

column1: 2337-And in the final instants I would hear
column2: already with the sky and sea alone
column3: no other sobbing prayers or sobbing voices than those of waves in their majestic fall.

column1: 2338-To die when life is sadly hauling back  its golden nets from out the tide's deep green and be like yonder sun that dies down slowly: some very shining thing that's lost from sight.
2339-To die
column3: before unfaithful time destroys the delicate and gentle crown; whilst life still tells us: I am yours although we know so well it will betray us.

column1: 2340-Manuel Gutierrez (1859 - 1895) (Translation: Gordon Challis)  Yes
column2: a modern person might find this sentimental and grandiose.

column1: 2341-It is utterly fantastical in its all-or-nothing approach to life.
2342-It offers no gritty pragmatic solutions to the problem of living in a less-than-perfect world.
2343-It may be adolescent in its grand gesture of utterly rejecting the world in all its complex awfulness.
2344-But would the world be a richer place if everything as great
column2: beautiful and futile as this poem
column3: were banished from our consciousness?

column1: 2345-I could not bear the loss.
2346-For this is the inner teenager that Tolkien and many other fantasy books appeal to.

2347-They are books that are about honour and justice and the recognition of absolute good and evil; they are books about daring and courage and ultimate sacrifices and grand gestures against hopeless odds.

2348-Nobody has lost that inner teenager who has flung aside their life and decided to change a political system or overturn a scientific belief; or who has shrugged off convention in order to embark on a great love affair across continents and oceans.
2349-Sadly
column2: it is the inner teenager we appeal to when we send young men off to die in wars; but it is my belief that all those who have risked their lives to stand up against oppression and injustice called on their inner teenager too.

column1: 2350-Because when teenagers look at the status quo they see wrongs
column3: whether society wants to hear or not.

column1: 2351-The whole question of geekdom has interested me for a while too.
2352-Other people are involved in writing more about this
column2: but I'll take the liberty of pre-empting their more extensive study with a few thoughts.

column1: 2353-Firstly

2354-Articles like Julian Dibbell's 'Lord of the Geeks' article on Village Voice seem to deride geeks as a minority of outsiders while simultaneously fearing that they're some vast inchoate conspiracy which controls the technology underpinning our modern world.
2355-They're losers
column3: but by some unfair twist of fate and genetics
column4: they get to spend their lives doing cool things with art

column1: 2356-(And I might add that some of them get shockingly rich doing it too
column2: and have to travel round the world for their pains.)

column1: 2357-My own definition of geeks is this: A geek cares about a subject or system so much that they're willing to learn how to master it
column2: whether anyone else cares about it or not.

column1: 2358-The link between geeks and teenagers exists because before that age
column2: if a child is fascinated by something
column3: we just think they're absorbed in play.

column1: 2359-It's only when they hit their teen years that we notice geeks because there's some expectation that they should be out partying and socialising.
2360-Instead they sometimes - or often - put aside their interest in other people because they'd rather be problemsolving on their computer
column2: or memorising the entire history of the Plantagenets
column3: or thinking up stories about an imaginary world
column4: or practicing scales for three hours on the violin.

column1: 2361-Sometimes they're fixed on a goal known only to themselves
column2: sometimes they've found a close-knit gang with similar interests
column3: but in any case they'll follow their own instincts or interests
column4: no matter what anybody else thinks.

column1: 2362-The larger group of non-geeks is always going to be nervous of somebody who resists the easiest form of social control
2363-In their eyes
column2: you should be able to laugh at somebody and tease them for being different
column3: and that should be sufficient to make them toe the line and make a bit more of an effort to appear similar to everyone else.

column1: 2364-Geeks resist that because
column3: it'd mean giving up the things that matter more than conformity.

column1: 2365-There's always been geeks.
2366-Mozart?
2367-What a nerd!
2368-He had to be a geek.

column2: violent centuries of the Dark Ages?

column1: 2371-Geek monks who remembered what civilisation was!

column2: with their heads in the clouds.

column1: 2374-And so I ask
column2: if anything worth doing is to be done: Are we not geeks?

column1: urlLink SELF-HELP: Divorce  DIVORCE: A Crisis
column2: Any Way You Look At It   If you are currently facing the realities of a divorce--either as a partner in a failing marriage
column3: or as a child of parents whose marriage is ending--you are not alone.

column1: 2490-More than two and one-half million adults divorce every year; and more than a million children become children of divorced parents.
2491-Divorce is a CRISIS of major proportions
column2: second only to death of a spouse or parent in terms of the emotional trauma
column3: stress

column1: 2492-According to the dictionary
column2: a "crisis" is a situation whose outcome decides whether possible bad consequences will occur.

column1: 2493-That is
column2: a crisis is not automatically a disaster; it is only potentially so.

column1: 2494-In fact
column2: the Chinese word for crisis is composed of symbols meaning DANGER and OPPORTUNITY.

column1: 2495-The process of coming to terms with a divorce (or any other crisis/loss
column2: for that matter) necessarily involves consideration of both its dangers and opportunities.

column1: 2496-The dangers associated with divorce can be summed up in one word--LOSS.
2497-Whether you are a partner willingly seeking divorce or a partner who is resisting the action or a child who has no choice in the matter
column2: you will incur serious losses as a result of divorce.

column1: 2498-Recognizing the extent of the losses--economic losses
column3: loss of previous social life
column4: loss of daily contact with children
column9: to name a few--is the first step toward identifying
column11: and resolving the wide range of intense feelings that accompany such losses.

column1: 2499-It is important to realize that the above losses result in emotional trauma.
2500-Reactions in the early stages of loss/trauma can include numbness
column3: and denial as well as helplessness

column1: 2501-In these early stages
column2: it is helpful to acknowledge the losses and the tremendous pain associated with them; to remind yourself that you will survive; to recognize the universality of loss reactions and that you are not alone; to remind yourself that it is normal and healthy to experience pain with loss and encourage yourself to sit with the pain; to take care of yourself by getting rest
column3: allowing friends to give you support
column4: building in structure to counter the sense of being out of control
column6: seeking out the comfort of others who have experienced similar losses; and seeking help and guidance immediately
column7: if you think you need it.

column1: 2502-A later stage in the loss process involves aspects of mourning.
2503-Feelings most often associated with this stage are anger and depression.
2504-Again
column2: it is important to understand and accept these feelings as legitimate.

column1: 2505-It is also important to give yourself time to experience and work through these feelings
column2: rather than allowing yourself to run away through compulsive activities
column3: new relationships
column4: or acting out the feelings through self-defeating behaviors or activities.

column1: 2506-The dangers of divorce for children are similar to those listed above but more intense.
2507-For children
column2: a divorce means the loss of their family as they have known it.

column1: 2508-This loss most often stimulates overwhelming fears of abandonment
column3: and disaster.

column1: 2509-Furthermore
column2: most children lack the emotional equipment to deal constructively with these intense feelings.

column1: 2510-Thus
column2: they often engage in acting-out behaviors which can bring on more trauma and loss.

column1: 2511-To help them cope with the dangers of divorce
column3: non-blaming and honest information about what is happening and what they can expect.

column1: 2512-They need reassurance that their parents are not divorcing them
column2: and that the parent-child relationships will be preserved and protected at all costs.

column1: 2513-They need to be protected from the negative or bitter feelings in the marriage.
2514-They need structure and routine and consistency.
2515-Finally
column2: they need help in identifying and legitimizing the many intense and scary emotions they are feeling.

column1: 2516-And they need to be given alternatives for expressing and coping with these feelings.
2517-As stated earlier
column2: the crisis of divorce involves not only danger but also opportunity.

column1: 2518-Once the traumatic feelings of pain and loss are being managed and the survival stage worked through
column2: one can approach the healing and growing stages of loss/divorce.

column1: 2519-The crisis of divorce necessarily presents new beginnings.
2520-it offers the opportunity for self-examination and self-renewal
column3: in turn

column1: 2521-At this point
column2: it is possible to view a divorce
column3: not as a failure

column1: 2522-Through such processes as forgiving (self and others)
column2: focusing on the gain that comes from pain
column3: taking constructive action
column4: discovering new relationships and new interests
column6: one is able to build joy
column9: and peace back into your life.

column1: 2523-For many
column2: they end up with a better life and self than they started with before the crisis.

column1: 2524-For most of us
column2: the challenge of coping with both the dangers and opportunities of divorce are enormous.

column1: 2525-There are many books available to assist you in these challenges.
2526-Two useful ones are Divorcing by Kranzler and Belli (detailing the emotional and legal/logistical aspects of divorce) and How to Survive the Loss of a Love by Colgrove
column2: Bloomfiled and McWilliams (dealing with emotional survival
column3: healing
column4: and growing from loss in general).

column1: 2527-Also be reminded that there are professionals on campus who understand the painful realities of divorce and who can help you survive and eventually thrive following divorce.
2528-Consult with the Counseling Center in Shoemaker Hall (314-7651) or the Mental Health Clinic in the Health Center (314-8106).
2529-They offer support and help.
2530-The author
column3: is a staff psychologist at the University Counseling Center.

column1: urlLink   THE FOUR EMOTIONAL STAGES OF DIVORCE WORK by Phil Rich
column3: MSW.

column1: 2540-The End of Marriage   The hallmark of the marriage is the expectation that this is to be a permanent relationship
column2: in which both partners commit their lives to one another
column3: joining their individual lives together in mutual co-existence.

column1: 2541-Accordingly
column2: the breakup of a marriage can be devastating and life disrupting.

column1: 2542-Divorce may be the sensible route to go for any number of reasons
column2: but nevertheless unless completely amicable and acceptable to both parties
column3: divorce represents the ending of a romance and the failure of a partnership in marriage
column4: and is bound to have an emotional impact on one or both partners.

column1: 2543-Regardless of the circumstances of a divorce or the conditions that led up to it
column2: the clear basis for any divorce work is the idea that the break up of a marriage is a loss.

column1: 2544-Divorce is composed of both "technical" and "emotional" aspects.
2545-The technical aspects will be taken care of
column2: one way or another by the legal process.

column1: 2546-But the "other" side of the process deals with the emotional aftermath.
2547-This is "divorce work" -- the process of dealing with and working through the sense of loss
column3: and situations caused by the divorce.

column1: 2548-The Emotional Stages of Divorce  Although every divorce is highly personal and unique
column2: it can help divorcees to know that they're not alone in their confusion and despair
column3: and that things improve over time.

column1: 2549-At this difficult time
column2: it can help to understand what's typical in the divorce process
column3: what to expect from their emotions and their life as their divorce progresses through the final decree and beyond
column4: and the sort of emotional and practical issues that they're likely to experience

column1: 2550-These are the "emotional" stages of divorce -- the sequence of feelings and issues that divorcees typically go through.
2551-The necessary emotional aspects of divorce work
column2: include:  facing the reality of the divorce  working through painful feelings  experiencing the full range of emotions associated with the breakdown of a marriage  coping with the situational and lifestyle changes resulting from loss  adapting to the change
column3: and reconfiguring life    Stage 1:  "Shock and Disbelief" begins as soon as the idea of a separation and divorce is introduced and sinks in.

column1: 2552-It involves four major tasks and issues to be worked through.

2553-Facing reality  Self esteem and inadequacy  Telling the world  Support and help    Stage 2:  "Initial Adjustment" involves the ability of people to actively adapt to this new phase of their lives.

2554-The primary goal of this stage is adaptation and mustering the personal resources needed to manage the many emotional and practical changes faced by people during this phase of their divorce work
column2: and tasks include:  Functioning and responsibility  Practical reality  Legal Matters  Managing emotions    Stage 3:  "Active Re-organization" centers around how people live their lives and cope with the tasks of being suddenly single.

column1: 2555-Major tasks to be dealt with and worked through include:  Managing life style and practical affairs  Re-defining relationships  Reconstructing personal values and beliefs  Concluding legal procedures    Stage 4:  "Life Re-formation" represents the final steps as readers pass through to the "other" side of their divorce.
2556-During this stage people deal with the emotional issues and life choices involved as they move on with their lives.
2557-Constructing relationships  New interests  Personal responsibility  Accepting your new life    Summary and Conclusion  The first stage of the divorce typically passes the most quickly.
2558-It's the quick hit
column3: as people realize their marriage is over.

column1: 2559-The second and third stages are the most active and represent the bulk of active divorce work
column3: practical
column4: and emotional changes in life after divorce.

column1: 2560-The final stage represents that time in life during which divorcees are moving far away from their divorce
2561-This stage really has no formal "end
column2:
and is marked by the full acceptance of the divorce and a resolution of most of the practical issues and many of the emotional.
2562-Of course, the reality is that many of the various tasks of each stage overlap.
2563-And things aren't as clean and neat as checking off one task and then moving on to the next.
2564-But helping divorcees recognize these stages and tasks can be an enormously useful way to help them see and understand the path that lies ahead for them.
2565-References:  Burns B.,  Whiteman, T.
2566-(1992.)
2567-The Fresh Start Divorce Recovery Workbook."

urlLink   Question: You've discussed briefly some of the physiological and emotional differences between the sexes.
2602-Could you list other physical characteristics unique to males and females?
2603-Dr. Dobson Responds:  Men and women differ in countless ways
column2: many of which they aren't even conscious of.

column1: 2604-Here are just a few of those differences:   1.
2605-A woman has greater constitutional vitality
column2: perhaps because of her unique chromosomal pattern.

column1: 2606-Normally
column2: she outlives a man by three or four years in the U.S.

column1: 2607-Females simply have a stronger hold on life than males
2608-More than 140 male babies are conceived for every 100 females; by the time birth occurs
column3: with the rest of the males dying in spontaneous abortions.159   2.

column1: 2609-Men have a higher incidence of death from almost every disease except three: benign tumors
column3: and breast cancer.160   3.

column1: 2610-Men have a higher rate of basal metabolism than women.161   4.
2611-The sexes differ in skeletal structure
column3: broader face

column1: 2612-The first finger of a woman's hand is usually longer than the third; with men the reverse is true.
2613-Boys' teeth last longer than do those of girls.162   5.
2614-Women have a larger stomach
column3: liver

column1: 2615-Women have three very important physiological functions totally absent in men--menstruation
column3: and lactation.

column1: 2616-Each of these mechanisms influences behavior and feelings significantly.
2617-Female hormonal patterns are more complex and varied.
2618-The glands work differently in the two sexes.
2619-For example
column2: a woman's thyroid is larger and more active; it enlarges during menstruation and pregnancy
column3: which makes her more prone to goiter
column5: and is associated with the smooth skin
column7: and the thin layer of subcutaneous fat that are important elements in the concept of personal beauty.

column1: 2620-Women are also more responsive emotionally
2621-Women's blood contains more water (20 percent fewer red cells).
2622-Since red cells supply oxygen to the body
column2: she tires more easily and is more prone to faint.

column1: 2623-Her constitutional viability is therefore strictly a long-range matter.
2624-When the working day in British factories
column3: was increased from ten to twelve hours
column4: accidents among women increased 150 percent; the rate of accidents among men did not increase significantly.165   8.

column1: 2625-Men are 50 percent stronger than women in brute strength.166   9.
2626-Women's hearts beat more rapidly than those of men (80 versus 72 beats per minute).
2627-Their blood pressure (ten points lower than men) varies more from minute to minute
column2: but they have much less tendency to high blood pressure--at least until after menopause.167   10.

column1: 2628-Female lung capacity is about 30 percent less than in males.168   11.
2629-Women can withstand high temperatures better than men because their metabolism slows down less.169   12.
2630-Men and women differ in every cell of their bodies because they carry a differing chromosomal pattern.
2631-The implications of those genetic components range from obvious to extremely subtle.
2632-For example
column2: when researchers visited high school and college campuses to study behavior of the sexes
column3: they observed that males and females even transported their books in different ways.

column1: 2633-The young men tended to carry them at their sides with their arms looped over the top.
2634-Women and girls
column3: usually cradled their books at their breasts
column4: in much the same way they would a baby.170   Who can estimate how many other sex-related influences lie below the level of consciousness?

2745-urlLink Haiku For Beginners    I guess the first thing you noticed is that they're short - two or three lines only.
2746-There are not many words in those lines either.
2747-And you didn't hear rhymes
2748-Beyond their physical form
column2: these poems obviously have something else in common.

column1: 2749-It is something to do with the subject matter and the direct method of presentation.
2750-If we had time to discuss it we could refine that thought until we had something like this.

2751-The poems speak  - about experience from the senses  - directly and with intensity  - about observation of nature   They seek to construct a clear and significant image in our minds or perhaps to juxtapose or contrast two such images.
2752-Usually it is an image from nature or from daily life.
2753-Perhaps though
column2: to say that the poem 'constructs' the image in our mind is a bad way of saying it.

column1: 2754-Really the poem is reminding us of something we've already seen
2755-That's how they manage to conjure up so complex an image with so few words.
2756-One possibility is to go with what you know now.
2757-Let me first remind you of the rules I've already given you.
2758-The poem should be start with an image or a pair if them.
2759-It should be direct from sense experience
column3: simile or rhyme.

column1: 2760-Haiku is of course a traditional Japanese form with further strict rules of construction.
2761-Not all are honoured outside Japan and even there some are defiantly broken.
2762-To what I've already stated let me add three more stipulations.
2763-three lines with 5 syllables
column3: then 5  one kigo or season word  one kireji or cutting word   The first rule is the most well known and it is the one most mentioned by writers on the subject of haiku.

column1: 2764-The idea is simple.
2765-Write a line of five syllables
column2: follow it with a seven-syllable line and then use five syllables to make the final line.

column1: 2766-This gives you two short lines divided by a longer one.
2767-It goes a long way to guiding the method of expression in the poem.
2768-There is a good deal of controversy about this rule; but let's skip that for the moment and talk about the third.
2769-The kireji or cutting word is used to divide the haiku into two parts.
2770-Obviously this should be used to enhance the juxtaposition of images we discussed earlier.
2771-In English the tendency is to use punctuation
column2: such as "-" or ":" to perform this function.

column1: 2772-The second rule that requires the use of a kigo or season word helps establish the season or time of year that the poem describes.
2773-For English-language haiku this rule is taken to remind the writer that the poem should be grounded in nature.
2774-But most important is that the form isn't the goal here.
2775-It's to write a good poem.
2776-So the exercise of writing haiku oneself is very important.
2777-Occasional reading and discussion on the form
column2: tradition and history of haiku and reading others' haiku all help to feed the writing with new ideas and approaches.

2870-urlLink Robert E. Wilkinson 's The Quantum Brahman   In their search to explain the mechanics of creation
column2: the world's leading theoretical physicists have determined that there are four fields of force in the universe.

column1: 2871-Scientists have been able to reduce and classify these fields in categories according to the strength of the force that they carry
column2: and the particles with which they interact.

column1: 2872-The first of these categories is the Gravitational Force.
2873-It is the weakest of the four forces and has two special properties; it is able to act over large distances and is always an attractive force.
2874-The gravitational force is present in large bodies such as the Sun
2875-The second category is the Electromagnetic Force which operates over short distances and interacts with electrically charged particles.
2876-While it is much stronger than the gravitational force
column2: this force operates on the very small scale of atoms and molecules which possess two kinds of electrical charges
column3: positive and negative
column4: that tend to attract or repel one another.

column1: 2877-The third category called the Weak Nuclear Force
column2: is responsible for radioactivity and is found in many nuclear decay processes that involve neutrinos.

scientists were able to develop a theory which successfully unified the weak nuclear force with the electromagnetic force as they had earlier been able to unify the forces of electricity and magnetism.

column1: 2879-It is now called the Electro-weak force.
2880-The fourth category
column3: binds particles together into combinations.

column1: 2881-Matter is mostly made up of protons and neutrons which in turn are made up of quarks.
2882-The strong nuclear force holds the quarks together in the proton and neutron and hold protons and neutrons together in the nucleus of an atom.

2883-While these four forces account for the theoretical dynamics of matter they do not appear to interact with each other in a manner sufficient to suggest a single unified field theory which could explain the natural ordering of the universe.
2884-This problem has forced scientists to continue their search for an as yet unidentified 5th field in nature which they hope will provide the basis for this long sought unification.
2885-Their search for this mysterious 5th field has led them to speculate about a sub-quantum reality described by the ancient sages as the Luminiferous Ether.
2886-It was believed to be an invisible medium that would fill all space and convey extremely subtle effects over large distances.
2887-To the world of science
column2: this metaphysical possibility was not considered viable because physicists were not convinced that etheric forces played any significant role in physical interactions.

column3: they have come to believe that the Etheric may hold the key to the elusive 5th field.

column1: 2889-Leading theoreticians now conclude that this invisible sub-quantum field
column2: capable of being the ground state of the universe
column3: would be free of matter as well as the effects of gravitation.

column1: 2890-Since it resembles empty space
column2: they appropriately named it the Quantum Vacuum.

column1: 2891-However
column3: they were forced to revise their notion of an etheric void in favor of new theories which suggest that the Quantum Vacuum is a highly charged cosmic medium; an energy-filled plenum whose subtle order measurably influences the space-time motion of the material universe.

column1: 2892-Scientists now agree that it was the Quantum Vacuum which gave birth to the observable universe.
2893-And they also believe that the 5th field which they are seeking is the interactive face of that plenum.
2894-A number of physicists now suspect that the dynamics of that interactive face hold the key to joining the fields of gravitation
column3: and the strong and weak nuclear forces in a Grand Unified Field Formula.

column1: 2895-The discovery of the Quantum Vacuum appears to represent a major paradigm shift for modern science but

column1: 3238-Intellectual curiosity gives them a penchant for gathering information that can develop into serious research endeavors
column2: or turn out to be just a fondness for gossip.

column1: 3239-At times they can be overly fastidious
column2: usually with regard to eating habits.

column1: 3240-Concern with health makes many of them outstanding health care professionals.
3241-Their own preoccupation with health can become exaggerated to the point of hypochondria
column2: or they can be guilty of using maladies to attract sympathy.

column1: 3242-They are mentally and emotionally stimulated by travel
column3: and information.

column1: 3243-Subject: Remembering Martin Luther King
3244-Date:  Fri
column2: 17 Jan 2003 13:58:56 -0800    From: "FAIR"        To:  "FAIR-L"                                     FAIR-L                     Fairness  Accuracy In Reporting                Media analysis
column3: critiques and activism   Remembering Martin Luther King

column1: 3245-This year
column2: Martin Luther King Jr. Day comes as the U.S. is moving toward war in Iraq.

column1: 3246-As media prepare to air retrospectives on King
column2: we thought it would be a good time to circulate this 1995 column by FAIR founder Jeff Cohen and FAIR associate Norman Solomon.

column3: 1995 The Martin Luther King You Don't See on TV By Jeff Cohen and Norman Solomon  It's become a TV ritual: Every year in mid-January
column4: around the time of Martin Luther King's birthday
column5: we get perfunctory network news reports about "the slain civil rights leader."

column1: 3248-The remarkable thing about this annual review of King's life is that several years-- his last years-- are totally missing
column2: as if flushed down a memory hole.

column1: 3249-What TV viewers see is a closed loop of familiar file footage: King battling desegregation in Birmingham (1963); reciting his dream of racial harmony at the rally in Washington (1963); marching for voting rights in Selma
column3: lying dead on the motel balcony in Memphis (1968).

column1: 3250-An alert viewer might notice that the chronology jumps from 1965 to 1968.
3251-Yet King didn't take a sabbatical near the end of his life.
3252-In fact
column2: he was speaking and organizing as diligently as ever.

column1: 3253-Almost all of those speeches were filmed or taped.
3254-But they're not shown today on TV.
3256-It's because national news media have never come to terms with what Martin Luther King Jr. stood for during his final years.
3257-In the early 1960s
column2: when King focused his challenge on legalized racial discrimination in the South
column3: most major media were his allies.

column1: 3258-Network TV and national publications graphically showed the police dogs and bullwhips and cattle prods used against Southern blacks who sought the right to vote or to eat at a public lunch counter.
3259-But after passage of civil rights acts in 1964 and 1965
column2: King began challenging the nation's fundamental priorities.

column1: 3260-He maintained that civil rights laws were empty without "human rights"-- including economic rights.
3261-For people too poor to eat at a restaurant or afford a decent home
column3: anti-discrimination laws were hollow.

column1: 3262-Noting that a majority of Americans below the poverty line were white
3263-He decried the huge income gaps between rich and poor
column2: and called for "radical changes in the structure of our society" to redistribute wealth and power.

column1: 3264-"True compassion
column2: King declared, is more than flinging a coin to a beggar; it comes to see that an edifice which produces beggars needs restructuring."
King had also become the country's most prominent opponent of the Vietnam War
column3: and a staunch critic of overall U.S. foreign policy

column1: 3266-In his "Beyond Vietnam" speech delivered at New York's Riverside Church on April 4
column2: 1967-- a year to the day before he was murdered-- King called the United States "the greatest purveyor of violence in the world today."

column1: 3267->From Vietnam to South Africa to Latin America
column3: the U.S. was "on the wrong side of a world revolution."

column1: 3268-King questioned "our alliance with the landed gentry of Latin America
column2: and asked why the U.S. was suppressing revolutions of the shirtless and barefoot people" in the Third World
column3: instead of supporting them.

column1: 3269-In foreign policy
column2: King also offered an economic critique
column3: complaining about "capitalists of the West investing huge sums of money in Asia
column5: only to take the profits out with no concern for the social betterment of the countries."

column1: 3270-You haven't heard the "Beyond Vietnam" speech on network news retrospectives
column2: but national media heard it loud and clear back in 1967-- and loudly denounced it.

column1: 3271-Time magazine called it "demagogic slander that sounded like a script for Radio Hanoi."
3272-The Washington Post patronized that "King has diminished his usefulness to his cause
column3: his people."

column1: 3273-In his last months
column2: King was organizing the most militant project of his life: the Poor People's Campaign.

column1: 3274-He crisscrossed the country to assemble "a multiracial army of the poor" that would descend on Washington-- engaging in nonviolent civil disobedience at the Capitol
column2: if need be-- until Congress enacted a poor people's bill of rights.

column1: 3275-Reader's Digest warned of an "insurrection."
3276-King's economic bill of rights called for massive government jobs programs to rebuild America's cities.
3277-He saw a crying need to confront a Congress that had demonstrated its "hostility to the poor"-- appropriating "military funds with alacrity and generosity
column2: but providing poverty funds with miserliness."

column1: 3278-How familiar that sounds today
column2: more than a quarter-century after King's efforts on behalf of the poor people's mobilization were cut short by an assassin's bullet.

column1: 3279-As 1995 gets underway
column2: in this nation of immense wealth
column3: the White House and Congress continue to accept the perpetuation of poverty.

column1: 3280-And so do most mass media.
3281-Perhaps it's no surprise that they tell us little about the last years of Martin Luther King's life.
3282------------------- Media Beat is Norman Solomon's weekly syndicated column on media and politics.

column2: the column was co-written by FAIR's founder
column3: Jeff Cohen (Cohen no longer works at FAIR).
