column1: urlLink Gather the Women  Beginning the week of March 3-8
column3: linked globally by our interactive website
column4: we are inviting women to demonstrate  their courage to risk leaving old conformities  by joining with millions of others throughout the world  in thousands of unique events celebrating woman's true worth
column5: expressing shared concern for our human family
column6: and creating and supporting actions  that will enable humanity to live together  in a world based on life-affirming values.

column1: 3371-Gather the Women is evoking at a profound level  an experience of our own woman's worth to the world.
3372-As women we bring life forward.
3373-We are in touch with the cycles of life and we function in a context that is deeply relational.
3374-This realization is allowing women to risk leaving  the safety of our comfortable conformities.
3375-We have the capacity to generate  creative solutions that benefit  all life on the planet.
3376-Gather the Women is creating  a rich exchange of cultural values  to dissolve the ties that bind us to the illusion  that one segment of our human family can win  while another loses.
3377-Together we women are contributing  to a new collective wisdom  and we are lending our strength  to that which we wish to embrace.
3378-From this emerging balance is being born  a new dimension of our humanity.
3379-Nicotine is the addicting chemical in all forms of tobacco.
3380-It is a very powerful and dangerous drug - a small child can die from eating just two cigarettes.
3381-Nicotine causes the release of brain chemicals
column2: which can give a "high" similar to other addicting drugs.

column1: 3382-It may be as addicting as heroin.
3383-The body goes through a physical "withdrawal" when the nicotine level drops - causing the "nicotine fit."
3384-Nicotine withdrawal can be very unpleasant - many smokers find it difficult to quit due to nicotine addiction.
3385-Withdrawal symptoms can include anxiety
column3: poor concentration

column1: 3386-These symptoms must be addressed for most smokers to successfully become non-smokers.
3387-urlLink TNT - The Power Within You  From Raphaela on 2/7/2003 11:41:34 AM   Stop bemoaning your fate and get wise to yourself.
3388-You have only two choices.
3389-You can either go higher or lower.
3390-You may take to drink or help yourself to a first-class nervous breakdown or wander around through the rest of your life
column2: moaning about "what might have been" if you had only lived your life differently - but telling yourself "it's too late now".

column1: 3391-But if you belong to that smaller percentage of men and women who have "gotten wise to themselves"
column2: you discover that it is never too late to get on the right track.

column1: 3392-You discover that you have been passing up the most wonderful force in your life
column3: which has been ready and willing

column1: 3393-A deep feeling of humility steals over you
column2: and you lose your falsely assumed attitudes of egoism and self-importance forever.

column1: 3394-Once you are down to bedrock
column2: you find that you have a foundation on which to build
column3: that you can pick up your life again and make something of it
column5: perhaps not so flashy or so gaudy

column3: you can decide what is best for you
column4: without worrying about what the other fellow is going to do to you unless
column6: you do it to him first.

column1: 3396-There has come to you the inner assurance that whatever you need can and will be supplied to you by your creative power
column2: if you keep in attunement with it
column3: and direct it by right mental picturing.

column1: 3397-Not only this but you realize that you have been missing out on many things in life of far greater value than many of the things you thought you had to have a short time ago.....There is no way out
column3: there is no other way but through.......Claude M. Bristol and Harold Sherman

        urlLink PERSONAL MINISTRY: Advancing God's Kingdom  TOOLS OF THE TRADE Message # 4: (Selected Scriptures) Taught by Dr. Larry Osborne North Coast Church January 30  31, 1999  As in all families, joining God's family brings with it certain responsibilities.
3434-And one of our most important responsibilities is to help advance God's Kingdom.
3435-But how can we determine the specific assignment and role God has for us?
3436-That's what we'll discover today as we explore the importance of a personal ministry and the special tools called spiritual gifts that make it possible to carry out that ministry.
3437---------------------------------------------------------------------------------  FAMILY CHORES    We all have a unique set of God given gifts, skills and resources.
3438-I Corinthians 12:1  7/ I Corinthians 4:7/ James 1:17  We are responsible to use them to advance God's Kingdom.
3439-I Peter 4:10-12/ Matthew 25:14-30  Luke 19:11-27  If we don't use them, we lose them.
3440-Advancing God's Kingdom is NOT optional.
3441-The goal is to match what we do best with where we're needed most.
3442-WHAT DO I DO BEST?
3443-Discovering Our Spiritual Gift Mix   1) Our spiritual gifts may or may not match our passions and desires.
3444-Exodus 3:1-4:18/ I Chronicles 26:16-20  You can miss out on what God has for you by pursuing your desires.
3445-2) Giftedness is based upon God's sovereignty not our spirituality.
3446-Romans 12:6  I Corinthians 12:4-6/ I Timothy 1:12-16  3) The greater the glory, the less important the gift.
3447-I Corinthians 12:21-26    4) The best way to discover our spiritual gifts is to do something and then check the result.
3448-Matthew 25:14-30, Luke 19:11-27   WHERE AM I NEEDED MOST?
3449-Discovering Our God Given Assignment   THREE TOUGH QUESTIONS:  1) Do I have the right paradigm?
3450-(viewpoint) Am I looking at this properly?
3451-Am I out to win the war or am I being self-indulgent?
3452-2) Do I have the right goal?
3453-Is my goal to serve the Lord or is it self fulfillment?
3454-Was your service hard or did it just make you feel good?
3455-3) Am I making a real impact?
3456-Matthew 26:36-45  When?
3457-Where?
3458-How?
3459-Voyeurism   urlLink War in the digital age: Did you see that?
3460-by Francis Till   Digital technology is bringing the war to the world in new, sometimes astonishingly immediate ways -- and the development is not always welcome.
3461-Anyone caught without a television, for example, can watch a free, live webcast of downtown Bagdhad on a computer screen, 24/7, courtesy BBC News.
3462-That link works on internet-capable PDAs, by the way, which can hook up to wireless nets and provide broadband streams to anyone in an 802.11x cloud, even over coffee in a Starbucks anywhere.
3463-Very early monday morning, that camera was trained on a bank of the Tigris river as Iraqi soldiers and police combed the reeds on the shore in search of what was later reported to be two downed American pilots.
3464-The soldiers fired their automatic weapons into the river, violating whatever passes these days for the rules of handling capture, small boats flitted about in the water, angry crowds gathered on the bridge and along the river road.
3465-The audio feed from the camera, which is adequate for loud sounds like traffic and bombs, caught the excited voices of the crowd and even some of the gunfire.
3466-Al Jazeera cameramen were with the soldiers and moments after the webstream fed the images into computers all over the world, very similar pictures began to bloom on television as the Qatar-based station put its images up to satellites.
3467-On BBC webstream 4, the talking heads in the newsroom were taking in the story and beginning to put it out to their global audience.
3468-BBC's webstream 4 is a duplicate feed of the news channel's broadcast, with slight variations: at times, it shows presenters during broadcast breaks, for example.
3469-According to the presenters, RAF sources said they could account for all their flights and none were missing.
3470-Within 10 minutes, they had quotes from senior officials at the Pentagon making similar statements about American aircraft.
3471-Yet, clearly, something was taking place on the banks of the Tigris, where some of the gathered crowd had begun tossing torches into the reeds, hoping to burn the hiding airmen out.
3472-Al Jazeera reported on television at that point that one American pilot had been captured and the crowd was searching for a second airman.
3473-According to Al Jazeera, both airmen had been seen parachuting into the river after their airplane had been shot down.
3474-Al Jazeera did not use modifiers.
3475-Sky news, at that point, began inserting tag frames onto a picture of the search that quoted US Central Command saying that no coalition planes had been shot down.
3476-On the webstream feed, the sky over Bagdhad began to show as a kind of eerie charcoal grey due to the plumes from burning oil pits, lit earlier in the day in a futile attempt to mask targets from the war planes and missiles.
3477-Meanwhile, the webcam broadcast the sounds of an incoming air attack.
3478-Hours before, webcams and television cameras had streamed out images of long range bombers leaving remote bases.
3479-Now, they were quite possibly arriving over their target.
3480-A target full of civilians, exposed and too far away from shelters to reach what passes for safety in Bagdhad today.
3481-As the crowd began to break up, heading for cover, word came over Sky News from American Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld that, indeed, a UK warplane, with two pilots, was missing.
3482-Not the Tornado shot down earlier by an American Patriot missile, but another.
3483-But then, it was revealed, he was speaking in only general terms, without specific knowlege.
3484-And finally, an astute BBC reporter pointed out that many things -- bombs, equipment -- came down from airplanes in parachutes.

Why are Women Leaving Corporate America and Where are They Going?
3780-by Denise Grer   urlLink http://www.cobolreport.com/columnists/denise/07292002.asp   In todays fast paced world
column2: people are expected to change jobs many times and even change careers several times in their lifetime.

column1: 3781-Even so
column2: women are leaving corporate America at twice the rate of men.

column1: 3782-Why are they leaving and where are they going?
3783-Many are leaving because they are fed up with the obstacles thrown in their path solely due to their gender.
3784-Many have seen their careers make slower progress than their male colleagues
column2: not due to their competence but due to what has been coined as the glass ceiling.

column1: 3785-Many need and want more autonomy and flexibility that corporate America is not willing to give.
3786-Many simply want to be their own boss and do for themselves what they have been doing for their employers.
3787-For all these reasons and more
column2: large numbers of women are leaving high paying and challenging jobs to start their own businesses.

column1: 3788-A majority of these organizations are wildly successful.
3789-Women-owned businesses are growing more rapidly than the overall economy and becoming major contributors to the U.S. overall economic health and competitiveness.
3790-Why Are Women Leaving?
3791-Even though women are making inroads into the executive suites of corporations
column2: they are moving at a snails pace.

column1: 3792-The glass ceiling is still firmly in existence and holding many women back.
3793-Thus
column2: the first logical hypothesis would be that women are leaving to start their own companies because they have run into too many roadblocks at their current institutions.

column1: 3794-In fact
column2: the glass ceiling was the highest ranked reason given by a survey of women entrepreneurs (23% of respondents) (Moore and Buttner 1997).

column1: 3795-In addition
column2: an almost equal number of women (21%) stated that creating a work environment more consistent with their values was the main reason they started their own company.

column1: 3796-In a different study by Catalyst
column2: the highest ranked reasons women gave for leaving a company were lack of flexibility (51%)
column3: the glass ceiling (29%)
column5: and feeling unchallenged in their job (22%) (Catalyst 1998).

column1: 3797-This suggests that women are being driven from traditional corporations due to blockades to career advancement and poor work environments.

3798-This further suggests that these entrepreneurs are not only driven by a desire to create a viable business but to be able to make a difference in their companys direction and to integrate their work into their lifestyle
column3: job autonomy

column1: 3799-In many cases
column2: women feel they need meaningful work in order to have a fulfilling and meaningful life.

column1: 3800-This cannot be accomplished if they are expected to fit into a niche and morph themselves into a corporate identity.
3801-Another factor is many women feel they are undervalued.
3802-In fact
column2: pay equity is still a problem.

column1: 3803-In the year 2000
column2: women made 87 cents to every dollar a man made (Chao 2001).

column1: 3804-More specifically
column2: in the year 2000 women technicians earn 81.2%
column3: computer programmers 89.6%
column6: and natural scientists 72.1% of what their male counterparts earn (USDoL 2001).

column1: 3805-Another interesting statistic is married women with children (less than 18 years old) make 96.2% of their female counterparts who do not have children.
3806-However there is virtually no difference in pay (99.3%) between married men with children and married men with no children.
3807-This discrepancy could be attributed to the fact that mothers still take on a larger burden of care for their children than the fathers and this affects their careers.
3808-To counteract this problem
column2: women need support and flexibility for balancing work and family so they can be 100% productive in both.

column1: 3809-Many view this support as something the company should provide.
3810-When the company does not come through
column2: women perceive this as a key contributor to a poor working environment and opt to start their own business where they have more control over such factors.

column1: 3811-How Can Corporations Reverse This Trend?
3812-In todays knowledge based economy the loss of high-level women in corporations is a loss in intellectual capital
column3: and connections.

column1: 3813-The loss of good people also precipitates low morale and uncertainty among the staff and incurs the cost of recruiting
column3: and training replacements.

column1: 3814-All of this can be avoided in many cases through low cost and innovative programs and changes to the work culture and environment (Donahue 1998).
3815-A corporations first step is to determine why women are leaving their company in particular.
3816-This could involve obtaining feedback from the employees through interviews or surveys (with a guarantee of confidentiality) and directed questions in exit interviews.
3817-Statistics must be gathered to understand the extent of the problem.
3818-These could include the numbers of women and men entering and leaving the company at different levels
column2: the promotion rate for women and men
column3: the percentage of women in higher management position and where those positions are located (e.g.
column5: and relative salaries grouped by experience

column1: 3819-Gender inequity issues should be openly discussed without fear of repercussion.
3820-In particular
column2: discussions could center around whether the performance standards are objective and appropriate
column3: whether women are visible enough (or at all) in highly respected positions
column4: the identification of male only traditions
column5: and how mentoring is and should be conducted within the company.

column1: 3821-It is only when the key problem areas are identified that initial steps can be taken to correct them.
3822-Based on this research
column2: goals and solutions to these problems must be formulated and mapped out and then finally implemented.

column1: 3823-It is crucial that the company
column2: all the way up to the executive office
column3: is fully supportive of this effort.

column1: 3824-Managers must be held responsible for implementing the procedures and meeting the defined goals for gender equity.

3825-Some example activities are: being proactive in identifying high potential women and providing mentoring and support for their upward career movement; making the higher ranking women more visible to the rest of the company; ensuring job searches include qualified women candidates; and providing flexibility in the workplace through flextime
column3: and telecommuting.

column1: 3826-Women tend to learn more from other people in the company than their male counterparts (Van Velsor and Hughes 1990).
3827-Thus
column2: mentoring and executive development are crucial for the upward movement and retention of women in the organization.

column1: 3828-Another key factor that professional women state over and over again for leaving a company is they felt underutilized and undervalued.
3829-This is in large part due to the necessity of constantly proving their competence because they are different from the one good model (i.e.
3830-Other models that fit women management styles should be accepted and encouraged throughout the corporation.
3831-Essentially the bottom line is: why should women devote all their efforts to fit into an unfriendly culture when they can leave and start their own business?
3832-If business organizations are genuinely concerned about this loss of talent
column2: they must immediately start making changes to their culture and be proactive about the recruitment and retention of women.

column1: 3833-Given the move towards a global economy and need for more diversity
column2: corporations cannot afford to ignore the large pool of talented professional women.

column1: 3834-Characteristics and Culture of Women Owned Businesses Starting a company is a difficult road
column3: setbacks

column1: 3835-However
column2: the professional women who are starting their own businesses are finding that they enjoy the empowerment
column3: excitement

column1: 3836-They are doing things their way
column2: implementing their ideas and management styles.

column1: 3837-For high tech businesses
column2: the majority of women-owned firms are in the biotechnology industry (46%) with 29% in information technology.

column1: 3838-Just the opposite is true for men with 47% in information technology and 33% in biotechnology (NFWBO 2001b).
3839-This follows current trends in bachelor degree awards in the U.S.
3840-The most recent statistics from the Department of Education show women graduates at 58.3% of B.S.
3841-graduates in biological and life sciences and only 28.1% in computer and information science (NCES 2001).
3842-No matter what the business area is
column2: women bring a different management style and culture to the table.

column1: 3843-NFWBO found that 53% of women business owners emphasize right-brain thinking (creativity and values-based decision making)
column2: while the majority of male business owners (71%) stress left-brain thinking such as methodological and procedural analysis (NFWBO 1994).

column1: 3844-The same study found that two-thirds of women business owners tended to weigh options and reflect internally before decision making more so than their male counterparts (66% vs. 56%)
column2: who tended to emphasize action and give more attention to external events.

column1: 3845-The attributes of a companys leadership have a strong effect on the culture of the workplace.
3846-Women entrepreneurs are more likely to describe their workplace in family terms and work within a network of business relationships.
3847-Men entrepreneurs
column3: tend to think more in hierarchical terms and focus on establishing clear rules and procedures (NFWBO 1994; Grer 2001).

column1: 3848-The NFWBO study also found that in addition to monetary gain
column2: women tend to derive success from building relationships with customers and employees and having control over their own destiny.

column1: 3849-Men on the other hand
column2: derive success from the satisfaction of a job well done and achieving desired goals.

column1: 3850-Thus
column2: womens leadership approaches are more likely to bring about an environment that is a web of inclusion (see Grer 2001; Helgesen 1995)
column3: while mens leadership is more likely to encourage hierarchical organizations with a top down approach.

column1: 3851-Another characteristic of women owned businesses is that they are more likely to offer environments that help provide balance in their employees lives through programs such as flextime
column3: and job sharing.

column1: 3852-Only 30% of small businesses (less than 25 employees) offer flextime
column2: while 40% of women owned small businesses do.

column1: 3853-For large businesses (greater than 25 employees)
column2: 40% of women-owned firms provide flextime as compared to only 19% of all large firms (NFWBO 1994).

column1: 3854-In addition
column2: 21% of women-owned small businesses offer tuition reimbursement programs
column3: as compared to only 8% of all small businesses.

column1: 3855-Diversity is another factor that can be affected by company leadership.
3856-Not surprisingly
column2: women-owned firms tend to employ a more gender-balanced workforce.

column1: 3857-Women-owned businesses employ half women and half men (52% women and 48% men).
3858-Men-owned firms
column3: employ only 38% women and 62% men (NFWBO 2000a).

column1: 3859-The Success of Women-Owned Businesses From an economic viewpoint
column2: women owned businesses are quite successful.

column3: employed over 27.5 million people
column4: and generated over $3.6 trillion in sales (NFWBO 1999).

column1: 3861-Of these businesses established in the last decade
column3: 000 or more in revenue.

column1: 3862-These businesses are also financially stable.
3863-Women owned firms are as likely to pay bills on time and are as financially sound as all U.S. firms (CWBR 1995).
3864-Businesses owned by women are the most rapidly expanding sector of the economy.
3865-The growth in the number of women-owned firms
column3: and revenue exceeded the rate of growth of all businesses in 1997 (USCB 1997).

column2: the number of women-owned firms increased by 103%
column3: employment grew by 320%

column1: 3867-With respect to high tech firms
column2: a higher percentage of women-owned high tech firms are fast growing than men-owned firms
column4: although women-owned firms are in the minority in the high tech sector.

column1: 3868-Still Some Difficulties Even though women-owned firms on average are very successful
column2: there are still obstacles faced due to gender.

column1: 3869-One key difficulty is most women owners of fast-growth firms are less likely to have entrepreneurial mentors or role models
column2: past experience in owning a business
column3: or an executive professional background.

column1: 3870-These are all crucial in assisting the entrepreneur along the path of success.
3871-Women entrepreneurs of fast growth firms have to depend more on personal debt and business earnings for financing than their male colleagues.
3872-Only 39% of women-owned firms have a commercial bank loan vs. 52% of men-owned firms.
3873-In addition
column2: equity capital for women-owned businesses typically comes from informal investors such as family members and individual angel investors (73%) with only 15% from venture capital firms (NFWBO 2000b).

column1: 3874-Women owners of fast-growth firms are also less likely to share ownership of their firms with outside investors (28% for women vs. 49% for men) (NFWBO 2001b).
3875-This reliance on personal and informal debt is holding women-owned firms back since high growth depends in large part to being able to leverage debt and equity.
3876-Given these factors
column2: it is crucial that women are given access to entrepreneurship information and mentoring in order to succeed.

column1: 3877-There are currently programs that strive towards these goals  many of which can be linked to via the Center for Women's Business Researchs website at http://www.nfwbo.org  Catalyst for Change?
3878-The management style
column3: and employee benefits offered by women-owned companies not only provide for powerful economic forces
column4: but are influential social forces as well.

column1: 3879-Interestingly
column2: the concerns of women in the workplace are also starting to apply to men as well.

column1: 3880-A recent survey of technology professionals by Webgrrls
column3: found that both men and women were experiencing an imbalance between their work and home life (38% of respondents) (Drury 2001).

column1: 3881-Men are now beginning to demand more of a balance between their personal and work life.
3882-In addition
column2: men are taking more of a role in raising their children and other nontraditional male at-home responsibilities.

column1: 3883-It is now possible to find stay-at-home dads where the mom is the sole source of income for the family.
3884-However
column2: it is still the majority of women who are concerned with work/life balance and quality of work environments.

column1: 3885-The Webgrrls survey found 76% of women feel their work environment is very important versus 51% of men.
3886-Even so
column2: there is a substantial number of men who are starting to realize they want to spend more time outside of work and that a pleasant productive work environment is important.

column1: 3887-As the workforce and business leadership become more diverse and markets become more global
column2: the workplace culture is slowly evolving.

column1: 3888-The tides of change are coming for more flexible and family or people-friendly workplaces.
3889-Regardless of the effect on workplace environments
column2: it is clear that more and more businesses are being created and run by women.

column1: 3890-These businesses are largely successful and it is not too wild of a speculation to state that the women-owned businesses of today will become the Fortune 500 companies of the future.

column6: North Carolina   About The Author   Dr. Denise W. Gurer is a computer scientist with a long standing interest in issues of concern to women in technology.

3910-Alert: Total Lunar Eclipse Set Thursday  AP to My Yahoo!
3911-LOS ANGELES - If the weather cooperates
column2: a total lunar eclipse will be seen across North America late Thursday  the first visible in the United States in three years  and just before dawn Friday in western Europe and western and southern Africa.

column1: 3912-A lunar eclipse occurs when the Earth casts its shadow on the full moon
column2: blocking the sunlight that otherwise reflects off the moon's surface.

column1: 3913-Unlike solar eclipses
column2: lunar eclipses are safe to view with the naked eye.

column1: 3914-In North America
column2: the moon will remain totally eclipsed for 53 minutes
column3: and should turn substantially darker and reddish in color.

column1: 3915-The total eclipse will start at 8:13 PDT in Los Angeles
3916-A second lunar eclipse
column3: will be visible from North and South America.

column1: 3917-Eclipses once helped prove the Earth is round
column2: because its shadow on the moon is curved.

Shining true being: Meditation for the Dying  Imagine that your body no longer has the strength
column3: to maintain its connection with the life-force
column4: with the body of awareness within.

column1: 3919-And imagine now that you are beginning to experience the process of dissolving out of that body.
3920-Sensations from the body no longer so distinct
column3: leaving just a spaciousness.

column1: 3921-Dissolving out of the body.
3922-Leaving that heavier form behind.
3923-Dissolving into consciousness itself.
3924-My friend
column3: for that which is called death has arrived.

column1: 3925-So let go gently
column3: of all that holds you back.

column1: 3926-Of all that pulls you away from this most precious moment.
3927-Know that now you have arrived at the transition called death.
3928-Open to it.
3929-Let go into it.
3930-Recognise the changing experience of the mind as it separates from the body
3931-Dissolving now into the realms of pure light.
3932-Your true nature shining everywhere before you.
3933-My friend
column3: a spaciousness of being that does not grasp.

column1: 3934-Let things be as they are without the least attempt to interfere.
3935-Grasping at nothing.
3936-Enter the essential nature of your own being shining there before you
3937-Rest in being.
3938-Knowing it for what it is.
3939-This light shining
3940-Your true self.
3941-Let go
column3: gently

column1: 3942-Before you shines your true being.
3943-It is without birth
3944-Let go of all which distracts or confuses the mind
column2: all that created density in life.

column1: 3945-Go gently into it.
3946-Do not be frightened or bewildered.
3947-Do not pull back in fear from the immensity of your true being.
3948-Now is a moment for liberation.
3949-Know that you are well guided by your compassion and love.
3950-You are the essence of all things.
3951-You are the light.
3952-From 'Who Dies?'
3953-by Stephen Levine.

3954-For Each of You  Be who you are and will be learn to cherish that boistrous Black Angel that drives you up one day and down another protecting the place where your power rises running like hot blood from the same source as your pain.
3955-When you are hungry learn to eat whatever sustains you until morning but do not be misled by details simply because you live them.

3956-Do not let your head deny your hands any memory of what passes through them nor your eyes nor your heart everything can be useful except what is wasteful (you will need  to remember this when you are accused of destruction.)
3957-Even when they are dangerous examine the heart of those machines you hate before you discard them and never mourn the lack of their power lest you be condemned to relive them.

3958-If you do not learn to hate you will never be lonely  enough to love easily nor will you always be brave although it does not grow any easier  Do not pretend to convenient beliefs even when they are righteous you will never be able to defend your city while shouting.
3959-Remember our sun is not the most noteworthy star only the nearest.

3960-Respect whatever pain you bring back from your dreaming but do not look for new gods in the sea nor in any part of a rainbow Each time you love love as deeply as if it were  forever only nothing is  eternal.
3961-Speak proudly to your children where ever you may find them tell them you are the offspring of slaves and your mother was a princess in darkness.

3967-urlLink Researchers create flexible
column2: paper-thin electronic screen  Associated Press  In a step toward electronic newspapers and wearable computer screens
column3: scientists have created an ultra-thin screen that can be bent
column4: twisted and even rolled up and still display crisp text.

column1: 3968-The material
column2: only as thick as three human hairs
column3: displays black text on a whitish-gray background with a resolution similar to that of a typical laptop computer screen.

column1: 3969-The screen is so flexible it can be rolled into a cylinder about a half-inch wide without losing its image quality.
3970-Although it's not quite the dream of single-sheet
column2: electronic newspapers or books that can display hundreds of pages of text
column3: its creators said it's the first flexible computer screen of its kind.

column1: 3971-``I think it's a major step forward.
3972-We have cleared a big obstacle in electronic paper development
column3: a research scientist with E Ink Corp. of Cambridge

column1: 3973-E Ink is one of several companies working to develop electronic ``paper'' for e-newspapers and e-books
column2: and other possible applications -- even clothing with computer screens sewn into it.

column1: 3974-The new screen is described in Thursday's issue of the journal Nature.
3975-Aris Silzars
column2: the past president of the San Jose
column3: Calif.-based Society for Information Display
column4: said one of the technology's first applications could be something like an electronic tablet lawyers could use in place of bulky laptops.

column1: 3976-But Silzars said the best uses of the new screen
column2: which E Ink is still developing
column3: may not be evident.

column1: 3977-``It's very hard to predict where this thing may go
3978-Chen and his co-workers made the 3-inch wide display screen flexible by developing a stainless steel foil topped with a thin layer of circuits that control an overlying film of electronic ink.
3979-That ``ink
column2: '' developed in 1997 by a Massachusetts Institute of Technology scientist
column3: contains tiny capsules with black and white particles with opposing electrical charges floating in a clear fluid.

column1: 3980-When a negative voltage is run through circuits behind these capsules
column2: the positive white particles move to the capsule's top.

column1: 3981-A positive current does the same to the negative black particles.
3982-The human eye blends these resulting patterns of black- or white-topped capsules into text displayed in a traditional column.
3983-Currently
column2: information and power is fed to the screen through a wired hookup.

column1: 3984-But Chen's team is working on a self-contained system that could receive data through a wireless connection.
3985-They also hope to boost the speed at which the screen switches to a new ``page'' of text
column2: from the current quarter of a second to at least 10 times as fast
column3: so it can display video.

column1: 3986-Another goal is making the screen display a full range of colors.
3987-Robert Wisnieff
column2: senior manager of IBM Corp.'s Advanced Display Technology Laboratory in Yorktown Heights
column3: N.Y.
column4: said E Ink's flexible screen is something many futurists believe is crucial to making electronic screens part of every day life.

column1: 3988-He envisions such lightweight
column2: thin screens being used for a credit card that could display the available balance or recent purchases.

column1: 3989-Another possible use is a jacket with a screen sewn into its sleeve to allow its wearer to read e-mail while on the run

column1: 4422-urlLink NASA researcher
column2: Rick Briggs has written:   "In ancient India the intention to discover truth was so consuming
column3: that in the process
column4: they discovered perhaps the most perfect tool for fulfilling such a search that the world has ever known -- the Sanskrit language.

column1: 4423-There is at least one language
column3: which for the duration of almost 1000 years was a living spoken language with a considerable literature of its own.

column1: 4424-Besides works of literary value
column2: there was a long philosophical and grammatical tradition that has continued to exist with undiminished vigor until the present century.

column1: 4425-Among the accomplishments of the grammarians can be reckoned a method for paraphrasing Sanskrit in a manner that is identical not only in essence but in form with current work in Artificial Intelligence.
4426-This article demonstrates that a natural language can serve as an artificial language also
column2: and that much work in AI has been reinventing a wheel millennia old.

column1: 4427-The discovery is of monumental significance.

4428-It is mind-boggling to consider that we have available to us a language which has been spoken for 4-7000 years that appears to be in every respect a perfect language designed for enlightened communication.
4429-But the most stunning aspect of the discovery is this: NASA the most advanced research center in the world for cutting edge technology has discovered that Sanskrit
column2: the world's oldest spiritual language is the only unambiguous spoken language on the planet.

column1: 4430-Considering Sanskrit's status as a spiritual language
column2: a further implication of this discovery is that the age old dichotomy between religion and science is an entirely unjustified one.

column1: 4431-It is also relevant to note that in the last decade physicists have begun to comment on the striking similarities between their own discoveries and the discoveries made thousands of years ago in India which went on to form the basis of most Eastern religions.
4432-Why has Sanskrit endured?
4433-Fundamentally it generates clarity and inspiration.
4434-And that clarity and inspiration is directly responsible for a brilliance of creative expression such as the world has rarely seen.
4435-Another hope for the return of Sanskrit lies in computers.
4436-Sanskrit and computers are a perfect fit.

4437-The precision play of Sanskrit with computer tools will awaken the capacity in human beings to utilize their innate higher mental faculty with a momentum that would inevitably transform the world.
4438-In fact the mere learning of Sanskrit by large numbers of people in itself represents a quantum leap in consciousness
column2: not to mention the rich endowment it will provide in the arena of future communication."

column1: 4439-(source: Knowledge Representation in Sanskrit and Artificial Intelligence - By Rick Briggs Artificial Intelligence Magazine 6(1) 32-39 1985).

column1: urlLink A glimpse into the heart of a dying star - Behind the scenes at a stellar chemical factory :  An image taken with the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope shows one of the most unusually long planetary nebulae found so far.
4498-Scientists think planetary nebulae hold the key to understanding how the Universe became enriched with heavier elements so they study them intensively.
4499-It is not well-understood how a perfectly round star can turn into such an unusual-looking nebula.
4500-{Apply this concept to people.}
4501-Planetary nebulae occur in a huge variety of shapes and sizes.
4502-They are the final stage of a star's life before it ends its days as a burnt-out white dwarf.
4503-When it dies
column2: a star rapidly sheds the outer parts of its atmosphere
column3: creating a planetary nebula that exists only as long as the star has fuel to burn.

column1: 4500-{Apply this concept to people.}
4505-Stars are large recycling factories.
4506-Over their lifetimes of millions of years they process huge amounts of the lighter elements (mostly hydrogen and helium)  {apply this concept to people}  into heavier ones (such as carbon
column2: nitrogen and oxygen)  {apply this concept to people} .

column1: 4507-These heavier elements are then dispersed into the surrounding space when the stars peel off their atmospheres to form planetary nebulae.
4508-In turn
column2: the heavier elements may become part of other stars or end up in planetary systems like our own Solar System.

column1: 4509-This dispersion process is therefore one of the most important in the Universe and can tell us something about our own origins.
4500-{Apply this concept to people.}

4706-urlLink Alexandria, Egypt  The second largest city and the main port of  Egypt , Alexandria was built by the  Greek  architect Dinocrates (332-331 BC) on the site of an old village, Rhakotis, at the orders of  Alexander the Great .
4707-The city, immortalizing Alexander's name, quickly flourished into a prominent cutural,  intellectual , political, and economic metropolis, the remains of which are still evident to this day.
4708-It was the renowned capital of the  Ptolemies , with numerous monuments.
4709-It was the site of the  Lighthouse , one of the  Seven Wonders of the Ancient World , as well as the  Great Library .
4710-It was along these shores that history took a tragic turn at the time of  Cleopatra ,  Julius Caesar ,  Mark Antony , and Octavian.
4711-Alexandria lies  north-west of the Nile delta  and stretches along a narrow land strip between the Mediterranean Sea and  Lake Mariut  (Mareotis).
4712-It is linked to  Cairo  by two major highways and a railroad line.
4713-It is one of the most notable summer resorts in the  Middle East , for, in addition to its temperate winters, its beaches, with white sands and magnificent scenery, stretch for 140 km along the  Mediterranean Sea , from  Abu Qir , in the east to  Al-Alamein  and Sidi Abdul Rahman, in the west.

4798-Realization: The Poori Effect: How We Sometimes Fool Ourselves  Just seated in an Indian vegetarian buffet restaurant with a friend
column3: "Poori or nan (traditional flour-based foods)?"

column1: 4799-I replied "Two nans please."
4800-She remarked enthusiastically
column3: would you like to try the poori?"

column1: 4802-She smiled on
4803-Have you tried them before?
4804-You should try!"
4805-I smiled weakly
4806-I tried poori before
4807-But she was so unknowingly pushy that I patronised her.
4808-She walked by later
column3: and asked

column1: 4809-My friend smiled sheepishly and gave a weak nod.
4810-She too prefers nan.
4811-The waitress smiles back
column2: moving off to serve another "happy" customer.

column1: 4812-I call this "The Poori Effect."
4813-It is the unmindful shaping of the world according to one's perceptions.
4814-The waitress already made up her mind as to what we should try before asking- her favourite.
4815-Due to the way she carried herself
4816-We were later "obliged" to give her a positive response- out of "courtesy".
4817-The result was a totally deluded idea of our opinion of poori.
4818-We might have made her day in the worldly sense
column2: but at the expense of reinforcing her delusion.

column1: 4819-We sometimes "unwittingly" mirror the world - the world smiles and we smile back.
4820-But is your smile true?
4821-On the other hand
column2: is your smiling "forcing" the world to smile back reluctantly or genuinely?

column1: 4822-We see what we want to see.
4823-I know friends who seemingly get along well with others
column2: who ironically talk behind their backs.

column1: 4824-The Poori Effect is a case of two-way hypocrisy- bad faith.
4825-We are at times not mindfully sincere enough to discover how the world truly feels about us and present ourselves in a way that will not receive negative feedback.
4826-This is hypocrisy to oneself and others
column2: even though there might be some genuine goodwill within.

column1: 4827-When we patronise in return
column2: giving positive feedback which is ungenuine
column3: it is hypocrisy too.

column1: 4828-Either way
column2: anyone being hypocritical is being untrue.

column1: 4829-Can we learn to speak true and wise words
column3: in a kind way?

column1: 4830-Even if the truth bites a little
4831-Since it is "sugar-coated" with kindness
column2: the truth should be more digestible
column3: right?

urlLink Grof Transpersonal Training - What is holotropic breathwork?
4891-:  "Holotropic Breathwork is a powerful approach to self-exploration and healing that integrates insights from modern consciousness research
column3: various depth psychologies
column6: and mystical traditions of the world.

column1: 4892-The name Holotropic means literally 'moving toward wholeness' (from the Greek 'holos'=whole and 'trepein'=moving in the direction of something).
4893-The process itself uses very simple means: it combines accelerated breathing with evocative music in a special set and setting.
4894-With the eyes closed and lying on a mat
column2: each person uses their own breath and the music in the room to enter a non-ordinary state of consciousness.

column1: 4895-This state activates the natural inner healing process of the individual's psyche
column2: bringing him or her a particular set of internal experiences.

column1: 4896-With the inner healing intelligence guiding the process
column2: the quality and content brought forth is unique to each person and for that particular time and place.

column1: 4897-While recurring themes are common
column2: no two sessions are ever alike.

column1: 4898-Additional elements of the process include focused energy release work and mandala drawing.
4899-Holotropic Breathwork is usually done in groups
column2: although individual sessions are also possible.

column1: 4900-Within the groups
column2: people work in pairs and alternate in the roles of experiencer and 'sitter'.

column1: 4901-The sitter's role is simply to be available to assist the breather
column2: not to interfere or interrupt the process.

column1: 4902-The same is true for trained facilitators
column2: who are available as helpers if necessary."

column3: and armpits

column3: reduce giggles

column1: 5959-Tickling satisfies our human need to touch.

6290-urlLink Painting Over Plastic Laminate :  "Is there any way to paint over dark-brown plastic-laminate kitchen cabinets?
6291-I can't replace or reface them right now
column2: and they're just too dark for the room.

column1: 6292-I'd appreciate any tips."
6293-- Lyndee
column2: via e-mail  John says: If you're looking at ugly laminate
column3: refacing it with not-so-ugly laminate is the best course of action
column4: from the standpoint of durability and ease of care.

column1: 6294-But if it's paint you want
column2: the answer to your question is yes
column3: as long as the laminate is well-adhered and in good condition.

column1: 6295-First
column2: I'd wipe down all the surfaces with a solvent such as xylol to get rid of dirt and grease.

column1: 6296-Be sure to don chemical-resistant gloves
column3: shut off any pilot lights
column4: and kick out the dog - this is powerful stuff.

column1: 6297-Then scuff up all the surfaces with 150-grit sandpaper and wipe them down again with xylol.
6298-Next
column2: you want a primer that will adhere tenaciously and serve as a good base for paint.

column1: 6299-The one I use comes from X-I-M
column2: a company that manufactures bonding primers; they have several solvent-based products suitable for your application.

column1: 6300-I find that the spray-applied primer actually holds better than the brush-on version.
6301-Allow two or three days for the primer to cure before sanding it lightly with 220-grit paper.
6302-Then you can apply either a latex or oil-based paint; I prefer oil in kitchens because it gives a smoother finish and is easier to clean.
6303-(John Dee
column2: a painting and decorating contractor based in Concord
column3: Mass.
column4: has restored finishes on five This Old House projects.)

column1: 6308-Rush for surnames produces 500 Genghis Khans  By Oliver August  MONGOLIANS have been ordered to invent their own surnames
column2: after generations of living with just one name on the orders of their former Soviet masters.

column1: 6309-Hundreds
column3: daily besiege a small office in the centre of their capital where identity documents are issued.

column1: 6310-Held back by armed guards outside
column2: some opt for surnames like Seven Drunk Men that hint at Mongolia's national pastime.

column1: 6311-Others prefer to adopt the name of Genghis Khan
column3: who now has 500 namesakes in Ulan Bator.

column1: 6312-When communism crumbled in 1990 the ban on family names was lifted but many nomadic herders who roam between Siberia and the Gobi desert continue to refer to each other only by single names.

column2: to fight incest and make official records more intelligible
column3: the Government has set a deadline of June 27 for all 2.5 million Mongolians to choose a family name on pain of a fine equivalent to several months' salary.

urlLink A GLASS OF MILK :  One day
column2: a poor boy who was selling goods from door to door to pay his way through school
column3: found he had only one thin dime left

column1: 6361-He decided he would ask for a meal at the next house.
6362-However
column2: he lost his nerve when a lovely young woman opened the door.

column1: 6363-Instead of a meal he asked for a drink of water.
6364-She thought he looked hungry so brought him a large glass of milk.
6365-He drank it slowly
column3: "How much do I owe  you?"

column1: 6366-"You don't owe me anything
column2:
she replied.
6367-Mother has taught us never to accept pay for a kindness."

column1: 6368-He said..... "Then I thank you from my heart."
6369-As Howard Kelly left that house
column2: he not only felt stronger physically
column3: but his faith in God and man was strong also.

column1: 6370-He had been ready to give up and quit.
6371-Many years later that same young woman became critically ill.
6372-The local doctors were baffled.
6373-They finally sent her to the big city
column2: where they called in specialists to study her rare disease.

column1: 6374-Dr. Howard Kelly was called in for the consultation.
6375-When he heard the name of the town she came from
column2: a strange light filled his eyes.

column1: 6376-Immediately he rose and went down the hall of the hospital to her room.
6377-Dressed in his doctor's gown he went in to see her.
6378-He recognized her at once.
6379-He went back to the consultation room determined to do his  best to save her life.
6380-From that day he gave special attention to her case.
6381-After a long struggle
6382-Dr. Kelly requested the business office to pass the final bill to him for approval.
6383-He looked at it
column2: then wrote something on the edge and the bill was sent to her room.

column1: 6384-She feared  to open it
column2: for she was sure it would take the rest of her life to pay for  it all.

column1: 6385-Finally she looked
column2: and something caught her attention on the side  of the bill.

column1: 6386-She read these words....."Paid in full with one glass of milk"  (Signed) Dr. Howard Kelly Tears of joy flooded her eyes as her happy heart prayed: "Thank You
column3: that Your love has spread abroad through human hearts and hands."

6405-urlLink Warning: nicotine seriously improves health  Robin McKie
column3: 2004 The Observer   Nicotine could soon be rehabilitated as a treatment for schizophrenia

column1: 6406-Research shows that the chemical that has addicted millions to smoking has a powerful impact on brain activity in patients who suffer from psychiatric and degenerative disorders.
6407-Some experiments have shown that nicotine can slow down the onset of Parkinson's symptoms; others have had revealed its power in curtailing the hallucinations of schizophrenics.
6408-'A whole range of psychiatric conditions seem to be helped by nicotine
column3: a neurobiologist at the University of Chicago.

column1: 6409-'However
column2: such benefits do not justify smoking.

column1: 6410-The lethal effects of cigarettes far outweigh any help they provide.
6411-On the other hand
column2: our research does suggest that derivatives of nicotine
column3: administered medically
column4: could help to alleviate a range of psychiatric problems.'

column1: 6412-Nicotine is known to switch on receptors on the surface of cells in certain parts of the brain
column2: causing these neurones to release the neuro-transmitter dopamine
column3: a chemical that is associated with feelings of pleasure.

column1: 6413-This effect leads to a person's addiction.
6414-More than 50 per cent of people suffering from clinical depression smoke
column2: while the figure rises to 95 per cent for schizophrenics.

column1: 6415-But smoking among the general public has dropped to about 25 per cent.
6416-'The assumption is that people with psychiatric conditions are self-medicating
6417-'They are smoking because the nicotine in particularly helpful in alleviating their condition.'
6418-This point is backed by Dr Tony George
6419-'Smoking is a marker for psychopathology
column2: ' he states in the current issue of the journal Nature Medicine.

column1: 6420-Similarly
column2: it has been found that nicotine can sometimes slow the debilitating symptoms of Parkinson's
column3: a disease caused by the slow destruction of certain types of brain cells.

column1: 6421-'Either nicotine stimulates other types of brain cells to compensate for the loss of the cells involved in Parkinson's
column2: or it is somehow providing protection to remaining healthy Parkinson's cells
column3: ' said McGehee.

column1: 6422-'Either way

column1: urlLink Affordances and Design ( jnd.org ) : "The word 'affordance' was originally invented by the perceptual psychologist J. J. Gibson (1977
column2: 1979) to refer to the actionable properties between the world and an actor (a person or animal).

column1: 28-To Gibson
29-They are a part of nature: they do not have to be visible
column3: or desirable.

column1: 30-Some affordances are yet to be discovered.
31-Some are dangerous.
32-I suspect that none of us know all the affordances of even everyday objects."
33-Nearly 80 percent of UK central government Web sites need to be redesigned before they can be fully accessible to users with disabilities
34-Did you know you can get the e-Government Digest sent direct to your inbox every week?
35-Just email us to get your free copy.

36-A UK publication called eGov Monitor Weekly has reported that around 800 public sector Web sites may need rebuilding to comply with accessibility laws requiring government services to cater for people with disabilities.
37-The claim is based on details leaked from an internal report carried out by the Office of the e-Envoy (OeE)
column2: the cabinet office unit responsible among other things for improving the accessibility and usability of UK government Web sites.

column1: 38-The OeE report draws upon the findings by the National Audit Office investigation
column2: which examined the accessibility of 65 central government Web sites and concluded that nearly all were potentially excluding users.

column1: 39-EGov Monitor estimates that to fix the problems
column2: government departments may need to spend at least 10 percent to 15 percent of their total annual budget for Web sites.

column1: 40-Editor Ian Cuddy told ElectricNews.Net that it was difficult to put a precise figure on the total cost of the redesigns required because the OeE has refused to release further details of the audit
column2: but it is expected to run into millions.

column1: 41-The OeE has now warned the Web design industry that future government contracts will demand that companies deliver Web sites that conform to international Web accessibility standards.
42-Current responsibility for adopting these standards rests with individual government webmasters
column3: and compliance is not centrally monitored.

140-urlLink BBC article:    Opening hours row at cottage: The cottage was opened as a museum in 1924.
141-A heritage group in Stafford say they are angry at plans to cut the opening hours of one of the town's most historic landmarks despite their offers of help.
142-The borough council says Izaak Walton's Cottage
column3: is proving expensive to run.

column1: 143-The former home of Izaak Walton
column2: the author of 1653 fishing book The Complete Angler
column3: houses a collection dedicated to his life and angling.

column1: 144-A report to councillors says that limiting access to the museum to weekends from May to August would save 17
145-Currently the attraction is open on weekday afternoons from April to October.
146-'Few opportunities' But the Izaak Walton Cottage Chapter
column2: who have set up a charitable trust to fund the running of the cottage
column3: said they were upset the council had not met them before making the decision.

column1: 147-Tony Bridgett
column3: said: "The council threatened to close the cottage 18 months ago and there was a campaign run by the people of Stafford and ourselves to keep it open.

column1: 148-"So in some respects we are delighted that it is staying open.
149-"But it is only going to open from May to the end of August
column2: and only on Saturdays and Sundays and not bank holidays so members of the public are going to get very few opportunities to visit.

column1: 150-"We have some money available and the council say they haven't got any but they haven't got round to meeting us so we are able to mutually work together."
151-Members of the council's leisure scrutiny committee will debate the plans next week.
152-A spokeswoman for the council said the hours had been revised to take into account when visitors most used the cottage.
153-She said a range of events will continue to be held at the cottage and coach trips
column3: would still be able to visit during the week.

column2: Yahoo face off in suit   Google is the darling of the Internet and seemingly at the top of its game as it charges toward a public stock offering sometime this summer.

column1: 169-But the Mountain View company could be paying hundreds of millions of dollars to its Sunnyvale archrival
column3: if it loses a little-noticed patent lawsuit unfolding in a San Jose courtroom.

column1: 170-The case pits Google against Overture Services
column2: an Internet advertising company bought by Yahoo last year.

column1: 171-Overture claims it patented an online bidding system for ads seven months before Google introduced a similar system.
172-Patent attorneys who have reviewed the suit said Overture's patent claims can't be easily dismissed.
173-``I think there is merit based on the breadth of the claims
column3: a patent attorney with the IP Strategy Group in Cupertino.

column1: 174-``I took a look at it and said
column3: Google does that.

column1: 175-Yep
176-''  A key ruling in the 2-year-old case -- which could determine whether the two sides settle or forge ahead to a jury trial -- is expected at any time
column2: say patent attorneys who have reviewed the suit.

column1: 177-Advertising made up about 95 percent of Google's $1 billion in revenue last year.
178-If the company loses the patent suit
column2: it would probably have to pay damages
column3: license technology from Yahoo or alter how it manages its ad system.

column1: 179-Overture
column3: filed its patent in May 1999 for a ``system and method for influencing a position on a search result list.''

column1: 180-The 43-page patent application details a system in which advertisers would be able to bid for better placement of ads in search-engine results and manage their accounts through a Web browser.
181-The U.S. Patent Office awarded the patent July 31
182-In February 2002
column2: Google introduced its AdWords program -- a system that would eventually help reshape Internet advertising and legitimize search engines as a viable business.

column1: 183-With AdWords
column2: advertisers bid for the right to certain keywords.

column1: 184-When a Google user types in that keyword as part of a search
column2: the advertiser's pitch shows up near the results.

column1: 185-A tour operator in Hawaii
column3: might buy the terms ``Hawaii
column6: '' and its ads will appear next to Google search results for those terms.

column1: 186-Advertisers bid against one another for keywords
column2: with higher bidders getting better ad placement.

column1: 187-In its suit
column3: Overture says Google is ``willfully'' and ``directly infringing'' on its patent.

column1: 188-The company is seeking triple damages.
189-Google
column2: which is in a mandated ``quiet period'' leading up to its IPO
column3: declined to comment on the suit
column4: as did attorneys representing both companies.

column1: 190-But in court documents
191-Among other things
column2: Google is claiming that Overture was using its advertising system for more than a year before it filed for its patent.

column1: 192-Patent law gives people a year to file patents after inventing something; a late filing automatically invalidates the patent.
193-Patent attorneys who have reviewed court documents have mixed views on Overture's chances of prevailing.
194-Mitchell Rosenfeld
column2: a patent attorney with Capstone Law Group in San Mateo
column3: said Google has submitted substantial evidence to show that Overture missed the one-year deadline.

column1: 195-Rosenfeld said a key issue in the case could end up being whether Overture was testing its technology or using a finished product.
196-On the other hand
column2: Overture needs only to prove that Google infringed on one of the 67 claims in its patent.

column1: 197-Also
column2: Overture's patent application appears to have been well-researched by both the company and the patent office
column3: said Bruce Sunstein of Bromberg  Sunstein in Boston.

column1: 198-``This is going to be a patent that is relatively difficult to knock out
199-Since late March
column3: a former patent attorney
column4: has been analyzing the scope and meaning of Overture's patent
column5: poring over each word and studying terminology such as ``database'' and ``search result list.''

column1: 200-It's a crucial step before a jury can be asked to decide whether a company has infringed on a patent.
201-A ruling could come any day.
202-Known as ``Markman'' rulings
column2: these decisions are often tipping points in patent cases
column3: said patent attorney John Ferrell
column4: co-founder of Carr  Ferrell in Palo Alto.

column1: 203-If the judge does not agree with one side's interpretation of the patent language
column2: it will often push to settle the suit
column3: he said.

column1: 204-The case is especially intriguing now that Internet search engines have become big business.
205-When the suit was filed two years ago
column2: Overture was suing an up-and-coming search engine with an unproven business model.

column1: 206-Today
column2: Google is considered the king of Internet search.

column1: 207-And Overture's stature increased when Yahoo acquired the company for $1.83 billion in stock and cash
column2: incorporating its advertising technology and patents into its services.

column1: 208-``It's one of those things that two or three years ago wouldn't have been an issue
column3: vice president of search marketing for WebSourced.

column1: 209-``But it just goes to show you how big search is.''
210-About half of all patent verdicts are overturned on appeal.
211-And the stakes are high.
212-Ultimately
column2: the two sides will have to weigh the costs of a prolonged legal fight -- attorney bills in a case like this could reach $1 million a year -- against the possibility of losing.

column1: 213-``My observation is that there is this big lawsuit between two enormous players
column3: ``and no one is paying attention to it.''

column2: I decided to start this site after some bad customer support experiences with  urlLink http://www.atkins.com  in their "My Atkins" area.

column1: 1-Their site is so slow and it's been impossible for me to upload my "before" photo to help me see my progress visually.
2-I figure it's probably better to have my own weight loss journal so that I can get exactly what I want out of it.
3-So
4-I'm 25 years old
column2: and I've been trying to lose weight since May 2003.

column1: 5-My highest weight ever was 400 pounds.
6-I've lost 57 pounds so far and it's been quite a journey.
7-I've had all sorts of eating habits.. for several months I was vegetarian because I got sick from fatty foods after having gallbladder surgery.
8-My gallbladder was taken out in July 2003 after I'd lost about 30 pounds rather quickly from low calorie dieting.

9-My doctor who did that surgery said that the pain might return because after physically looking at the stuff he took out of me he just didn't think that the stones were causing the kind of pain that I felt.
10-I don't really regret having the surgery since those stones had to pass at some point.
11-My dad had a stone pass once and it got stuck in a duct and he had to be hospitalized for a while
column2: it was a really traumatic experience.

column1: 12-I'm glad I'm not going to have to go through that.
13-On July 12 2004 I started the Atkins Nutritional Approach because of course that pain returned along with a lot of bowel symptoms.
14-I had read somewhere that eating low-carbohydrates can help ease the pain with some people who have Irritable Bowel Syndrome.
15-Boy were they right.
16-Every time I thought back to all the times I got sick while eating
column2: it was always after eating a bowl of mashed potatoes or a bunch of bread.

column1: 17-I talked this over with a gastroenterologist and he gave me the information that I needed to make a life-change to my eating habits that will make me not feel so sick anymore.
18-He agrees that I most likely have Irritable Bowel Syndrome from discussing my history
column2: dating all the way back to my childhood.

column1: 19-During the last month I've already had just about every other medical condition ruled out.
20-IBS can not be tested for.. it is a "functional" syndrome
column2: meaning that there's no disease present
column3: my body just works differently in a way that can be painful if I am not careful with the way that I eat.

column1: 21-So
column2: I've been doing a sort of modified Atkins plan for one week
column3: and I already feel 95% better.

column1: 22-I've lost 2 inches off my measurements already (wow!)
23-although the scale is playing games with my head.
24-That's probably due to all the water and that will come down with time as well.
25-I feel a little bit better every day.
26-Two weeks ago
column2: I didn't want to get out of bed because of the excruciating abdominal pain.

column1: 27-Now I am able to live my life again.
28-Right now I'm doinga modified Atkins induction.
29-Thismeans less than net 20 carbs a day
column2: except I'm eating extra fiber foods thaninduction allows
column3: such as spinach and broccoli
column4: and I'm takingmetamucil up to the recommended 25-30 grams of fiber a day.

column1: 30-First thing in the morning I have 36 ounces of water
column3: 2 doses of 17g Miralax (polyethylene glycol..

column1: 31-ewww!

column2: and the third 12 oz glass of water is my first metamucil of the day.

column1: 33-This morning routine is part of my bowel program given to me by my doctor last week.
34-If I dont follow the program the way that I do
column3: really sick just like I was before.

column1: 35-Besides
column2: the vitamins from my fiber veggies are really good for me.

column1: 36-Speaking of vitamins
column2: I take a One a Day Carb Smart in the afternoon right before lunch time.

column1: 37-The motivation not to eat some french fries or a piece of bread
column2: is the constant knowledge that eliminating them from my diet is the only reason that I am not in pain anymore.

column1: 38-I track all of my food/exercise using Fitday PC which I bought at  urlLink http://www.fitday.com  .
39-They have a free version that you can track your stuff through their website
column2: but I like the PC version better because it has a lot more flexibility and options.

column1: 40-Here are some links for articles about Atkins and IBS
column2: explaining why I am feeling a lot better:    urlLink http://atkins.com/Archive/2002/1/11-771731.html      urlLink http://atkins.com/Archive/2002/2/12-234348.html0-17

column1: 0-           "Being Twenty-Something"  They call it the "Quarter-life Crisis."
1-It is when you stop going along with the crowd and start realizing that there are many things about yourself that you didn't know and may not like.
2-You start feeling insecure and wonder where you will be in a year or two
column2: but then get scared because you barely know where you are now.

column1: 3-You start realizing that people are selfish and that
column3: those friends that you thought you were so close to aren't exactly the greatest people you have ever met
column4: and the people you have lost touch with are some of the most important ones.

column1: 4-What you don't recognize is that they are realizing that too
column3: catty
column5: but that they are as confused as you.

column1: 5-You look at your job... and it is not even close to what you thought you would be doing
column2: or maybe you are looking for a job and realizing that you are going to have to start at the bottom and that scares you.

column1: 6-Your opinions have gotten stronger.

7-You see what others are doing and find yourself judging more than usual because suddenly you realize that you have certain boundaries in your life and are constantly adding things to your list of what is acceptable and what isn't.
8-One minute
column2: you are insecure and then the next
column3: secure.

column1: 9-You laugh and cry with the greatest force of your life.
10-You feel alone and scared and confused.
11-Suddenly
column2: change is the enemy and you try and cling on to the past with dear life
column3: but soon realize that the past is drifting further and further away
column4: and there is nothing to do but stay where you are or move forward.

column1: 12-You get your heart broken and wonder how someone you loved could do such damage to you.
13-Or you lie in bed and wonder why you can't meet anyone decent enough that you want to get to know better.
14-Or maybe you love someone but love someone else too and cannot figure out why you are doing this because you know that you aren't a bad person.
15-One night stands and random hook ups start to look cheap.
16-Getting wasted and acting like an idiot starts to look pathetic.
17-You go through the same emotions and questions over and over
column2: and talk with your friends about the same topics because you cannot seem to make a decision.

column1: 18-You worry about loans
column3: the future and making a life for yourself... and while winning the race would be great
column4: right now you'd just like to be a contender!

column1: 19-What you may not realize is that everyone reading this relates to it.
20-We are in our best of times and our worst of times
column2: trying as hard as we can to figure this whole thing out.

column1: 21-Send this to your twenty something friends.... maybe it will help someone feel like they aren't alone in their state of confusion.....    GOOD LUCK TO ALL OF US!!
22-I can't help but think about the past.
23-The past I truely want to forget.
24-I just had my birthday a few days ago
column2: and as I was talking to my friend about life in general
column3: I realized that I am missing a major thing in my life.

column1: 25-A man.
26-What I mean is
column3: a boyfriend and or a close friend who is a guy.

column1: 27-I used to.
28-But my father passed away a few years ago
column2: I broke up with my boyfriend of three years and me  my best guy friend  aren't as close as we used to be.

column1: 29-Is there something wrong with that?
30-I need to get away.
31-I don't know what it is
32-I'm gone.
33-I not might sure what's going on right now in my life.
34-But what I'm sure about is that life is getting even more crazy as the day goes by.
35-For example
column3: Jason's uncle called me.

column1: 36-I bet your asking yourself
column2: why is his uncle calling me right?

column1: 37-Well
column2: he called to tell me that he likes me!

column1: 38-I know it sounds really strange but I thought he was joking or something but he wasn't.
39-He also told me something that I would never get over.
40-Jason has a two year old son and his married.
41-The worst part is
column2: Jason was married the past few years!

column1: 42-I can't believe he would do that.
43-I must be blind not to have noticed anything....
44-So much for my happy ending  Let's talk this over It's not like we're dead Was it something I did?
45-Was it something You said?
46-Don't leave me hanging In a city so dead Held up so high  On such a breakable thread  You were all the things I thought I knew And I thought we could be  You were everything
column2: everything that I wanted We were meant to be
column3: supposed to be
column4: but we lost it And all of the memories
column6: just fade away All this time you were pretending So much for my happy ending  You've got your dumb friends I know what they say They tell you I'm difficult But so are they But they don't know me Do they even know you?

column1: 47-All the things you hide from me All the shit that you do  You were all the things I thought I knew And I thought we could be  It's nice to know you were there Thanks for acting like you cared And making me feel like I was the only one It's nice to know we had it all Thanks for watching as I fall And letting me know we were done  So much for my happy ending0-28

52-The following concerns a question in a physics degree exam at the University of Copenhagen:"Describe how to determine the height of a skyscraper with a barometer.
53-"One student replied:"You tie a long piece of string to the neck of the barometer
column2: then lower the barometer from the roof of the skyscraper to the ground.

column1: 54-The length of the string plus the length of the barometer will equal the height of the building.
55-"This highly original answer so incensed the examiner that the student was failed immediately.
56-The student appealed on the grounds that his answer was indisputably correct
column2: and the university appointed an independent arbiter to decide the case.The arbiter judged that the answer was indeed correct
column3: but did not display any noticeable knowledge of physics.

column1: 57-To resolve the problem it was decided to call the student in and allow him six minutes in which to provide a verbal answer which showed at least a minimal familiarity with the basic principles of physics.For five minutes the student sat in silence
58-The arbiter reminded him that time was running out
column2: to which the student replied that he had several extremely relevant answers
column3: but couldn't make up his mind which to use.

column1: 59-On being advised to hurry up the student replied as follows:"Firstly
column2: you could take the barometer up to the roof of the skyscraper
column3: drop it over the edge
column4: and measure the time it takes to reach the ground.

column1: 60-The height of the building can then be worked out from the formula H = 0.5g x t squared.
61-But bad luck on the barometer.
62-""Or if the sun is shining you could measure the height of the barometer
column2: then set it on end and measure the length of its shadow.

column1: 63-Then you measure the length of the skyscraper's shadow
column2: and thereafter it is a simple matter of proportional arithmetic to work out the height of the skyscraper.

column1: 64-""But if you wanted to be highly scientific about it
column2: you could tie a short piece of string to the barometer and swing it like a pendulum
column3: first at ground level and then on the roof of the skyscraper.

column1: 65-The height is worked out by the difference in the gravitational restoring force T = 2 pi sqrroot (l / g).
66-""Or if the skyscraper has an outside emergency staircase
column2: it would be easier to walk up it and mark off the height of the skyscraper in barometer lengths
column3: then add them up.

column1: 67-""If you merely wanted to be boring and orthodox about it
column3: you could use the barometer to measure the air pressure on the roof of the skyscraper and on the ground
column4: and convert the difference in millibars into feet to give the height of the building.

column1: 68-""But since we are constantly being exhorted to exercise independence of mind and apply scientific methods
column2: undoubtedly the best way would be to knock on the janitor's door and say to him 'If you would like a nice new barometer
column3: I will give you this one if you tell me the height of this skyscraper'.

column1: 69-"The student was Niels Bohr
column2: the only Dane to win the Nobel prize for Physics.

column1: 388-In  urlLink Ann Arbor
column2: most of the client machines could not connect to anything but the file server.

column1: 389-Knowing that the file server uses Appletalk as the protocol and TCP/IP is used for everything else
column2: we narrowed down the list of possible problems.

column1: 390-Checking out the error logs on our servers showed stuff like this over and over and over: Aug 16 18:54:45 beer.pub.umich.edu dhcpd: DHCPDISCOVER from 00:50:e4:30:6f:24 via eth1 Aug 16 18:54:45 beer.pub.umich.edu dhcpd: DHCPOFFER on 141.211.148.76 to 00:50:e4:30:6f:24 via eth1 Aug 16 18:54:45 beer.pub.umich.edu dhcpd: DHCPREQUEST for 10.0.1.5 from 00:50:e4:30:6f:24 via eth1 Aug 16 18:54:45 beer.pub.umich.edu dhcpd: DHCPNAK on 10.0.1.5 to 00:50:e4:30:6f:24 via eth1 In basic terms
column2: this is what was happening:  a system comes online and tries to DISCOVER the DHCP server
column3: the server OFFERs a good IP from it's pool
column4: the client REQUESTed a bad IP
column5: and the server does Not AcKnowledge that request.

column1: 391-Then the cycle repeats.
392-This made no sense to all three of us working on the problem.
393-We tried restarting our DHCP server
column2: we tried using a different server
column3: etc etc.

column1: 395-Searching the  urlLink Apple Tech Info Library

column1: 396-It was accepting all of the requests
