column1: 1060-she's hot
column3: and she's wearing a tri-delt sweatshirt.

column1: 1061-after i was done thinking about how hot she was
column2: i realize that she's an idiot because i'm wearing my winter fucking coat and am still cold and she's standing outside waiting for a bus in nothing more than a sweatshirt.

column1: 1062-well
column2: i've probably never been more right about anything in my life.so right when the bus is coming up she sees one of her friends - had to be in a sorority if not tridelt due to the black fuck me pants
column3: black down north face jacket
column4: black wool hat and black framed glasses.

column1: 1063-she also had black sandals on - yes
column2: it was still cold outside.as i get on the bus
column3: they sit down in front of me

column1: 1064-i'm not really paying attention to anything in particular
column2: mostly because i'm contemplating how much it sucks that i'm going to north campus to sit in a class that i don't really need to be going to anyway
column3: and so it catches me off guard a bit when i realize what the two girls in front of me are talking about.

column1: 1065-hard boiled eggs.
1066-it was just weird
column3: i'm listening to the girl in black bitch about how her roommate will hard boil all of the eggs in the fridge to use on salads at once
column4: and then keep them in the egg carton so that when she wants to use an egg (god only know for what purpose - it certainly wasn't to eat
column5: unless she was planning on inducing vomiting afterwards) she cracks it open only to find that it's hard boiled and not a raw egg.

column1: 1067-well this is where it starts to get entertaining for all of the engineers on the bus.

column2: it was just about 1 o'clock when i was on the bus
column3: so there were a lot of non-engineering students just headed back to bursley after class
column4: and thus only about half the bus was keeping an eye on the hot chicks - you see
column5: engineers don't come across girls much
column6: and when we encounter hot chicks we tend to just kind of stare at them.

column1: 1069-well
column3: remember the girl in black was talking about all of the hard boiled eggs.so
column4: the girl in the sweatshirt says
column7: why don't you just unboil them?

column2: remember we on the bus that are paying attention are all engineers.

column1: 1071-i had already figured out that this girl was an idiot (sweatshirt in the cold)
column2: but the rest of the engineers must have been too engrossed staring at her to think much of that
column3: so when she says the line about unboiling the eggs
column4: one engineer just about chokes on his jimmy john's while the others stares turn from awe to amazement and shock at her stupidity - it really was funny.so the girl in black actually notices everyone staring at them at this point
column5: and gets a little bit freaked out.

column1: 1072-she says something like
column2: "what the fuck are you talking about
column3: you can't unboil an egg"
column4: to which dumb sweatshirt girl says
column6: my boyfriend told me all about it.and i'll spare you the story
column7: but it basically involved a practical joke that her boyfriend had played on her which resulted in her cracking a raw egg on her forehead.

column1: 1073-by now
column2: most of the people on the bus
column3: even the non-engineers
column4: are trying to contain their laughter.

column1: 1074-i really can't
column2: and i'm pretty much laughing out loud
column3: but only the girl in black notices.and she gets pissed - either at the sweatshirt girl
column4: or at everyone laughing at her
column5: i don't know - and starts YELLING

column1: 1075-each time she yells it
column2: sweatshirt girl starts getting bitchier and bitchier
column3: yelling "YES YOU CAN".

column1: 1076-finally
column2: the dude in front of them turns around
column3: looks sweatshirt girl in the eye and says "you're crazy

column1: 1077-this shut her up at least
column2: and the north face girl looks really happy at being validated - i think that during the whole argument she wasn't really sure herself that you couldn't unboil an egg.so the sweatshirt girl just sits there for a minute
column3: and then i can hear her mumbling under her breath something about "chemicals" and "her boyfriend" and she finally tells the northface girl that "i'm sure you can somehow.

column1: 1078-"northface girl of course just yells "NO YOU CANT".by now
column2: most of the engineers have slapped their foreheads and left their hands there
column3: making a pretty funny scene - a whole bunch of dorky guys holding their hands to their heads while shaking them.the girls talked about it for a while
column4: and finally sweatshirt girl agreed that maybe you couldn't unboil an egg.

column1: 1079-by now
column2: the rest of the bus was talking about it
column3: and from the front
column4: we could all hear a flaming homosexual music major ask
column9: which caused me and just about everyone else to go into convulsions of laughter all over again.by now
column10: we had just about reached the stop
column11: but stupid sweatshirt girl wasn't done yet.

column1: 1080-she had started talking about how it was tuesday
column3: and how we should change the calendar so that wednesday was the first day in the week and tuesday was the last

column1: 1841-As I pull into my parking lot

column1: 1842-Annoyed though intrigued

column2: I realize almost simultaneously that the sound is coming from my apartment and is the sound of six smoke detectors going off at once.

column1: 1844-Can someone cautiously bust into an apartment?
1845-I did just that.
1846-No smoke.
1847-IRON ON AN IRONING BOARD!
1848-But it was cool and non-burning.
1849-RUN UPSTAIRS.
1654-Nothing.
1851-W h a t  t h e  h e l l .
1854-The usual way to get the damned smoke detectors is to find the one that is being set off and then flagellate a large cloth object (usually a bath towel) in its general direction.
1855-No smoke means no amount of flagellating will help.
1856-By this point
1857-The sound is so much
column2: I cannot even tell where it is coming from any more.

column1: 1858-All of the detectors are on the same circuit
column2: so I started disconnecting them one by one.

column1: 1859-Being just under 6 foot tall
column2: the detectors were *just* out of my reach to be grabbed down and disconnected.

column1: 1860-Damn it all
column2: I just started ripping them down cautiously (again
column3: if possible).

column1: 1861-I got 5 of them (the sixth was already disconnected) but the sound continued!

column2: or if the sound was all in my head.

column1: 1863-After an eternity of going nuts
column2: the detectors timed out and the silence was deafening.

column1: 1864-None of my roommates were home
column3: it made no sense.

column1: 1865-Thinking of how great my luck is
column2: I knew that if I left all of the detectors disconnected there *would* be a fire.

column2: the system administrator could boot off this floppy again and run the comparison utility.

column1: 2174-I am resodding my parent's front lawn.
2175-It's a fireball of fun
2176-Here is a little list I whipped up of the steps I need to take to properly resod (reseed
column2: actually) the lawn:   Remove all old turf.

column1: 2177-Test the composition of the soil.
2178-Add soil amendments to correct soil composition.
2179-Add fertilizer and till 6 inches of the soil.
2180-Level soil to a 1-2 degree grade.
2181-Water for 2 weeks to allow weed seeds to germinate.
2182-Remove weeds with Round Up.
2183-Lightly rake top of soil.
2184-Spread seed equally in two passes
column2: the second at 90 degrees to the first.

column1: 2185-Lightly rake the fresh seed.
2186-Lightly roll the fresh seed.
2187-Apply a light layer of mulch.
2188-Water lightly (5-10 minutes) twice daily until lawn height is  inch.
2189-Water deeper (15-20 minutes) once daily until lawn height is 3 inches.
2190-Mow lawn to 2 inches with a sharp-bladed bagging mower.

column2: we need to take advantage of the compute power in Linux clusters.

column1: 2247-We have our own small cluster and we would liek to exploit the capabilities of the large cluster in the Center for Parallel Computing.

column1: 2251-A script would detect what machines are idle and launch jobs in a joblist serially.

column2: I will define the "lifespan" of an operating system to be from the day it is released to the public (either for purchase or for download) to the time *two* new versions of the operating system have come out.

column1: 2264-An example would be  urlLink OpenBSD 2.9 .
2265-It was released on June 1st of 2001.
2266-Since  urlLink OpenBSD 3.1  (the second version past 2.9) came out on May 19th of 2002

2336-Ever wanted to print a man page in unix?
2337-You can't simply pipe the output straight to a printer device
2338-Most normal workstations will have a2ps installed
column2: a tool that converts ascii text to a PostScript file.

column1: 2339-To print a man page:  man {someSubject} | a2ps -m -P {printerName}  To save a man page in PS format:  man {someSubject} | a2ps -m -o {fileName}

column1: 2467-Her lyrics were a bit obtuse for a first time listener

I've fallen in love with two older games lately:   urlLink Gran Turismo 3  and  urlLink chess .
2510-Yeah
column2: chess is just a wee bit older.

column1: 2511-Basically
column2: Joe tossed GT3 into the PS2 earlier this week for the first time since we've owned it.

column1: 2512-He has only played the rally races (since he hates all of the races on pavement).
2513-Matt and him scrapped for awhile and I tossed my hat into the ring.
2514-I was under the impression that to correctly navigate a turn you had to be turning the whole time.
2515-In rally
column2: this couldn't be farther from the truth.

column1: 2516-You turn well before the actual bend in the road and then power slide through almost every one.
2517-I got smoked in those first few races.
2518-After they had left
column2: I gave the course a few more runs.

column1: 2519-I just barely beat the course on "Easy" mode *then* I figured out turning.
2520-Each run saw my times improving after each iteration.
2521-Eventually
column2: I was beating the CPU car by 10 seconds in "Hard" mode.

column1: 2522-That is when I got hooked.
2523-GT3 is an extremely deep game.
2524-Even the simplistic "Arcade" mode has 30+ tracks and too many cars for me to count.
2525-The simulation mode has a depth I haven't quite fathomed yet.
2526-You start off with a meager amount of money and no cars.
2527-My first car had a whopping 116 HP to start
column2: which was pretty depressing since Zig had a car that was pushing 1048 HP.

column1: 2528-You can customize your car
column2: earn driving licenses (that allow you to enter the more difficult races)
column3: and obviously race.

column1: 2529-I've just started
column2: but I'm sure I am going to be hooked.

column1: 2530-On to chess.
2531-For some reason
column2: Zig decided that all of his programming buddies should have a contest.

column1: 2532-He will write a basic GUI that allows people to plug-in two chess engines and have them go at it.
2533-I doubt I will participate (since writing a chess engine would take hundreds of hours
column3: but that got chess on our minds.

column1: 2535-We went back to my apartment and played four games:  Chris versus Matt
column3: Joe versus myself and then Joe versus Chris.

column1: 2536-None of the games ended with a checkmate since we were playing with the clock.
2537-The first game gave 15 minutes per person then we pulled that down to 10 minutes per game when Joe was playing.
2538-I just didn't pay attention to the clock and I ran out of time with the game probably only half way through.
2539-Speed chess just isn't my thing
column2: but I at least didn't lose in less than 20 minutes total.

2759-Here are the details:  The wrestling mats were laid out in the martial arts room because a session of aikido had just concluded.

column2: since she was just watching because who walks on their hands?

column1: 2765-Thirty seconds later
column2: she came up to me and asked if she could join me.

column1: 2766-At this point
2767-I hadn't been hit on in a very long time so I didn't know what to do and I also have a very serious girlfriend.

column2: but I couldn't lead her on in any way.

column1: 2769-Anyway
column2: I said of course she could join me and she asked if I did gymnastics.

column1: 2770-I explained that I used to walk on my hands when I wrestled in high school.

3007-Let's see
column3: the interview from a week and a half ago!

column1: 3008-I can't divulge much information
column2: for two reasons:  1)  I haven't gotten a yes or a no from said company.

column1: 3009-2)  I had to sign an NDA before I could talk to anyone.
3010-Let's see how many details I can give away without giving it all away.
3011-First
column2: I was told that I would have anywhere between three and five interviews total.

column1: 3012-There ended up being a total of six
column2: which I can only interpret as being a hopeful sign.

column1: 3013-I arrived at the recruiting building (yes
column2: an entire building devoted to recruiting) around 8 AM and didn't end up leaving until around 6 PM.

column1: 3014-Given a half hour for lunch
column2: that was practically nine and a half hours of interviewing!

column1: 3015-Second
column2: the riddles asked were fairly interesting and though I might have heard them all before
column3: I had never solved any of them.

column1: 3016-The first one wasn't so much a riddle as a generic design question.
3017-I was asked how I would design the timing on any given traffic light.
3018-I was allowed to request whatever information desired and then I had to come up with some formulas for making the "best" traffic light.
3019-The first part of the problem was how to define "best".
3020-What makes a good traffic light?
3021-I decided it was a combination of two factors:  1)  Maximum throughput in all directions.
3022-2)  Low traffic jam incidence rate.
3023-After figuring out the formula for a single intersection
column2: I had to modify it for a grid of intersections.

column1: 3024-Then I was asked to "think outside the box" (yes
column2: that phrase was used exactly) and figure out other ways to improve the experience.

column1: 3025-All in all
3026-The second riddle was a programming question
column2: something I didn't expect to encounter since I was interviewing for a management position.

column1: 3027-Managers don't code!
3028-I was given a 2D array and had to figure out the time it would take to sort it.
3029-I barely remembered performance numbers for the different sort algorithms
column2: but I remembered that quick sort was O(n log n) (and thankfully was correct).

column1: 3030-Sorting a 2D array would thus take (O(n log n))^2.
3031-The second part to the programming question was how to sort two already sorted linked lists.
3032-This was simple
column2: since you just setup two iterators that would move along the two lists
column3: removing the smaller of the two items.

column1: 3033-The riddle I had the hardest time with was the cube desk calendar.
3034-You have two cubes and you are allowed to put any single digit on any face.
3035-With these two cubes
column2: you have to represent every number from 01 to 31.

column1: 3036-This turned out to not be that difficult when I realized you could mathematically approach this and define restrictions.
3037-Some examples of these restrictions are that you need a "1" on each block since you have to represent "11".
3038-The same thing for "2" and "22".
3039-Eventually
column2: I got to the point where I had six open spots on the cubes but seven numbers to put on the cubes.

column1: 3040-This is when I realized that you could use "6" to represent a "9" and thus solved the puzzle.
3041-Almost all of the riddle had a mathematic basis.
3042-The next riddle started off as a word problem.
3043-A man starts at point A on a mountain and walks up to point B in exactly 12 hours.
3044-At some time later
column2: he walks down from point B to point A in exactly 12 hours.

column1: 3045-He does not have a constant rate of ascent or descent.
3046-The actual riddle was "Can you prove or disprove the existence of a point P where the man took the same amount of time to reach the same spot on the mountain?"
3047-I was having trouble trying to prove this
column2: since it had to be true.

column1: 3048-Eventually
column2: I was given a hint to use a graph.

column1: 3049-First I tried plotting time versus distance.
3050-That was dumb.
3051-Once I plotted time versus location
column2: I showed that the plots must intersect and thus a point P does exist.

column1: 3052-The last riddle was one I heard a long
3053-I knew the answer
column2: but didn't know how to explain it at first.

column1: 3054-This was the "Let's Make a Deal" riddle:  You have three doors to choose from
3055-After you choose your door
column2: the host of the show will eliminate one of the doors you did not choose and then ask you to pick again.

column1: 3056-You can either stick with your original door or choose the remaining door.
3057-The question is
column2: do you stay or do you switch and why?

column1: 3058-I knew you were supposed to switch
column2: but couldn't think off the top of my head why.

column1: 3059-Finally I realized that your initial chance at winning was only 1 in 3.
3060-After the elimination
column2: your chance is at least 2 in 3.

column1: 3061-Switching is smart.

column2: that was the first of more updates.

column1: Well
3079-I didn't buy  urlLink this
3080-Instead of leasing a car for three years
column2: I'm buying it over three years.

column1: 3081-I'm also saving myself hundreds of dollars a month in payments and insurance.
3082-I guess I'm happy with this responsible decision.
3083-Mmm mmm
column2: nothing like a good one month hiatus to get the not-so-creative juices flowing.

column1: 3084-Where to start...  Well
column3: I started working at Microsoft!

column1: 3085-The move out was emotional
3086-The flight went fine
column2: I got my month-long rental car just fine and I got into my new (temporary) apartment just fine.

column1: 3087-Jenn so gratiously gave me a Gamecube just before I left.
3088-That worked out perfectly because all of my stuff had already been packed to be shipped to the Seattle area so I had to take the GC on the plane.
3089-If it wasn't for the TV and the GC
column2: I probably would have died of boredom those first four days.

column1: 3090-Imagine being in apartment without 99% of your belongings in a new city where you don't know anyone.
3091-It was worse than I can describe.
3092-Yeah
column2: I cried off and on those first few days.

column1: 3093-There are so many people back in the SE-MI area that I miss!
3094-Once I got through those first few days
3095-I got into a routine of waking up early and going to bed early to prepare myself for work.
3096-I drove around town getting myself used to the area.
3097-One big thing I've noticed is the marked difference in driving patterns.
3098-Five over the speed limit is the most I've seen someone without a radar detector do.
3099-Most people drive slower than the speed limit!
3100-This could be because everyone is used to the traffic...
3101-I swear to god it has to be some of the worst in the US.
3102-The area is surrounded by water and mountains so the highways are not as plentiful as possible.
3103-It's also difficult to widen any of the existing highways.
3104-There are simply too many people and cars for the area.
3105-They do have HOV (carpool) lanes
column2: but it seems that very few people can take advantage of them.

column1: 3106-I think I might start carpooling just because no one else is.
3107-Some of the on-ramps are metered (meaning that there is a light that will allow only one car through every few seconds) but allow open access to the HOV lane.
3108-I've also decided to change my car choice because of the traffic.
3109-What's the fun in a  urlLink sports car  if you can't take advantage of it?
3110-It's also possible that I will have a substantial commute
column2: so gas mileage might be a big concern.

column1: 3111-I also haven't chosen a city to live in
3112-Lots to do in the next couple of weeks!
3113-As for the job itself
column2: I'm really not sure how much I can say.

column1: 3114-I have a much better understanding of what I will actually be doing though!
3115-From what I can tell
column2: I will be a bug wrangler.

column1: 3116-Basically
column2: I will help the developers and testers eliminate bugs from already-released products.

column1: 3117-Hotfix
column3: service packs

column1: 3118-Also
column2: my title has changed in the past two weeks: Program Manager on the Critical Response Team in the Mobile Devices Product Group.

column1: 3119-They changed from MDD (Mobile Devices Division) to MDPG (Mobile Devices Product Group).
3120-I was told this is a common occurance and not to stock up on business cards since they will be out of date before I get them.
3121-I can't tell anyone my phone number or office number since they are supposed to change in the next two weeks.
3122-The entire group (MDPG) is being shuffled around to better coordinate the smaller groups (like CRT).
3123-If there is one thing I don't like about the job (yeah
3124-is that there are no set hours.
3125-Basically
column2: if you are in the office in time for meetings and you get all of your work done
column3: you can work whatever hours you want.

column1: 3126-Because of this
column2: everyone has the mentality that they need to work 12 hours a day to look productive!

column1: 3127-The first day (Monday)
column2: I simply told my boss that I was leaving when I had finished all of my day-one work.

column1: 3128-He said that was okay.
3129-Today (the second day)
column2: I ended up staying for 11 hours.

column1: 3130-I got in around 7:30 AM
column2: which is about 2.5 hours before most of the office gets in.

column1: 3131-When 4:30 PM rolled around
column2: I didn't think it would look right to leave.

column1: 3132-The office was still packed!
3133-I need to go to a car dealership tomorrow around 5 PM and the dealership is 30 minutes away.
3134-I'm going to have to leave before 4:30 PM.
3135-I don't care what it looks like
3136-I was given a simple to-do list for the next two days and I've already finished it.
3137-I'm doing well
3138-Anyway
column2: that is all I have time for right now.

column1: 3139-I still don't have my company-issued laptop and my two computers from home haven't shipped yet
column2: so I have resorted to checking my Umich mail from the local library.

column1: 3140-Hopefully this all gets rectified soon.
3141-I miss you all!

column4: urlLink Russ  and I went over to  urlLink Mark's  place for a BBQ.

column2: but that was after we had already melted a plastic spatula trying to remove some hamburgers.

column1: 3153-We cooked and chatted for a few hours
column2: then decided to go to downtown Seattle for fireworks.

column1: 3154-Russ and I took his car and Ben and Lee took Lee's car.

3156-Once we found where we were supposed to be
3157-It took us at least an hour to find parking
column2: then another 30 minutes to walk to the park.

column1: 3158-We met up with some other people just in time for some snacks and then the fireworks started!
3159-The show wasn't terribly eventful; the Livonia fireworks were almost as good.

column2: most of the group was going to bars down in Pioneer Square.

column1: 3166-They are a fun bunch

column1: 3368-I was driving on 520 from my apartment to the good Target in Redmond.
3369-I'm following behind a Red Ford Expedition at a decent distance.
3370-Out of nowhere
column2: I see that he is about to run over a 4'x4' piece of plywood.

column1: 3371-The SUV drives directly over it so that it goes between his wheels.
3372-The downforce air pressure from the SUV causes the wood to fly up into the air.
3373-It flips slowly and at just the right angle so that when I PLOW into it
column2: it is like hitting a wall.

column1: 3374-Most of the board shatters into hundreds of car-scratching pieces but one 1.5'x1.5' chunk sticks to my bumper since I'm driving 60 MPH.
3375-I pull off to the shoulder
column3: the piece slides down and I run it over (possibly causing unseen tire damage).

column1: 3376-I just called the insurance agent and thankfully it will be covered.
3377-Unfortunately
column2: the adjuster is booked until next Saturday and I will have to pay my $250 comprensible deductible.

column1: 3378-Oh well

column1: 3390-Ive been to a few large metropolises before:  Detroit
column3: Atlanta
column6: Orlando and Toronto to name them all.

column1: 3391-NYC is completely different from all of them and it starts with the ambiance.
3392-Starting out in Times Square had to affect my perception dramatically
3393-The overall feeling that spewed from the city wasnt the common perception of impatience
column3: but one of surging energy.

column1: 3394-As Leah said
column2: there is just so much to the city given that there are so many different sectors
column3: each with its own life force.

column1: 3395-Time Square was bursting with this power because of the sheer vivacity (tactless extravagance) and curiosity (aimless tourists).
3396-We also visited the rest of midtown
column2: much of the upper East and West sides
column3: downtown and even touched some of the NYU campus.

column1: 3397-Blast to the fact that I didnt have my camera that night:  there is a cube almost identical to the one on the UMich campus!
3398-The only difference is that theirs didnt spin.
3399-As Leah and I noticed it and walked near
column2: someone hopped out of the car at a red light.

column1: 3400-He scampered over the cube and tried to give it a push.
3401-He hopped back into his car and then gestured to his passenger that he knew of a cube that rotated.
3402-I yelled to him The one in Ann Arbor spins
column3: slightly bewildered and replied in the affirmative.

column1: 3403-Since Leah had just turned twenty one the previous week

column3: but ended up going to the closest bar we saw.

column1: 3409-It was called Pioneer and wasnt too bad of a place.

column2: NYC bars are open until 4 AM and dont seem to swell until 1:30 AM.

column1: 3411-There were about 25-35 people inside total
column2: but you couldnt tell by the noise level.

column1: 3412-The DJ was blaring a mix of old and new dance (pop mostly) though no one was dancing and everyone had to yell over the music to hear each other.
3413-Nonetheless

column2: our tongues were looser and we both learned something.

column1: 3428-Hoffmans role seemed small and insignificant at first

column1: 3429-Read the book or watch the movie to see what I mean.

column1: 3431-If it does not show technical ability or is not visually appealing (very subjective)
3432-I still dislike watercolors and most modern art
column3: pale orange and brown against white and silver
column6: geometric abstraction and period fusion (example:  an series of WWII-style Japanese bombers in the shape of an infinity symbol over a burning current-day mid Manhattan done in the style of Edo period Japanese room screens using mother-of-pearl inlay and gold).

column1: 3533-The first dream I had was more of a nightmare.
3534-Basically
column2: two shady guys were going door to door trying to sell Smartphones to people.

column1: 3535-They had about 40 of the phones just tossed into a big plastic box.
3536-I don't remember actually letting them into the house
column2: but all of a sudden they were both in my parents kitchen trying to sell us AR11s.

column1: 3537-As a side note
column2: the  urlLink AR11  is our most hated device.

column1: 3538-It would never see a retail market because it has so many problems.
3539-Anyway
column2: at first they were lackadaisically trying to get us to each buy a phone.

column1: 3540-It seemed that they were both very tired
column2: worn out and just wanted money.

column1: 3541-It also seemed as if all the phones were stolen
3542-When we refused to buy a phone
column2: they started to argue and yell at us.

column1: 3543-Eventually
column2: I took things into my own hands and started to beat on the leader of the two guys.

column1: 3544-I didn't hurt him too much and suddenly he was gone.
3545-I shoved his companion out the door and he rested against a parked car.
3546-Now this is where it starts to get weird and will be hard to imagine.
3547-So picture that you are looking out the door of a house onto a driveway.
3548-From your vantage point
column2: you can see just the backend of a car parked in the driveway.

column1: 3549-The second bad guy that I tossed out of the house was leaning against the car
3550-He wasn't looking directly at me
column2: but basically looking at the ground.

column1: 3551-He seemed exhausted and looked to be resting a bit before moving on.
3552-Suddenly and without warning
column2: you see just a glimpse of the first shady guy come into the picture as he drops an axe down on the skull of the second guy
column3: practically cleaving it in two!

column1: 3553-For some reason
column2: I busted out of the house and ran past both the man wielding the axe and his now-dead accomplice.

column1: 3554-I felt that I was being chased a bit and then I felt everything had changed.
3555-I looked around
column2: and the man with the axe was now laying on his back on the hood of a different car.

column1: 3556-His axe seemed to have bashed him directly in the face.
3557-I focused past that and saw my mom's friend Evelyn holding a smoking gun!
3558-I can only assume that while he was chasing me
column2: she shot him in the back
column3: he fell back onto the car and then his axe fell onto his face.

column1: 4039-Starting with  urlLink this discussion about a nuclear-powered mission to the moons of Jupiter
column2: there was a link to this  urlLink article
column3: stating that crash landing a nuclear-powered probe into Jupiter could cause it to turn into a star.

column1: 4040-Basically
column2: this article is full of facts and a gross misuse of these facts.

column1: 4041-They have correct information about the Galileo craft and some fairly factual discussion about fission
4042-While it is true that the materials on the craft could be used for a fission bomb
column2: they completely ignored the concept of critical mass.

column1: 4043-I couldn't think of the right term while reading the incorrect article
column2: but the question of just how much plutonium was necessary came to mind.

column1: 4044-Bad Astronomy saves the day and debunks the possiblity of a small nuclear-powered probe turning Jupiter into a star with this  urlLink article .
4045-The critical (pun intended) points here are:  The plutonium onboard Galileo was kept in small pellets
column2: none of which were near critical mass.

column1: 4046-The hydrogen on Jupiter is of the most abundant isotope and lacks deuterium and tritium needed for a fusion reaction.
4047-Jupiter is about 1/80th the size needed to be a self-sustaining star.
4048-I love science.
4049-The most difficult thing in the world is to know how to do a thing and to watch someone else doing it wrong

4154-Sorry that I disappeared for a few days there; I have a good reason.
4155-On Monday while playing racquetball
column2: I severely injured my knee again.

column1: 4156-Here is how I did it.
4157-Instead of wearing my normal cross-trainer shoes to play rball
column2: I was wearing my turf shoes.

column1: 4158-Turf shoes have amazing traction on almost any surface
column2: including the hardwood floor of the rball court.

column1: 4159-Whenever I land from a jump
column2: I keep my foot perpendicular to my shoulders until I land
column3: when I rotate my foot away from my body for added balance.

column1: 4160-that is how you are supposed to land.
4161-Well
column3: I went to rotate my foot but my shoe decided to have super traction and not move.

column1: 4162-All of the rotational force went straight to the inner portion of my left knee.
4163-It was 10 PM by the time I got home
column2: so I couldn't see a doctor on Monday.

column1: 4164-The next morning
column2: I waited until I heard from Kat to make an appointment since I figured her dad (a doctor) would be able to make a good recommendation.

column1: 4165-When I called to make an appointment at 11 AM
column2: they were booked for the day and I had to wait until Wednesday.

column1: 4166-The x-ray shows that I definitely did some serious damage and that I also have a bone shard taken off the medial portion of my left knee.
4167-Because of the amount of swelling
column2: the doc recommended that I get an MRI.

column1: 4168-That was done the same day but I will not get the results until at least Friday afternoon.
4169-The current prognosis is a torn MCL
column3: torn meniscus and the bone shard.

column1: 1127-Lovely.
4171-I'm currently wearing a huge brace but the pain is not so bad.
4172-It comes and goes and luckily I can walk fairly well.
4173-I missed a day and a half of work
column2: so I'm a bit behind now.

column1: 4326-I've been wrestling with hardware issues for about four days now.
4327-That is what I get for naming a server fireball!
4328-Basically
column2: the machine that has been my internet router
column3: NAT box
column6: RDP proxy has gone through quite a few upgrades.

column1: 4329-It originally was my old overclocking desktop (thus
4330-It was upgraded to a 500 MHz PIII and it currently has a 700 MHz Duron.
4331-A month or so ago
column2: I bought a new 120 GB drive for my desktop (thanks
column3: urlLink Slickdeals !)

column1: 4332-and last week I finally got around to putting my old 30 GB drive into fireball.
4333-The problems started then.
4334-Since the 30 GB drive was already in my desktop
column2: I decided to install OpenBSD 3.4 on the drive before transferring it to the server.

column1: 4335-That install went smoothly
column2: but the drive would not boot when I transferred it.

column1: 4336-I figured it just didn't like the transfer
column2: so I reinstalled OpenBSD while in fireball.

column1: 4337-When I tried to boot after the second install
column2: the bootloader would come up with crap like "@$%@#$*@#$#$%!@#((^%".

column1: 4338-After 45 minutes of playing around with the bootloader
column2: the BIOS and the boot sequence
column3: I finally figured out that it wouldn't boot unless the drive was the primary on the IDE chain.

column2: finally got the new drive up and running!

column1: 4340-When installing OBSD
column2: my first steps are to install the ports tree
column3: tcsh
column5: the source and add 'mbibik' as a user.

column1: 4341-I got as far as compiling tcsh static when the machine just froze
4342-I figured
column3: just a random lockup.

column1: 4343-Nope
column3: the machine would freeze.

column1: 4344-Obviously (at least to me)
column2: this seemed like a heat issue.

column1: 4345-I opened the case to check out the CPU fan
column2: but it's a fairly small (AKA cramped) case so I couldn't see the fan behind the power supply.

column1: 4346-I monitored the CPU temp and it never seemed to get into dangerous territory.
4347-I gave up at this point and told Russell the internet would be down for awhile (no server
column3: no internet).

column1: 4348-I started to play with it again
column2: but there isn't much you can do when the damned thing freezes every 15 minutes!

column1: 4349-I gave up trying to install tcsh
column3: etc and just started surfing the net from my desktop.

column1: 4350-Oddly enough
4351-At this point
column2: I realized that interactive activities such as installing or compiling are probably accessing the disk more than just using the box as a router (which would only access the disk to periodically write logs).

column1: 4352-I switched back to the old drive
4353-Too bad my 30 GB drive is fried!

column1: 4525-Excellent comment on society and a good social experiment.
4526-I believe George Carlin said it best:  Here is my problem with the ten commandments- why exactly are there 10?
4527-You simply do not need ten.
4528-The list of ten commandments was artificially and deliberately inflated to get it up to ten.
4529-Here's what happened:  About 5
column2: 000 years ago a bunch of religious and political hustlers got together to try to figure out how to control people and keep them in line.

column1: 4530-They knew people were basically stupid and would believe anything they were told
column2: so they announced that God had given them some commandments
column3: up on a mountain

column1: 4531-Well let me ask you this- when they were making this shit up
4532-Why not 9 or 11?
4533-I'll tell you why- because 10 sound official.
4534-Ten sounds important!
4535-Ten is the basis for the decimal system
column3: it's a psychologically satisfying number (the top ten

column1: 4536-So having ten commandments was really a marketing decision!
4537-It is clearly a bullshit list.
4538-It's a political document artificially inflated to sell better.
4539-I will now show you how you can reduce the number of commandments and come up with a list that's a little more workable and logical.
4540-I am going to use the Roman Catholic version because those were the ones I was taught as a little boy.

4541-Let's start with the first three:  I AM THE LORD THY GOD THOU SHALT NOT HAVE STRANGE GODS BEFORE ME  THOU SHALT NOT TAKE THE NAME OF THE LORD THY GOD IN VAIN  THOU SHALT KEEP HOLY THE SABBATH  Right off the bat the first three are pure bullshit.
4542-Sabbath day?
4543-Lord's name?
4544-strange gods?
4545-Spooky language!
4546-Designed to scare and control primitive people.
4547-In no way does superstitious nonsense like this apply to the lives of intelligent civilized humans in the 21st century.
4548-So now we're down to 7.
4549-Next:  HONOR THY FATHER AND MOTHER  Obedience
4550-Just another name for controlling people.
4551-The truth is that obedience and respect shouldn't be automatic.
4552-They should be earned and based on the parent's performance.
4553-Some parents deserve respect
column3: period.

column1: 4554-You're down to six.
4555-Now in the interest of logic
column2: something religion is very uncomfortable with
column3: we're going to jump around the list a little bit.

column1: 4556-THOU SHALT NOT STEAL  THOU SHALT NOT BEAR FALSE WITNESS  Stealing and lying.
4557-Well actually
column2: these two both prohibit the same kind of behavior- dishonesty.

column1: 4558-So you don't really need two you combine them and call the commandment "thou shalt not be dishonest".
4559-And suddenly you're down to 5.
4560-And as long as we're combining I have two others that belong together:  THOU SHALT NOT COMMIT ADULTRY  THOU SHALT NOT COVET THY NEIGHBOR'S WIFE  Once again
column2: these two prohibit the same type of behavior.

column1: 4561-In this case it is marital infidelity.
4562-The difference is- coveting takes place in the mind.
4563-But I don't think you should outlaw fantasizing about someone else's wife because what is a guy gonna think about when he's waxing his carrot?

column2: marital infidelity is a good idea so we're gonna keep this one and call it "thou shalt not be unfaithful".

column1: 4565-And suddenly we're down to four.
4566-But when you think about it
column2: honesty and infidelity are really part of the same overall value so
column3: in truth
column4: you could combine the two honesty commandments with the two fidelity commandments and give them simpler language
column5: positive language instead of negative language and call the whole thing "thou shalt always be honest and faithful" and we're down to 3.

column1: 4567-THOU SHALT NOT COVET THY NEIGHBOR"S GOODS  This one is just plain fuckin' stupid.
4568-Coveting your neighbor's goods is what keeps the economy going!
4569-Your neighbor gets a vibrator that plays "o come o ye faithful"
4570-Coveting creates jobs
4571-You throw out coveting and you're down to 2 now- the big honesty and fidelity commandment and the one we haven't talked about yet:  THOU SHALT NOT KILL  Murder.
4572-But when you think about it
column2: religion has never really had a big problem with murder.

column1: 4573-More people have been killed in the name of god than for any other reason.
4574-All you have to do is look at Northern Ireland
column3: the Inquisition
column5: and the World Trade Center to see how seriously the religious folks take thou shalt not kill.

column1: 4575-The more devout they are
column2: the more they see murder as being negotiable.

column1: 4576-It depends on who's doin the killin' and who's gettin' killed.

column2: with all of this in mind
column3: I give you my revised list of the two commandments:  Thou shalt always be honest and faithful to the provider of thy nookie.

column2: unless of course they pray to a different invisible man than you.

4671-Setting:   A Gameworks or some sort of gaming facility.

column3: similar to a casino in that respect.

column1: 4673-Basically
column2: it had the feel of a Gameworks
column3: casino and bowling alley combined.

column1: 4674-First scene:  I'm sitting down and playing some sort of matching game
column3: with quarters.

column1: 4675-An older lady approaches from nowhere and demands to know where my gamer card is (If you have been to Gameworks or Dave  Busters
column2: you know that instead of using quarters
column3: you get a credit card of sorts that you can put money on.

column1: 4676-I show a pocket full of quarters
column2: implying that I'm just playing with quarters and she storms off.

column1: 4677-She returns about 5 minutes later and hands me a large stack of gamer chips (4 $25
column4: 4 $1) and a fist fill of Twizzlers.

column1: 4678-The look she gives me as she walks off was
column3: kid.

column1: 4679-Have some fun and enjoy the sugar!".
4680-Possibly she thought I was poor since I only showed about 5 dollars with in quarters.
4681-I vaguely remember winning a lot of money on the Mastermind game and then being given a tour of the facility.
4682-The man in charge was giving the tour and reminded me of  urlLink Tom Poston  from the Newhart show
column2: but with a suit that Rod Roddy would wear.

column1: 4683-Well
column2: a suit he would have worn
column3: since he  urlLink died  of breast cancer.

column1: 4684-During the tour
column2: I remember passing by a small room in the back with mirrors on the walls and a rainbow motif adorning the ceiling.

column1: 4685-He said that was in case anyone felt like dancing and could also be rented out.
4686-Oddly enough
column2: it was empty and the lights were off.

column1: 4687-I can only imagine how those rainbows would look with the full house lights!
4688-I know I would want to shake my groove thang
column2: and probably go suck on a popsicle or eat some sausage.

column1: 4689-Second scene:  The dream gets fuzzy for a bit
column2: but I remember after the tour there was this one counter way in the back with no one around it.

column1: 4690-The person running it is none other than Beth Manoongian
4691-This game was a trivia game with a twist.
4692-The questions are extremely difficult but the prize for answering a single question runs in the millions of dollars.
4693-I decide to give it a shot
column2: hoping that Beth will help me out a little bit.

column1: 4694-As she pulls the question from a long box of cards
column2: she places it on ledge face down in front of me
column3: then gets a phone call.

column1: 4695-While she isn't watching
column2: I try to see what the answer is
column3: but can't quite make it out.

column1: 4696-It looks like "Yeh" to me backwards.
4697-The question was something like "What is the beach on Jo Beach?".
4698-Sort of a trick question
column2: but I thought I already had the answer.

column1: 4699-I hem and haw for a bit
4700-The answer was actually "Lev"
column2: which doesn't make sense to me in the dream or in the waking world.

column1: 4701-Since playing the game is free
column2: I have her pull out another card.

column1: 4702-By this time
column2: someone else has joined me at the counter.

column1: 4703-This person seemed to be between 18-22 years old
column3: dark hair
column4: reminded me of a frat boy.

column1: 4704-The next question wasn't even a question
column2: it was something along the lines of "(SomeForeignName) is furious."

column1: 4705-I think the riddle was that you had to figure out the country that would give out a name like that then give the translation for "furious".
4706-The random guy and I looked at each other trying to figure it out and then I woke up.
4707-I should rent out my brain for studies into the abnormal.

column1: 4724-urlLink New Scientist :  It looks like the "fact" that mammals do not produce new eggs after birth may be incorrect.
4725-With a study done on mice
column2: it appears that the number of living eggs decreases too rapidly for the number of eggs available at birth to persist until menopause.

column1: 4726-To test if new eggs were created
column2: an ovary from a normal mouse was inplanted into a mouse that was genetically modified to generate a glowing protein in all new cells.

column1: 4727-After transplant
column2: eggs were observed with the glowing protein
column3: practically confirming that new eggs are created after birth.

column2: I went to donate without an appointment and they were full.

column1: 4983-Finally

column2: I had to go through the full screening process
column3: mini interview and all.

column1: 4985-Finally
column2: I give blood and they have me lay down for an extra a few minutes afterward since this was my first time with them and all.

column1: 4986-The actual process of giving blood went just fine.
4987-As I was laying down resting
column2: my stomach started to feel a bit nauseous.

column1: 4988-Suddenly
column2: the nausea got worse and I started to think about asking one of the nurses for something to vomit into.

column1: 4989-The next thing I notice
column2: there are three people crowded around me and I've got cold compresses on my neck and chest.

column1: 4990-Turns out
4991-I was only out for a few seconds
column2: but it was not a pleasant experience.

column1: 4992-Soon after I woke up
column2: I broke out in a cold sweat.

column1: 4993-I felt functional about 5 minutes later
column2: but I was definitely tired and out of it for the rest of the day.

column3: skipped my hockey game.

4998-Katherine and I went to Daniel's Broiler on Lake Union on Thursday night.
4999-We had a $25 gift certificate
column2: but that really doesn't go very far when the entrees are about $40 each!

column1: 5000-The hostess treated us just like any other couple having dinner on a Thursday night
column2: but the waiter had a different idea.

column1: 5001-It seems that he saw two kids that were in over their heads and thus he didn't expect a large tip.
5002-Since
column3: his tip was already shot
column4: he decided to basically treat us like an annoyance.

column1: 5003-Since I was out for a nice dinner
column2: I ordered Perrier to start and I made Kat get some Evian even though she is a tap water kind of girl.

column1: 5004-He brought us two glasses and two bottles and didn't even offer to pour for us.
5005-I know
column3: but come on.

column1: 5006-While every other table received warm bread and butter before the meal
column2: I had to specifically request it.

column1: 5007-When it finally came
column2: our food was ready not 2 minutes later.

column1: 5008-When we ordered wine
column2: he acted as if the only grape product we had ever drank was Welch's.

column1: 5009-Thanks buddy
column2: I know the basics of wine
column3: and yes I do know that higher altitude wines come from a more concentrated grape.

column1: 5010-He got most of our order correct
column2: but he switched how Katherine and I liked our meat (I ordered medium and she ordered medium-rare and he switched them).

column1: 5011-Kat has eaten at Daniel's probably ten times and she said this was the first time they didn't offer to cut the meat at the table to show that it was cooked properly.
5012-Maybe he knew he had messed up.
5013-No matter what
column2: our waiter was still not the most annoying part of the evening!

column1: 5014-Soon after we had sat down
column2: a pair of gentlemen were seated directly behind us.

column1: 5015-Our backs were mostly turned to them
column2: but Kat could tell that the older of the two
column3: maybe 45-50 years old

column1: 5016-This skeeved her out a bit
5017-After we had finished our entree and started to dig into some creme brulee
column2: our waiter approached carrying two glasses of red wine.

column1: 5018-He informed us that the man behind us offered two glasses of his fine Argentinean wine.
5019-We raised our glasses and turned to the man and thanked him.
5020-He said "Enjoy
column2: or as we would say in Norway
column3: Skord."

column1: 5021-At this point
5022-Here was two men that had offered us nice wine and now expected us to at least talk to them.
5023-I basically told Kat to hurry up and drink the wine so we could say a quick word with them and then get the hell out of there!
5024-Kat didn't want to gulp the wine
column2: figuring that would be even more rude.

column1: 5025-Eventually
column2: we started to talk to them while we were all still seated.

column1: 5026-He asked if we were here on business and when I replied in the negative
column3: you two look too romantic for business."

column1: 5027-The older man was doing all the talking and when he informed me that his companion was visiting from Norway
column2: I just assumed that he couldn't speak English very well.

column1: 5028-The older man then complemented Kat on her looks and said something about us being an attractive couple.
5029-Kat and were both obviously nervous and annoyed
column2: but we were still stuck talking.

column1: 5030-The man finally said something about his wife and then started babbling.
5031-I couldn't understand a word he was saying and Katherine was having trouble hearing
column2: so we basically turned back to our table to finish the wine and escape.

column1: 5032-After drinking the last drop
column2: we got up to leave and I approached the man to at least shake his hand.

column1: 5033-After shaking
column2: he gently held on to my hand and placed his other hand on my upper arm
column3: basically trapping me there.

column1: 5034-He asked if we enjoyed the wine
column2: if we would like to sit down and have another glass.

column1: 5035-I told him we had to leave and we basically fled.
5036-At this point
column2: I heard his companion speak and he said something in accent-free English.

column1: 5037-He understood the language
column2: he was just being quiet because he was obviously embarrassed by what was going on!

column1: 5038-Kat was
column3: a bit disturbed by the whole situation.

5084-My take on GMail.

column2: I've only been using it for a short while
column3: but I haven't quite gotten the hang of it yet.

column1: 5086-The first issue is that all email is sorted by "conversations"
column2: which is basically what everyone but Microsoft and GMail call threads.

column1: 5087-For those of you that don't know what that means
column2: a thread/conversation is just what it sounds like
column3: a collection of email messages relating to a specific topic.

column1: 5088-On the most basic level
column2: a conversation is an original message and any replies to that message.

column1: 5089-Certain mail clients assign a thread ID and thus you can change the message subject and it will still be a part of the original thread/conversation.
5090-Either GMail or Yahoo doesn't support thread ID because I changed the subject on a thread and GMail started a new "conversation".
5091-There are a ton of keyboard shortcuts
column2: which is interesting for a webmail client.

column1: 5092-Seeing as I used pine for my email for 6 years
column2: I'm quite used to navigating my email with a keyboard...  in pine!

column1: 5093-Using it in gmail isn't as easy as I expected.
5094-There are keyboard shortcuts for navigating various messages and conversations
column3: like cancelling the composition of a message
column4: has to be done by mouse.

column1: 5095-I do love that the keyboard shortcut for reporting spam is the excalamation key...  it just goes so well with most spam: "Ge.t a m.a$siv3 mem.b3r!
5096-buttercup obtuse bingo cxoiuqweijfd4klhjd7"  My natural response is "!".
5097-GMail has a concept of "All mail" and "archive".
5098-The main action for all emails is to "archive" it.
5099-It doesn't place the message in the trash
column2: it doesn't move it to a specific folder
column3: it just moves the email out of your inbox.

column1: 5100-The only way to view archived mails is to use the All Mail view.
5101-All Mail shows any mail in your inbox
column2: your sent mail "folder" and anything you have archived.

column1: 5102-It does not show any spam or trash emails.
5103-Instead of supporting folders like most email clients (web or desktop)
column2: GMail has introduced the concept of "Labels".

column1: 5104-Well
column3: but this is the first time I've seen it in relation to an email client.

column1: 5105-Instead of storing a conversation (see above) in various default or unique folders
column2: you can assign one or more labels to the conversation.

column1: 5106-Let's say that you wanted to save all conversations from a specific person in a specific folder and you wanted to save all conversations about a specific topic in a specific folder
column2: what happens if your specifics collide?

column1: 5107-Do you try to decide which folder takes presidence?
5108-With labels
column2: you can give the conversation labels for both the sender and the topic.

column1: 5109-Like most folder views
column2: there is a list of labels so you can jump to the list of all conversations with a specific label.

column1: 5110-GMail also supports filters which works hand in hand with labels.
5111-You can filter on sender
column3: subject
column4: words in the body and words missing from the body.

column1: 5112-The actions you can take are skip inbox (meaning it places the mail into the archive (see above))
column2: apply a specific label or move it directly to the trash.

column1: 5113-You cannot mark anything as spam through the filter.One little feature that I saw in their help files but they did not actually implement related to attachments.
5114-Instead of showing the common and generic paper clip icon to denote an attachment
column2: GMail would use an icon to represent the file type of the attachment.

column1: 5115-If it was a PDF
column2: the common PDF icon would be used
column3: etc.

column1: 5116-I tested this out
column2: and it's just a paper clip.

column1: 5117-Shucky darn.
5118-Overall
column2: I'm sure that I will get used to conversation view
column3: labels and archive and be very happy with my free 1000 MB webmail client harnessing Google!

1657-Sigh.
5474-Here are some of the highlights:  Set in a time where USA and the Soviet Union are at a full-on war.
5475-The first part of the dream sees me running across an American battlefield
column3: mines
column5: missiles and just about every other type of munition.

column1: 5476-I saw a very large passenger jet
column3: get hit by a missle and then crash into the sea.

column1: 5477-This jet was filled with Olympic athletes.
5478-At this point
column2: the dream becomes more of a movie and I am delegated to observer status.

column1: 5479-A rag-tag group of Americans decide that the only way to stop the Soviet Union is to infiltrate their country and kill their leader.
5480-The group of Americans consist of a female Olympic judge
column2: a 12-year-old girl and an older guy that looks like James Earl Jones.

column1: 5481-This group has to train to be able to infiltrate the country.
5482-Instead of learning military techniques
column2: they learn how to train water snakes.

column1: 5483-I don't remember how
column2: but all of a sudden the entire group is in the heart of the Soviet Union.

column1: 5484-The unnamed leader is hiding out in a rural town in a boarding house.
5485-The little girl sneaks upstairs
column3: to find the leader sleeping amongst 15 other people from the town.

column1: 5486-The girl places a rag of some sort of chemical over the leaders mouth
5487-Instead of just killing him
column2: the girl saws off his head with a dull machete and puts it into a burlap bag.

column1: 5488-No one has yet noticed anything has happened.
5489-She sneaks downstairs and runs outside.
5490-Just as she joins the rest of her group hiding behind a bush outside
column2: there is a sound much like the sharpening of a machete.

column1: 5491-From an open window upstairs
column2: the now-dead body of the leader with a ghostly head starts to appear in the window.

column1: 5492-At first
column2: it's safe to assume he is about to brandish a machete when instead he pulls out a .50 cal machine gun (the type that is normally truck mounted).

column1: 5493-Before he can fire
column2: the James Earl Jones character grabs a gun from the ground and sprays the leader with bullets.

column1: 5494-The end.

column1: 33-I've always been interested in VR and spent quite a bit of time working in VRML
column2: but I think the inherant problem with VRML was that not enough attention had been given to community.

column1: 34-You could build all these really cool places but people couldn't interact in them.
35-You also couldn't easily move from one 3D environment to another without going back and forth between 2D web pages.
36-I was involved with a project that tried to solve some of these problems with VRML (anybody remember Terra Vista?)
37-but it didn't as far as we would have liked.
38-Atmosphere appears to have addressed these problems.
39-It's not the first product to do so
column2: but maybe Adobe has enough muscle for it to gain wide acceptance.

265-Four or five years ago
column2: I had a sea-change in my computing experience.

column1: 266-One day
column2: I realized that I had started to view any computer not connected to the Internet as just a fancy game-console-cum-jumped-up-typewriter.

column1: 267-Working on an airplane or from a caf just felt wrong.
268-This feeling deepened and magnified a thousandfold the day I got my first iBook and Airport Base Station.
269-If you've used wireless networking on a laptop
column2: you know what I'm talking about -- snatching the Internet out of the very air is an experience you won't go back from willingly (another one is TiVo -- I've stopped watching TV in hotel rooms because I can't choose among thirty hours of custom-recorded programming and skip commercials).

column1: 270-Just as TiVo ruined me for dumb TV
column2: 802.11 ruined me for wired networking or no networking at all.

column1: 271-And it keeps on getting better.
272-802.11 isn't just a technology
column3: an ad-hoc world of open base-stations around the world.

334-If there's a message of the 'for dummies' age it's that nothing is beyond our grasp.
335-And our desire to believe this is reinforced by trends like usability
336-No one anticipated it all better than Marshall McLuhan
column2: who whittled big insights into sound bites in order to engage an audience beyond the lecture halls of the University of Toronto.

column1: 337-With the help of Tom Wolfe and others
column2: the scholarly McLuhan became a cool media prophet.

column1: 338-It was
column3: a practical strategy in anti-intellectual times.

column1: 339-But in the process
column2: much of McLuhan's meaning has been reduced to a one-liner.

column1: 340-This has as much to do with the absence of commentary on McLuhan's literary
column2: philosophical and cultural influences as it does with the way his work is taught.

column1: 407-Tucked away in one of the seediest neighborhoods of San Francisco is a roomful of over two hundred computers with a terabyte of data stored on every three.
408-Stairs from the street lead up an intimidating hallway that opens into a room with 15-foot ceilings and just-this-side of hip ductwork in the ceiling.
409-To the right is a storage area with a single desk
column2: to the left are Baker's racks tightly packed with off-the-shelf HP desktop machines
column3: each turned on it's side to maximize the space.

column1: 410-Somewhere in all that ductwork
411-Walking into this echoey
column3: it's easy to be underwhelmed until you realize what you are looking at: spinning away on these computers is nothing less than a copy of the Internet from 1996 until today.

413-The new issue has  urlLink a report  on the Supernova conference by Doug Roberts.
414-Supernova 2002 was an ambitious conference and Kevin Warbach
column3: acknowledged that from the outset when he said that he had crammed a three day conference into two days.

column1: 415-The conference was touted as a glimpse into the decentralized future.
416-Decentralized systems
column3: are systems that have no single point of control - the Internet is a perfect example.

column1: 417-No one entity or agency controls it
column2: no single server provides the service
column3: and no single point of failure will bring down the system.

column1: 418-Warbach sees these types of systems as the fundamental issue in computing for the next decade.
419-By then end of day one
column3: it became clear that the conference was going to be about one thing: blogging.

column3: is an insightful examination of the state and future of the medium.

column1: 513-Here's a snippet:   In the earliest days of television
column2: writers like George Orwell in  1984  and Ray Bradbury in  Fahrenheit 451  projected television as the instrumentality of a totalitarian future - a monolithic entity dispensing propaganda.

column1: 514-And
column2: if any of you occasionally watch Fox News
column3: you can see they weren't that far off the mark.

column1: 515-But here's the thing: the monolithic days of television are numbered.
516-Actually
column3: as yet

column1: 517-To understand why
column2: we need to go back to first principles.

column1: 518-What is television?
519-Here's a functional definition:   Television is the capture
column3: transmission
column5: decoding and display of moving images.

column1: 520-This definition applies to the Golden Age of television
521-Yet the definition of every word in the definition of television has changed
column2: because of the introduction of digital production
column3: encoding

column1: 0-       Every day should be a half day.
1-Took the afternoon off to hit the dentist
column2: and while I was out I managed to get my oil changed
column3: too.

column1: 2-Remember that business with my car dealership this winter?
3-Well
4-The friendly fellas at the Valvoline Instant Oil Change on Snelling were nice enough to notice that my dipstick was broken
column2: and the metal piece was too far down in its little dipstick tube to pull out.

column1: 5-Looks like I'm going to need a magnet.
6-Damn you
column3: daaaaaaammmnnn yooouuuu....   Today I let my boss know that I've submitted my Corps application.

column1: 7-The news has been greeted by everyone in the company with a level of enthusiasm that really floors me.
8-The back deck has finally been cleared off by the construction company working on the place.
9-This company
column3: consists mainly of one guy who spends his days cursing at his crew of Spanish-speaking laborers.

column1: 10-Construction of my deck began around the time Nixon was getting out of office.
11-Consider the ball rolling.
12-I've submitted my application and health review
column2: and I've made myself available for assignment starting March 2005.

column1: 13-I'm going to be back in the office environment again starting Thursday.
14-Cry for me.
15-Oh well
column2: I think hitting the submit button on my application tomorrow might actually make that return bearable.

column1: 16-I'm still not making any headway with my family.
17-In fact
column2: I think Mom has been rallying the troops (aka aunts and uncles) against me.

column1: 18-Meanwhile
column2: my friends have been really supportive of the idea.

column1: 19-Thanks
20-It's frustrating
21-Here
column2: I want to get out into the world
column3: have a pinch of adventure
column4: and maybe help some people out in the process
column5: and I'm earning the resentment of the entire freakin' family because of this.

column1: 22-I can only hope that
column3: cooler heads will prevail.

column1: 23-There's now a nationwide girlfriend hunt on for yours truly (hell
column3: this shit could go international)
column6: the cure for all this foolishness is for me to get laid.

column1: 24-Oh
column2: and I should buy myself something nice.

column1: 25-Problem solved.
26-Life is so sad.
27-Had a spot of Sunday night insomnia
column2: fueled mostly by my discussions with the parents yesterday.

column1: 28-Thankfully
column2: Jack Daniels helped me out with that.

column1: 29-Whoever is in charge of late night Sunday programming should be shot.
30-Sunday night insomnia is not an uncommon phenomenon
column2: and TV needs to be there for people in their hour(s) of need!

with each and every passing day its hard to imagine your going away... i still wake up every day cherishing your presence in a special way... no matter where i am or what i'm doing your always there in my heart... you never leave my mind
column3: i don't even try it would be to hard....  each minute away seems like a whole day and a different place.... each hour is spent picturing your smile and your face.... each thought becomes physical
column4: as i race to make it home.... excited to just see your face
column5: not have to talk on the phone....  i realize when i walk through the door i've been dreaming all day.... your more beautiful than i could ever dream now that we're face to face... as i wrap my arms around you and cherish we're in the same place... alls i can think of is your passionate kiss
column6: and how i've longed for its taste....  its time to relax now so we sit down and vent about our days... we talk about all we've done
column7: and how we missed each others face.... we spend our evenings together whoever said they needed space.... we wrap around each other as we drift away to our dreams... i'm laying next to the only girl i want how bad can life be.....  to many this is boring and just seems like killing time.... to me this is heaven and just being with what is mine.... listening to her breathe in my ear
column8: knowing just then shes fine.... we might be lame laying there all curled.... but i wouldn't change a thing
column9: i'm the happiest man in the world....

column1: 393-friend or no friend - guess what - i love her.

417-in the wake of our Wednesday night just when things started to feel normal again - with the lack of sleep .... and the over whelming frustration of the 'changes' happening between her and i... things went to shit.
418-we fought / went to bed / woke up and here we are again.... "ended".
419-i begged and pleaded all day and just when i was finished doing so... there you are ready to hang out and squash the entire episode... like this is a fucking game.
420-you heard me earlier on the phone.. ya know?

421-you know how upset all of this is making me... you know what you are capable of doing to me... yet one thing was different this evening... ALL day and early night you fucking treated me like total shit
column2: and acted as though what i was going through didn't matter too you and you gave two shits about how i felt only about what you wanted
column3: and about what you felt... you hardly gave me the time of the day other than answering your phone... yet one thing i did notice tonight that will help me out in the future...  the moment i came to reality... that there was nothing i could do
column4: and i am so sick and tired of one day bonnie and clyde against the world / next day bonnie and clyde shooting each other.... that i calmed down and acted like the shit didn't phase me.

column1: 422-the minute you called and heard that i was calmed down and i wasn't "emotional" about it anymore... then we were able to fucking squash the stupid bullshit and hang out and actually treat one another like humans... wait on that note... when don't you get treated like a human... i believe that if i talked to you the way you talk to me everytime you get mad... just talked to you ONCE like you talk to me all the time when your mad... you would leave... but i dont.. i stick around... and ya know.. i cant blame a single soul but myself when this hits rock bottom... because i see what your doing... i see what your capable of doing to me... and yet i stand around and take it ... because i have one thing that no matter what... WONT go away....  hope.
423-.....if you guys only knew....

column3: and until then we will keep whatever it is we have going on
column4: on the downlow... to stay under the radar and not get caught by her parents.

column2: and in every way shape and form... be sally.

column2: you see one of the main reasons i suffer so much from the harsh reality of loosing sally every now and then is because i do so much planning for the future with her - its like i get these visions and begin to form those into expectations... something that i really shouldn't do... but i do.

column1: 438-so i will start today taking it day by day... because i mean we are not obligated too one another right now but at the same time we kind of are... we hug / kiss / say i love you / like a rebel love if you will.

444-windows are down as the cool breeze goes by the music is on low so i can hear myself drive  i watch the lines in the road as they go by slow i hear the raine hitting my tires as if it were snow  i can smell the humidity flowing in the air my face is getting wet and i just dont care  every few seconds i watch my windshield get wiped its just at that moment i realize how alone i am tonight  i pull over in a empty lot with really bright lights i get my pen and pad cease the moment and start to write  i begin to observe all which i can see i begin to realize no one else is around but me  i ask myself questions hoping my heart will be honest i ask myself if im able to not be with her this august  its her birthday in 11 days and she is so far away how did all of this happen why wont we share that day  things im pondering inside my mind sitting in the car on august 10th instead of being with her ill go to the bar  not to drink away my pain and sorrow but to celebrate my life and the new tomorrow  1 year ago we were together in texas the farthest thing from our heads was that we would ever be ex's  part of me of course wishes that all of this was a dream but then again if it was i would have never found me  a guy that can sit in a empty lot writing his thoughts a guy that never use to give up on life but always fought  a guy that believed in himself every step of the way a guy that struggles for his future but still knows how to play  a guy that is secure enough to write how he feels a guy that is strong enough to stand up for his ideals  i realize that no matter what is going on with my mind im so happy in life right now why even look behind  life is music and you just have to learn how to dance i think i've learned enough now
column2: i'll give love another chance  here i am sitting alone in this lot with not a bit of fear if i could be anywhere else in the world i'd still be right here.

column1: 501-the smell of your skin is still tainted in my mind the warmth of your body at night knowing you were still mine  passion in our actions as we kissed away our days the sleepless nights that i would lay awake and pray  your hand upon my leg as we drive into the stars beyond the physical touch your passion went so far  chasing you to the room just to throw you down sitting on top of you staring not making a sound  eyes talking as if they were mouths emotions so pure they pour right out  as we would bath together i could smell your hair taking it for granted now i just think of you there  it is all the small things that i have grown to miss its the simple taken for granted things like a small kiss  feet cold enough to freeze the sun and cause a storm yet everynight i knew it was my job to keep them warm  no insecurities or doubts in my head just knowing you cared enough to look ahead  the dependence you put on me to become a man the dependence i had in you for you to hold my hand  i miss the romance and passion and comfort of love i miss the small things all the way down to a hug  i miss everything in life being more because it was you i miss the goodnights and the i love yous because i know they were true  so these are my secrets that my heart can not hide these are the feelings that im left dealing with inside  is there a cure for all of these deep thoughts will i ever find this again or are they lost.

column3: buttttttttttt yeah actually... that was the entire trip i wished she was there...   i didn't even see this picture until i got home and downloaded the pics
column4: someone must have took it while i was there day dreaming...   we got back to the campsite and sat around the fire telling jokes and what not

column1: 33-After this city I've always studied in Kendriya Vidyalayas(Central Schools in Hindi).
34-Amazingly there is nothing very remarkable about this city as far as modern times go.
35-But this city is steeped in Indian Mythology.
36-Lord Ram is said to have been here during his 14 years of forced exile.
37-Another feature of this place
column2: the roots of a Banyan tree which gives of leaves(you've got to see it to believe it)
column3: the very same Banyan tree is said to be several Millenia old and the British even tried to set it afire (out of plain old Malice)so that we'd lose this part of our heritage
column4: but this tree survived and is said to be one of the largest trees in India.

column1: 38-There is also a tunnel which is said to go all the way from Allahabad to Delhi.
39-People have tried to follow this tunnel but it ends due to a rockfall some distance inside.
40-I was here during the infamous Babri Masjid (Mosque) Demolition.
41-That was one shameful aspect of India's modern history
column2: when a bunch of Hooligans decided to break down the Mosque.

column1: 42-There was a lot of tension because of the demolition and the Army had to do Flag Marches and the like in certain localities to calm things down a bit.
43-I was also here during the infamous Anti Mandal Commision riots.
44-The riots took place because of the provision for reservation for the Backward classes in the Government jobs and other government owned and operated institutions.
45-A lot of heartburn took place in this country because of that one man who was responsible for this.
46-The amazing part is that man is alive and hopes to enter active politics again.
47-(To dispel any confusion it was not Mr Mandal
column2: But Prime Minister VP singh who actually implemented the commision report and is thus reviled for the reason).
