column1: Some months ago
column3: (the publisher of The Times of India and he Economic Times)
column4: I had a conversation with CTO of the group Internet company

column1: 353-Who asked me to put down some thoughts on how I see things on the internet shaping up.
354-While I did put down those thoughts
column2: I never actually sent it to him
column3: the file was lying around till I came across it a couple of days back.

column1: 355-Here is a rewrite of what I initially penned down (typed up?).
356-A lot of rambling about nothing in particular.
357-The positioning of a product or service is more and more targeted to more and more specific audiences?
358-Case in point are the BMW and Mercedes
column2: both are from fine German engineering pedigree
column3: both are premium luxury cars.

column1: 359-However the buyers of the two will probably as different as two people can be.
360-The former will be bought by a person who will drive the car himself and the latter probably by someone who has a chauffer (Yes
column2: I know Mercedes also makes sports cars this is the general perception that I expressed here).

column1: 361-Such a huge differentiation in mindset is what branding is all about.
362-This trend is seen in media as well.
363-The rise of niche publications in developed economies such as the US and UK is illustrative of this.
364-Any media would broadly undergo the distinct phases of consolidation in the growth phase and then  fragmentation once the medium matures.
365-The internet is perhaps one medium which fragmented even before it matured.
366-This is perhaps explained by the global reach of the media and the fact that ideas can be easily replicated across geographical  political boundaries; i.e.
367-something that works in America
column2: will almost certainly not work in India
column3: simply because the maturity of the American market is of a different order of magnitude.

column1: 368-To illustrate this point further the existence and flourishing of sites like epinions.com (in the American context) and the apparent non-starter of the Indian equivalent mouthshut.com which are sources of information.
369-Or price comparison sites like mySimon.com which as far as I know has no comparable Indian site.
370-With this brief background
column2: it would be instrumental to see the whole internet game in a different perspective .

column1: 371-The internet tends to promote the formation of groups of people with very specific interests.
372-A sort of mother of all niche publications
column2: which you can talk back to and whats more it talks back to you and allows you to communicate with your peer group.

column1: 373-While the Bennet philosophy has been to be an aggregator of audiences by subsidizing the price the audience pays to retrieve content and then retrieving profit from the purchasing those audiences.
374-This can prove counter productive as far as the Internet goes
column2: as the internet has people who are used to getting content for free and are likely to freeload.

column1: 375-On the other hand the audience which does pay to retrieve the content would then be most prized and wanted by an advertiser
column2: if nothing to prove non frivolousness of their transaction with us.

column1: 376-The idea would be to convince the mass populace that information is of value.
377-The easiest way to ensure that is to look for focused verticals in the information segment.
378-The first one that comes to mind is economictimes.com or more accurately perhaps the work of ETIG.
379-The biggest problem that one can make out is how will people pay for it online.
380-Multimodal payment mechansims are already in use by the Indiatimes family of websites.
381-Virtual currency of some kind can perhaps be also created for this purpose.
382-What about the business we are in?
383-Content can take several forms
column2: one of the forms could be that of blogs (such as the one you are reading right now).

column1: 384-Blogs are the latest rage in America
column2: now spreading to other parts of the world.

column1: 385-Blogs are nothing but a personal running commentary on the world in general and sometimes specific to a topic.
386-Another form could be in the form of reviews.
387-Reviews can be on any topic
column2: from the palces to party  eat out in Delhi to where to find the best shoes in Chandini Chowk.

column1: 388-Ineractivity which needs to be the cornerstone of such an offering.
389-Such content may well be in the form of a blog.
390-Traditional content in the form of newspapers
column3: Radio will definitely migrate in one form or the other to the web.

column1: 391-Evolution of devices like the Microsoft Tablet PC or the Handspring Treo are definitely a step in that direction.
392-In that respect standardisation under one name a la indiatimes.com is probably the biggest single mistake being undertaken by us and many others across the world.
393-This conclusion is based on our initial premise that internet promotes the formation of specific focus groups.
394-By definition these focus groups would be unlikey to turn to a general interest portal to get their kicks so to speak.
395-The creation of multiple brands would be a better branding and strategic idea
column2: having a ghoomnahai.com rather than having something like Indiatimes Travel.

column1: 396-This gives an identity to the content and makes it more valued by its consumers.
397-The above
column2: when seen in the overall context of evolution of media
column3: is a perfectly logical sequence of events.

column1: 398-Growing media consolidates
399-During the growth phase it is perfectly acceptable to have a single brand name
column2: but the moment the medium matures (maybe in the context of the limited audience it gathers in the Indian scenario)   Show me the money!!!

column1: 400-Whether people will pay to read ( someday in the future see) such content is debatable.
401-The likes of Al Ries would have us believe that advertising will never work on the internet (which is something I disagree with strongly).
402-So what will happen?
403-Will the internet become a subversive medium which will undermine modern society as we know it.
404-A sort of a no mans land where no content will be paid for?
405-products and services being the only ones able to draw any sort of revenue?
406-The Truth as the immortal words form X Files go is out there...
407-My personal suspicion is that heavily prized content a la NYT or WSJ will not only be paid for
column2: but will also attract significant advertising revenues.

column1: 408-For the rest
column2: creation of strong niches will allow them to do the same   PS: Don't hesitate to comment...

The Festival of Lights  This is one of the oldest Hindu festivals occuring in the month of Kartik
column2: which commemorates the return of Rama to Ayodhya after an exile of 14 years.

column1: 511-It also marks the beginning of the new year and is celebrated with the lighting of lamps.
512-Diwali or Deepawali
column3: is the festival of lights and is celebrated on the darkest night of Kartik.

column1: 513-It is perhaps the most important festival in India.
514-Originally a Hindu festival
column2: it has now crossed the bounds of religion and is celebrated by all in India with fervor and gaiety.

column1: 515-This day is a public holiday all over India.
516-Twinkling oil lamps or diyas light up every home and firework displays are common all across the country.
517-The goddess Lakshmi (consort of Vishnu)
column2: who is the symbol of wealth and prosperity
column3: is also worshipped on this day.

column1: 518-This festive occasion also marks the beginning of the Hindu new year and Lord Ganesha
column3: the symbol of auspiciousness and wisdom
column4: is also worshipped in most Hindu homes on this day.

column1: 519-Another view is that Deepawali is meant to celebrate the destruction of the arrogant tyrant Bali at the hands of Vishnu when the latter appeared in his Vamana (dwarf) avatar.
520-The occasion of Deepawali sees the spring-cleaning and white-washing of houses; decorative designs or rangolis are painted on floors and walls.
521-New clothes are bought and family members and relatives gather together to offer prayers
column2: distribute sweets and to light up their homes.

column1: 522-Diwali is also perhaps the oldest festival still celebrated today and is mentioned in the Ramayana.
523-The celebrations include the lighting of lamps and candles
524-Friends and neighbours exchange special sweets.
525-People buy new clothes and in fact
column3: it is absolutely essential to wear new clothes on this day.

column1: 526-Diwali in India is equivalent to Christmas in the West.
527-Therefore it is also the time when people get the festival bonus to their salaries.
528-It marks the beginning of the new year for a large majority of Hindus
529-Preparations for the festival begin many days prior to Diwali.
530-It is time for a thorough cleaning of the house
column2: for the belief is that Lakshmi will enter clean and nicely decorated houses.

column1: 531-The scientific reason is that the monsoon is a time for insects and fungus to breed.With the end of the monsoon
column2: homes need to be cleaned and painted
column3: and belongings aired and dried before the onset of winter.

column1: 532-The festival itself extends over about a week even though the most important day is the new moonday.
533-In east Bihar and northern India
column2: two days before Diwali is celebrated as Dhanteras in honour of Dhanvantari
column3: the physician of the gods.

column1: 534-He is believed to have emerged with a pot of amrita during the samudra manthan.
535-People bathe early in the morning and observe a fast
column2: which is broken only after sunset with sweetmeats
column3: puri and other delicacies.

column1: 536-On Dhanteras
column2: new kitchen utensils are bought and kept at the place of worship.

column1: 537-The buying of utensils
column3: relates to the myth of Dhanvantari emerging from the ocean with a pot in his hand.

column1: 538-Since he is also the physician of the gods
column2: cleanliness and hygiene are essential to this festival.

column1: 539-The day before Diwali is celebratedas Choti Diwali or 'small Diwali'.
540-It is Diwali on a smaller scale
column2: with fewer lights lit and fewer crackers burst.

column1: 541-The morning after Choti Diwali
column2: the women of the house make beautiful
column3: coloured rangoli in the doorway and courtyard.

column1: 542-Tiny footprints made out of rice paste are a special feature of the rangolis made for Diwali.
543-They signify the footprints of Lakshmi
544-In Hindu homes
column2: Diwali celebrations involve a ritual puja to Lakshmi and also to Rama in the evening.

column1: 545-Songs in honour of the gods are sung and arati is performed.
546-Oil or ghee diyas are also lit.
547-The gods are offered kheel
column2: batashe and khilone and various sweetmeats.

column1: 548-After the puja
column2: the diyas are placed in and around the house: in the doorway
column3: near the Tulasi plant
column5: every room and the back and front gates.

column1: 549-After this
column3: and people meet friends and neighbours to exchange good wishes and sweets.

column1: 550-Since Diwali falls on the new moon night
column2: lamps are lit to brighten this moonless night.

column1: 551-According to a myth
column2: Lakshmi will not enter a dark house.

column1: 552-The lamps also welcome home the spirits of dead ancestors
column2: who are believed to visit on this auspicious night.

column1: 553-In addition
column2: the light frightens away any evil spirit that might be wandering about near the house on this night.

column1: 554-In Orissa
column2: lamps are lit to light up the dark path that the spirits of ancestors take back to heaven.

column1: 555-In modern times
column2: ghee diyas have been replaced by wax candles and coloured electric bulbs.

column1: 556-In many areas
column2: there is a competition of sorts among neighbours as everyone tries to have the brightest lights.

column1: 557-The origin of Diwali can be traced back to ancient India
column2: when it was probably an important harvesting season.

column1: 558-It was thus extremely important to the largely pastoral Vaishya community.
559-Their granaries were full
column3: at the end of the long monsoon and before the arduous winter.

column1: 560-It was therefore a good time to celebrate.
561-The Vaishya community began their new year with this happy occassion
column2: after paying their debts and clearing their ledgers.

column1: 562-As the religion developed
column2: various mythological stories and explanations were attributedto this festival to give it religious sanction.

column1: 563-However today
column2: this historical explanation is all but lost among the many stories and folklore linked with the origin of the festival.

column1: 564-According to the most popular one
column2: Diwali is celebrated in honour of Rama
column3: his consort Sita and brother Lakshmana
column4: returning to their kingdom Ayodhya after a 14-year exile.To celebrate this event
column5: people at Ayodhya are believed to have lit up their houses with lamps.

column1: 565-The illuminations also symbolise the removal of spiritual darkness and the onset of happiness and prosperity.
566-According to another belief
column2: it is on this day that Lakshmi emerged from the ocean during the samudra manthan .Lakshmi Puja commemorates her birth and therefore forms a major part of Diwali celebrations.

column1: 567-Being associated with the goddess of wealth and fortune
column2: Diwali is specially important to the Vaishya   community.

column1: 568-Most tradesmen close their old ledgers and dealings and start afresh with new ledgers after Diwali.
569-This day
column3: is also considered lucky for gambling.

column1: 570-Giving social sanction to a vice
column2: a popular saying states that one who does not gamble on this day will beborn a donkey in his next birth.

column1: 571-Casinos and local gambling houses do brisk business during the Diwali week.
572-In most homes
column2: people invite their friends and relatives over to play cards.

column1: 573-Another reason for the celebration of Diwali is that it marks the killing of the evil Narkasura at the hands of Krishna Naraka is believed to have abducted 16
574-Krishna killed him and rescued these women whom he later married.
575-Naraka is the personification of hell and is believed to be the monsoon during which all activities come to a standstill.
576-Though Diwali is equally important in the south and the north
577-In South India
column2: the story widely associated with Diwali is that of Narasimha
column3: the man-lion incarnation of Vishnu.

column1: 578-According to a legend
column2: Hiranyakshipu was an evil demon king.

column1: 579-He was unjust and cruel to his people.
580-However
column3: having extracted a boon from Brahma that he would be killed neither by beast nor man
column5: neither during the day nor at night.

column1: 581-When his atrocities became unbearable
582-Assuming his fifth incarnation of Narasimha
column3: Vishnu killed Hiranyakshipu with his claws in the courtyard just before day break
column4: hence steering clear of the boundaries of the boon.

column1: 583-For this reason in the south
column2: people light diyas in their houses on the day preceding Diwali.

column1: 584-The next day begins early.
585-First is the ritual bath
column2: which begins with an oil massage of the hair and body.

column1: 586-This is absolutely essential on this day.
587-Its importance probably refers to cleaning oneself thoroughly after the monsoon months.
588-After bathing
column2: people receive new clothes and gifts from their elders
column3: which they are expected to wear.

column1: 589-The family then prays to Vishnu for its well-being and prosperity.
590-After the prayers start the main celebrations which
column3: consist of bursting crackers and lighting candles.At day break
column4: all celebrations end.People then visit friends and relatives and exchange sweets.

column1: 591-References to the word 'atishbaji' or'crackers' are found even in ancient literature.
592-The bursting of crackers is today the most important and eagerly-awaited part of the Diwali celebrations.
593-According to one belief
column2: the sound that resounds throughout the universe makes all aware of the great homecoming of Rama.

column1: 594-Another belief is that the crackers are an indication ofthe joy of the people living on the earth
column2: making the gods aware of their plentiful state.

column1: 595-Still another possible reason has a more scientific basis: the fumes produced by the crackers kill a lot of insects
column2: found in plenty after the rains.

column1: 596-The use of high-tech bomb crackers is fairly recent.
597-At times
column3: especially in the metropolitan cities.

column1: 598-In New Delhi
column2: people start bursting crackers in the evening and this continues till the early hours ofthe morning.

column1: 599-As a result
column2: the city is engulfed in toxic fumes and smoke for almost 10 hours.

column1: 600-Another problem with crackers is that their manufacture is usually unregulated.
601-As a result
column2: the manufacturing units are unsafe and the material used is inflammable and toxic.Every year
column3: many units are destroyed inaccidental fires
column4: resulting in the death of those employed there.

column1: 602-Kerala is probably the only state in India where even Hindus do not celebrate Diwali.
603-The major festival there is Onam.
604-In West Bengal
column2: Kali Puja is performed on Diwali as it is believed that on this day Kali killed the wicked Raktavija.

column1: 605-Being one of the main festivals of the trader community
column2: markets are gaily decorated and lit up.

column1: 606-Many safety measures and precautions are telecast on television and radio
607-The fire departments are kept on the alert
column2: and the municipal corporations of bigger cities also organise buckets and tankers of water at strategic locations.

column1: 608-The second day after Diwali is celebrated as Bhai Duja when sisters apply tilak to their brothers and pray for their long and happy life.
609-In all likelihood
column2: this ritual was originally intended only for married women.

column1: 610-Since they celebrated Diwali with their in-laws
column2: this festival allowed them to come to their parents' home during this auspicious time.

column1: 611-They got some time to meet the family and to rest after the hectic activity of the preceding week.And it gave their parents an opportunity to give them gifts
column2: an opportunity they did not often get.

column1: 612-Nowadays however
column2: among many communities Bhai Duja is observed by both married and unmarried sisters.

In an Economist feature  urlLink The World In 2004  A story on the Smart Dust revolution.
784-Alun Andersen
column2: the Editor in Chief comments that for decades we have considered progress to be packing of more and more transistors on less and less silicon... Progress he argues is
column3: things like the coming smart dust revolution.

column1: 785-Smart dust or more accurately networked intelligenece to do  hazaar  things like do remote surveliiance for the military.

786-or the use of RFID in supermarkets... enabling tracking of merchandise and a  fully automated staff less  supermakret...    For almost 40 years we have all been subscribing to a simple dogma about the growth of the information age: progress means making more and more computing power available at lower and lower prices.
787-Back in 1965 Gordon Moore laid out his famous law that the number of components that could be squeezed on to a silicon chip would double every year or two.
788-Now everybody can buy a laptop computer with the computing power that entire nations were aspiring to in the 1970s.
789-Moores law still has a long future.
790-But in 2004 the belief that progress means packing in ever more computing power will be seen as far too narrow.
791-Just arriving is another kind of information revolution
column2: driven by the ability to manufacture billions of tiny
column3: intelligent communicating sensors.

column1: 792-Capable of organising themselves into networks
column2: intelligent sensors will make up for their small brains by their immense numbers.
